HEADLINE: Little Real Outrage Over a Thinner Blue Line 

BYLINE:  By SHAILA K. DEWAN 

 BODY:
It has not been so very long since New York was a city where, it was said, if you were killed on the street, people would just step over you and keep walking and where the police were more likely to be seen seen as intruders rather than protectors. 
 In some neighborhoods there is less psychological distance from those times than others. Still, it could perhaps be taken as an indicator of how far the city has come that when Lisa Greenfield heard there was a possibility of police layoffs in the city, her first thought was not of crime, but of the men and women who would lose their jobs. 
 "As far as I'm concerned, it would be a shame for their job security, especially since last year," she said as she pushed her daughter Onyx in a swing at Fort Greene Park in Brooklyn on Friday afternoon. "Their job is one of the most unappreciated."
Ms. Greenfield was not wholly sanguine about the fate of her own neighborhood. "I wish there would be more beat cops," she said. But, she added, she would not want to decide between cutting police officers or cutting education, if that is what budgetary realities came down to.
In a smattering of interviews throughout the city, people agreed that they did not want to see fewer officers on the street. But they could not muster much outrage about the possibility of layoffs because they understood that the city faced difficult times. 
"You can't cut firemen, police or children's services," said Richard Parmenter, a truck driver, as he made a delivery. 
But he did not want to see much of a reduction, either, in trash pickup, or libraries, or health care or parks. "No, no, no, no," he said. But, he added, "There's got to be something that they don't need." 
Mr. Parmenter was not entirely convinced that the money needed was not already somewhere in the system. "I don't know how there could be a budget deficit," he said, gesturing at his delivery truck parked against the curb. "They raised the tickets to $110."
Mr. Parmenter said that his neighborhood, Greenpoint, in Brooklyn, would not be affected by a reduction in the police force. But in Crown Heights, a neighborhood that has not kept pace with the rest of the city's decline in crime, people feared a surge of violence if there were any letup in policing.
"The young people, you don't know how they think," said Joyce Noel from behind the counter of Joyce's Cafe on Utica Avenue. "If they see cops across the street, they're definitely not going to do anything." In the staggering economy, she added, more people were unemployed, which meant more people would be tempted to commit crimes. 
Judy Rios, 35, stood on a corner waiting for her daughter to come home from school and watching a patrol car move slowly through the park across the street. Ms. Rios, a nursing assistant, moved two years ago to Crown Heights from East New York, where, she said, crime was rampant. She feels safer now. But she understands that the city has to save money.
"Over here, I need it. I need some police," said Jose Garcia, handing out change in his family's coin laundry in Harlem. "At night, I feel safe," Mr. Garcia added. But what if , say, only one in 20 officers was cut? It would be O.K. to cut one of 20, he said. "One police. Not 10."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Jose Garcia, in his family's coin laundry in Harlem, said that he could support limited cuts to the police force in his area, but nothing drastic. (Ting-Li Wang/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Personal Business; 
Class-Action Suits Mean Delays and, Maybe, Cash

BYLINE:  By LYNNLEY BROWNING 

 BODY:
WHENEVER Ira W. David hears about yet another big class-action lawsuit, he is overcome with mixed emotions.
 Last fall, Mr. David, the owner of a small software marketing company in Las Vegas, received a check for $19,889.23. The money was his share of an $11 million award against Computer Associates International, a software company found by a federal jury more than two years ago to have violated securities laws in its purchase of the privately held On-Line Software International in 1991. Computer Associates was accused of secretly paying a higher per-share price to On-Line's chairman. Mr. David, 54, who owned 7,250 shares and options in the acquired company, was part of a class-action suit filed against Computer Associates about 12 years ago. 
 He said he viewed his settlement check as "found money," because he is a former executive at On-Line Software who had bought his stock at a discount and had actually made around $25,000 when the company was acquired. "It's putting me through law school," he said. 
But that was only one experience. Mr. David has had a far less rewarding one involving a shareholder class-action lawsuit against a former online prescription drugstore, PlanetRx.com. Mr. David, who said he had lost $15,200 after investing in the company, said he expected little or no money from any future settlement with that company because it had few assets remaining. The lawsuit, which is pending, also accuses some of PlanetRX.com's underwriters of inflating the company's initial public offering price in 1999. 
At least 10,000 class-action suits are filed each year, and billions of dollars are ultimately awarded to consumers. Anyone who, on designated dates, invested in or did business with a company that is named in a class-action suit can join in. The process usually involves filling out forms and scaring up old receipts or financial statements. But just because you may qualify to share in a settlement doesn't necessarily mean you will receive instant wealth, as Mr. David's contrasting experiences show.
Barry A. Weprin, a lawyer at Milberg Weiss Bershad Hynes & Lerach in New York, a firm regarded in the industry as a leading filer of class-action suits, said, "Many people seem to think that they're going to get a lot more than they actually end up getting."
Usually, the lawyers who bring the suits stand to gain the most. Nearly all class-action suits are brought on a contingency basis, which means that lawyers are paid a percentage of any recovery. The damage award can grow with additional plaintiffs.
Institutional investors are often big winners as well. Financial institutions like mutual fund families have a big incentive to step forward: they own large blocks of stock and constitute about half the claims class in securities-fraud lawsuits. These institutions typically put their payouts directly into the funds that own or owned stock in the company that settled.
Lawyers say relatively few individuals -- nobody knows precisely how many -- make the effort to receive what is legally theirs. Stanley M. Grossman, a senior partner at the Pomerantz Haudek Block Grossman & Gross law firm in New York, said that in the average securities-fraud case, only half of those eligible join in. For consumer-fraud cases, the estimates are even lower. Roger W. Kirby, a lawyer at Kirby McInerney & Squire, a firm in New York, said he had heard of cases in which only 6 percent of the class members had submitted claims. Many cases drag on for so many years, he said, that class members either forget about them or move, leaving no way for settlement administrators to contact them about how to collect. Unclaimed payments may be divided among other members of the class, awarded to charities or returned to the defendant.
Sometimes there is little worth claiming. In a 1996 memo for the Manhattan Institute, a research organization in New York, Lawrence W. Schonbrun, a securities lawyer, described a settlement check written to one class member for 14 cents, complete with four pages of instructions on how to report the payment to the Internal Revenue Service. Although cash claims worth less than $5 are often not paid, some settlements offer other compensation of dubious value: discount coupons for goods or services from the very company whose products or services prompted the lawsuits.
Mr. David said he first received information about the lawsuit against Computer Associates in 1994 from Kirby McInerney & Squire, which had filed the suit against the company in 1991. He filled out and returned a form that was included with the mailed information. But a database glitch -- he said he did not know where -- meant that he later had to dig out old brokerage-firm receipts for his shares and mail those in, too. Mr. Kirby, the lawyer, said claim forms were also mailed last January, but Mr. David could not remember whether he had to fill one out. Checks from the case, one of the rare class-action cases to go to trial, were mailed about a month ago. 
"It was painless," Mr. David said of the procedure, "but a little stretched out."
In many cases, class members may be disappointed. Bulent Pektas, 38, a manager of a car repair shop in Jersey City, said he was told recently by his lawyers to expect a $99 check in coming weeks from Hewlett-Packard. It was his share, he said he had been told, of the company's estimated $11 million settlement last month over accusations from customers of false advertising. 
Mr. Pektas said he bought a Hewlett-Packard DVD burner more than a year ago for $599 after seeing advertisements that promoted DVD burners with free internal upgrades. But he said the upgrade was canceled. He said the company said that it was technologically not feasible, and instead told consumers they could pay $99 to trade in their old DVD burners for upgraded ones.
"It's not a fair deal,"' Mr. Pektas complained of the settlement. He said he would never have bought the Hewlett-Packard product had he known it could not be internally upgraded -- especially when that product was now selling for less than $300. 
Hewlett-Packard had no comment on Mr. Pektas's complaints, said Kevin P. Beagley, a company spokesman.
Mr. Pektas said he learned he was a class member late last year, when he received an e-mail notice of the suit and a claim form from Faruqi & Faruqi, a New York law firm that had sued Hewlett-Packard. As part of its settlement, the company supplied the law firm with information from product registration forms to track class members. 
Mr. Pektas said he had to mail in a notarized form including the serial number of his DVD burner. But he said that when he had called Hewlett-Packard's claims administrators recently to check on his award, he had been told they had no record of his having submitted a claim. "I guess you could say I'm a little bit disappointed," he said.
He said he would continue to check on the status, although he is prepared to submit another claim.
Legal experts debate the degree to which settlements compensate individuals for their losses. Citing widely used figures, Michael A. Perino, a specialist in securities law and an associate professor at St. John's University School of Law in Queens, said claimants for all types of cases typically recovered 8 percent to 15 percent of their overall losses. But when securities-fraud settlements are computed on the basis of losses directly tied to a company, and not those from declining markets or other factors, the recovered amount climbs to 34 percent, according to Mr. Kirby. Attorneys' fees typically take about 20 percent of settlements, including expenses.
Since 1995, the median settlement has nearly doubled, to $16.5 million, according to Frederick C. Dunbar, senior vice president for data at National Economic Research Associates, a consulting firm in New York. The average settlement since 1995 is $27.2 million, but Mr. Dunbar said that figure was potentially misleading because of huge settlements like the $2.83 billion in 1999 with the Cendant Corporation, a record in a securities case. (In addition, its former auditor, Ernst & Young, agreed to pay $335 million.)
Several factors are behind the increase in settlement amounts. A 1995 law made it tougher for lawsuits to receive court certification to proceed toward settlement or trial, producing more meritorious cases in recent years. The boom on Wall Street in the mid- to late 1990's swelled corporate coffers, making more money available for settlements. Securities-fraud cases, which are typically settled for twice as much as other cases, also have increased in recent years.
But a welter of big-dollar, class-action lawsuits against scandal-plagued companies like WorldCom, Enron and Adelphia Communications may also result in awards of dubious merit. Mr. Dunbar said that warrants, which are securities to purchase stock in a company at a future date, had been increasingly common as awards in securities-fraud lawsuits for companies lacking the cash or insurance to settle for large amounts. But warrants can be worth little if a company's stock is already depressed, and they dilute the interests of existing shareholders.
IN any case, investors wounded by the downturn on Wall Street should not count on joining class-action lawsuits to recoup their losses.
Steven H. Rosner, a retired small-business owner in Miami, knows that all too well. In November, he received a check for $2,918.20 from Assisted Living Concepts of Portland, Ore., a chain of residences for the elderly. The money was his share of a $10 million settlement that the company reached more than two years ago with investors over allegations that it falsified its financial statements. Mr. Rosner, 60, estimated that he had lost about $15,000 on the $25,000 he invested in Assisted Living bonds.
"Better than nothing," he said of his recent check. "But it doesn't make up my losses."

HEADLINE: Footlights 

BYLINE:  By ROBERTA HERSHENSON; E-mail address: westarts@nytimes.com

 BODY:
Toward Racial Harmony
The world holds different challenges than in 1992, when Pepsico and the Westchester Philharmonic organized the first Music America as a tribute to the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., but the county event is still held each January in the name of nonviolence and racial harmony.
 The concert draws a diverse audience, who go to hear a mix of jazz, spirituals and orchestral music and raise money for causes ranging from fair housing to Holocaust remembrance. 
 The music is provided by the Westchester Philharmonic, whose music director and conductor, Paul Lustig Dunkel, is committed to entertainment that builds bridges. 
The concert, which takes place next Saturday at 7:30 p.m. at the Performing Arts Center of Purchase College, and the dinner reception preceding it, will benefit 15 groups this year including the Center for Preventive Psychiatry in White Plains and the Mount Vernon Firehouse Hip-Hop Museum.
The featured artists are the Valerie Capers Ensemble, led by Ms. Capers, a jazz pianist, composer and arranger (pictured at left); and Brenda Schaffer Weiner, a singer who appears in opera and musical theater.
Mr. Dunkel has composed "From the Mountain," which incorporates Dr. King's writings as well as the words of five African-American poets. Mr. Dunkel will also play the flute solo in Nathaniel Hailstork's "Pied Piper of Harlem." 
Pepsico, J.P. Morgan Chase & Company and the Abraham Fund/Alan B. Slifka Foundation are the main sponsors. 
Tickets to the dress rehearsal on Saturday at 10 a.m. are $5. Tickets to the concert are $20 and $35; tickets at $70 and $85 include the reception, which starts at 5:30 p.m.
Information: (914) 682-3707, extension 10. 

New Arts President
The Westchester Arts Council's new president, Jamie Shenkman, is a writer and publicist whose grandfather was the late Jacob Burns, a Manhattan lawyer and philanthropist for whom the popular film center in Pleasantville was named. (She is also a trustee of the Jacob Burns Foundation, which gave a major gift to help establish the center in 2001.) She took over Jan. 1 from LaRuth Gray, who continues as deputy director of the Metropolitan Center for Urban Education at New York University. 
Ms. Shenkman became a member of the council's board in 1995, continuing a love for the arts that began in childhood. She writes short stories and works for Thompson & Bender in Briarcliff Manor, a publicity firm whose accounts include the Jacob Burns Film Center. "I really believe the arts are important," she said. "Not only as a creative outlet but also as an economic stimulant."

A Battle Remembered
The Battle of White Plains in 1776 left 300 British and Hessian troops dead or wounded and caused 150 American casualties. The battle gained time for General George Washington and his army, who moved on to Peekskill without the British pursuing them. The conflict is re-enacted in a 1978 docudrama, "The Battle of White Plains," which was sponsored by the White Plains Historical Society, filmed by the Film Workshop of Westchester and directed by Mark Sadan. The 30-minute black and white film will be shown free Wednesday at 7 p.m. at the White Plains Public Library. Jack Harrington, president of the society, will introduce the film and lead a discussion afterward. 
Information (914) 422-1480. 

Chapters in C Minor
A father-and-son power struggle, a vow that helped win a woman's heart, a death that derailed the premiere of a masterpiece: Read all about it at www.thegrandmass.org, a Web site that tells the story of Mozart's C minor Mass in chapters like "The Inextricable Opposites," "A Family Torn Asunder" and "The C Minor Mystery."
The Web site was designed and written by Scott Anderson of Hastings-on-Hudson, whose wife, Melanie, is a member of the Hastings-based Hudson Valley Singers. The 73-member chorus will perform the rarely heard Mass -- which is "far more ambitious and elaborate than the 'Requiem,' " said Mr. Anderson -- with a 33-piece orchestra next Sunday at 3 p.m. at the Presbyterian Church in White Plains. Eugene Sirotkine, the chorus's music director (who is also assistant chorusmaster of the Metropolitan Opera), will conduct the concert, which features soloists from the Met chorus.
Tickets range from $12 to $20. Information: (914) 674-2865.
 ROBERTA HERSHENSON

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW; 
No Need To Wring Hands Over Retail Sales

BYLINE:  By TOM REDBURN 

 BODY:
THE worst Christmas in 30 years.
 That's what all the retail experts said, and the news media, regrettably, pretty much reported it that way, too. 
 Or as The New York Times put it, in accurately describing the report of Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi, "growth in United States retail sales for the months of November and December, at 1.5 percent, was the lowest it had been since at least 1970, when the bank began keeping track."
But that's not even close to the truth. In fact, there have been quite a few holiday shopping seasons since 1970 that were worse -- some a lot worse. 
Real retail sales -- adjusted, as they should be, for changes in prices of the goods sold -- have actually fallen several times since 1970. Moreover, there have been other years when they eked out only modest gains. By contrast, real sales for the 2002 season are expected to show a healthy gain of about 4 to 5 percent over the previous year. 
That doesn't mean it was a great year for holiday shopping. It wasn't. But it's just as misleading to conclude, as The Wall Street Journal put it in a headline on Friday: "It's Official: Retailers Had a Crummy Holiday."
How can we have gotten it so wrong? Much of the problem arises because retailers report sales in nominal terms, not taking account of the typical inflation that occurs every year. Lately, it has become even more confusing, because prices of many retail products have been falling sharply.
So, because of deflation in retail goods, the slight gain in nominal sales for 2002 -- indeed low by historical standards -- masks a significantly greater increase. In the past, when inflation was rampant, consumers could spend a lot more than they did in the previous year but go home with less-valuable stuff.
Why bother with this arcane explanation of what economists call the "money illusion"? Because the failure to account for this simple difference leads to a serious misunderstanding of the economy.
Steven Wieting, a senior economist at Salomon Smith Barney, pointed this out in a report last week explaining why so many people have an interest in perpetuating the holiday shopping myth.
"Presumably, if you are bearish on the stock market, the worst consumer in 30 years would help justify your position." he wrote. "If you are bullish, such a notion might leave you drooling over thoughts of 'pent up' consumer demand on the rebound. Perhaps, if you are a retail executive, the alleged worst consumer in 30 years might provide you with cover for bad execution."
In fact, consumer spending held up surprisingly well during the 2001 recession and was decent last year as the economy began its lackluster rebound. The implication for this year, boring as that may be, is for more of the same.
"You shouldn't be looking for a recovery," Mr. Wieting said in an interview, "in something that hasn't collapsed."
Indeed, for all the talk of how consumer spending represents the bulk of the nation's economic activity, changes in business investment and inventories are far more important swing forces in the economy.
"The consumer has cushioned every economic downturn," Mr. Wieting added, "and restrained every recovery."
THE focus in retailing on same-store sales -- those for stores open at least a year -- also paints a distorted picture. Same-store sales may be useful for evaluating the success of one chain versus another, but they miss the just as important growth in consumption that occurs at new outlets.
It's easy to understand, then, why Paul Farhi wrote in an excellent article last week in The Washington Post: 
"This is the season in which journalists pore over retailers' receipts, interview a few wise people and reflect on What It All Meant. Here's what it all meant, this season and every one before it: almost nothing."
I'm not willing to go that far. You can learn a lot about the economy from properly interpreting trends in retailing and consumer spending. And it helps to understand how big retailers can repeatedly complain about poor sales while still generating good profits and building plenty of new stores.
Just remember the difference between the money illusion and reality.

GRAPHIC: Chart: "A Not-So-Bad Holiday"Retail sales, adjusted for price changes in goods. Graph tracks real non-auto retail sales year-over-year change, plotted monthly, from the 70's through November 2002. (Source: Salomon Smith Barney)

HEADLINE: FILM; 
Upward Mobility And Downright Lies

BYLINE:  By CARYN JAMES

 BODY:
YOU want to end up back in the projects? Keep dreaming dreams that'll never happen," warns the heroine's mother in "Maid in Manhattan," when it looks like her daughter the chambermaid has lost the rich, handsome politician she loves. Gee, thanks, Mom. 
 In this Cinderella tale, the wicked non-stepmother has offered what amounts to the anti-moral of the story. We know that Marisa the maid's dreams will come true because she is Jennifer Lopez, because the trajectory of the film is obvious from its first two minutes, and because in old-fashioned Hollywood movies like this, character always transcends class, and class itself is no more than a tiny speed bump that good-hearted people can hop over. 
 What's more surprising is that this backward notion of easy upward mobility -- which defies recent socio-economic studies -- is so tenacious that it exists even in a far smarter, better, more realistic film like "Real Women Have Curves," the story of Ana, a working-class Latina whose mother doesn't want her to go to college. Here characters are believably hemmed in by class: Ana's complicated, resentful mother worries that her daughter's education will tear the family apart; her father is a gardener who has put aside just a little money; her sister is the struggling owner of a small shop that sews dresses for big companies for a pittance. Yet even this shrewdly observed film, which so matter-of-factly links Ana's immigrant family with her working-class limitations, invents a fairy tale to catapult her upward.
She has graduated from high school without having applied to colleges, but a sympathetic Hispanic teacher at her Beverly Hills school (how she got there the film never explains) writes a letter to his friend, the dean of Columbia University, who magically admits Ana at the last minute with a full scholarship. Tell that to all the parents of students hiring tutors and sweating out college admissions.
What these movies reveal is not just film's addiction to fantasy, which audiences expect and embrace, but also to the Big Lie that class is meaningless in American life. Beneath the fairy dust of "Maid in Manhattan" and the grittiness of "Real Women Have Curves" is a similar message: not that America is a classless society, but that class is as fluid as water and upward mobility a cinch.
The idea, of course, goes back to the Founding Fathers' egalitarian goals, and quickly became so ingrained in the national mythos that what Tocqueville wrote in 1840 could stand as the motto for the J. Lo movie as well as its ancestors like "Sabrina" and "Working Girl": "At any moment a servant may become a master." The amalgam of American idealism and rags-to-riches dreams is irresistible.
But that persistent idea ignores the realities of today's economy and research about social mobility. The aristocratic politician Ralph Fiennes plays in "Maid in Manhattan" precisely fits the profile described by the Princeton economist Alan B. Krueger in a November article in The New York Times, which said that new studies show it takes an average of five or six generations to change a family's economic position, and that wealth tends to linger in families. Such inherited wealth helps create political dynasties like that of the Bushes and of the Fiennes character -- an assemblyman, a senator's son running for his father's seat, and not the kind of guy likely to take up with a maid. As Mr. Krueger added in an interview, "Recent trends in income distribution have made upward mobility less likely" than it was even 20 years ago. 
And such research isn't brand new. As Kevin Phillips says in "Wealth and Democracy: A Political History of the American Rich," published last year, the increasing gap between the median American family income and the richest 1 percent has been "a point of national discussion for over a decade." By the turn of the 21st century, he writes, the United States "had also become the West's citadel of inherited wealth."
"Aristocracy," he adds, "was a cultural and economic fact."
When films choose to examine class, though, the issue is still seen in terms that are backward-looking, simplistic or fantastic. "8 Mile," which treats the trailer-park life of the Eminem character with sobering realism, is a fierce anomaly. More typically films are as flat-footed about class as last year's preachy drama "John Q," in which Denzel Washington's beleaguered factory worker holds a hospital hostage until his son is given an expensive heart transplant. It turns out his gun was never loaded. Poor is good and noble; wealth makes people mean. And "John Q" was rare in treating class and money seriously.
In comedies, the rich are everywhere as caricatured villains, nasty and small-minded. In "Maid in Manhattan," Natasha Richardson plays a wealthy viper who chases the Fiennes character. And his heroism exists in his ability to ignore his own class and everyone else's. He's so down-to-earth, he walks his own dog, just like a poor person (this movie's sign of humanity) and is able to appreciate Marisa's "genuine" self even after she has replaced her borrowed Dolce & Gabbana suit with her maid's uniform. "What we do does not define who we are," says Bob Hoskins as the hotel's chief butler, in one of the movie's many hollow aphorisms.
A similar equation of money and meanness underlies the romantic comedy "Sweet Home Alabama," in which Melanie, the fashion designer played by Reese Witherspoon, rejects New York and her rich fiance for Alabama and the poor husband she left behind. At first she calls her soon-to-be-ex-husband a "dumb stubborn redneck" and he calls her "hoity-toity," but that's just their pallid echo of a Tracy-Hepburn battle before they swoon into each other's arms.
More telling, her fiance's vile, disapproving mother is the mayor of New York, a figure of unlikely glamour played by Candice Bergen. "What do you suggest I do, Mom? Dump her for being poor?" he asks, even though Melanie has become a Manhattan sophisticate and was never poverty-stricken to begin with. 
"There is nothing wrong with being poor," the mayor says. "I get elected by poor people." (There are particularly monstrous mothers in these films, but that's another issue.) 
As it happens, while Melanie was becoming a fashion star, the ex-husband was building a successful designer-glass business back home, but she doesn't know that when she decides she still loves him. Factoring in money would undercut her nobility.
And his economic rise is itself revealing. He becomes a success to prove himself to Melanie, and gives the film a faint stab at realism. (Would the audience have bought her return to a redneck life?) But he still dresses and acts like his poor, good-old-boy self -- a sign of integrity and character, this film's equivalent of Ralph Fiennes walking his dog.
While movie characters are busy zooming up and down the social ladder, some thoughtful television series are sending a more credible message: that upward mobility happens one rung at a time, and is fraught with problems and anxieties. The finest example is "The Sopranos," which has always been precise about its characters' social positions. Tony and Carmela have proudly sent their daughter, Meadow, to Columbia University, a huge yet plausible social step up. But unlike Ana in "Real Women," Meadow Soprano has nouveau-riche parents paying her way.
In a painfully realistic scene this season, Meadow's parents come to dinner at the apartment she shares with college friends. It is instantly evident how badly Tony and Carmela fit in, with their gold chains and parochial attitudes. One roommate is descended from Spanish royalty. "My daughter's an Italian princess; that count?" Tony asks. During a literary discussion Carmela argues angrily, "I'm sorry, but 'Billy Budd' is not a homosexual book!" and mistakenly thinks the critic Leslie Fiedler is a woman. Meadow's own social status is precariously balanced, between her upscale roommates and her gauche parents.
Sometimes even a fluffy sitcom like "George Lopez" can see upward mobility as a difficult maneuver, full of repercussions. Mr. Lopez plays a fictional George who is promoted from factory worker to manager. Suddenly he is his mother's and his best friend's boss, and struggles to read management manuals at night. Yet the Mexican-American working-class hero still finds himself one-upped by his well-off, better-educated Cuban father-in-law, as the show savvily hints that ethnicity and class are not simple categories. (It's a coincidence that Mr. Lopez also plays the teacher who changes Ana's fortunes in "Real Women"; or maybe that's a comment on the relatively small pool of Hispanic actors filmmakers choose from.)
Television is not better or more astute at tackling social issues; it's just that series, unlike movies, can't transform people's lives with a glass slipper week after week. And while there is a history of working-class television heroes, from "The Honeymooners" through "The King of Queens," addressing upward mobility with the clarity of "The Sopranos" is still rare.
On big or small screens, it may be the shadow stories that are most revealing about class. In "8 Mile" and "Maid in Manhattan," the stars never entirely disappear into their characters. Eminem deliberately echoes his real-life story, in which rapping becomes his escape from Detroit's factories and trailer parks. "Maid" is built around Ms. Lopez's glamorous presence. She came from a lower middle class family but her upward mobility has been especially spectacular. When her maid character puts on her borrowed jewels and clothes, she does not look like a dressed-up version of Marisa but like Jennifer Lopez, the woman with the flashing rings and designer clothes and trophy fiance, Ben Affleck. And although she does not sing on the movie's soundtrack, her recording "Jenny From the Block" bluntly expresses the film's message, conflating J. Lo and Marisa: "Don't be fooled by the rocks I got, I'm still, I'm still Jenny from the block." 
That emphasis on humble character obscures the film's deeper message. For Eminem and Jennifer Lopez, success as a music star catapulted them out of the modest past into the rich and famous present. When films persist in seeing social mobility as an issue of money, they are looking in the wrong direction. The real moral of these fairy tales is that Americans can vault out of one class into another; what does it is that great equalizer, show-business fame.

HEADLINE: L.I. @ WORK; 
The Goliath of Medical and Dental Supplies

BYLINE:  By WARREN STRUGATCH 

 BODY:
CLEAR evidence that dentistry is changing can be found in the "dancing banana" card in the current Henry Schein dental merchandise catalog. One of about 50 easygoing cards offered for sale to dentists to mail out to remind patients to come in for scheduled visits, the cartoon features four bananas performing a line dance and the message, "The bunch of us wants to see you soon!" 
 Because Americans get far fewer cavities than they did a generation ago, thanks largely to fluoridation, dentists have had to become more entrepreneurial to keep their practices humming. To keep pace, Henry Schein, the Melville company that is one of the largest distributors of health-care products and services in the world, has expanded, too. 
 Although Schein's offerings run to items like syringes, "bite into this" impression material and X-ray equipment, the company also offers office management software and marketing aids, including 50 different reminder cards, known as recall cards in the industry.
Selling supplies to doctors, dentists and veterinarians may not be a glamorous business, but for Henry Schein it has been a highly profitable one, particularly in recent years. The company has run up a string of increasingly profitable quarters since going public in 1995; last year, a dismal one for many companies, Schein's profits grew by about 18 percent.
Last year, Schein clearly outpaced not only most of the big Long Island companies but also benchmarks like the Nasdaq composite, the Dow Jones industrial average and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index. Sales this year are expected to approach $3 billion.
"We think that all of our businesses are running on all four cylinders," Stanley M. Bergman, the company's chairman, chief executive and president, told Wall Street analysts during a November conference call. "Everything is working well."
One big reason things are working so well is Mr. Bergman himself. He was the company's outside auditor before being recruited to run the business, and he has transformed Schein into what Catalog Age, a trade magazine, calls a "world dominator."
Schein began as a retail drugstore in Woodside, Queens, in 1932. It now has more than 6,500 employees around the world, including a telephone marketing squad of 600, and has expanded into medical and veterinary products, specializing in sales to individual practitioners rather than to hospitals.
Industry insiders give Mr. Bergman credit for his insistence on technological innovation, for developing a database of customer information and for hiring and developing a direct-sales team.
In addition to offering more than 80,000 individual items supplied by industry vendors, the company under Mr. Bergman has expanded into proprietary services like medical office design and has introduced a line of office-management software.
"Stan recognizes the way health care is changing and addresses his customers as small business owners and entrepreneurs rather than only as clinicians," said Suey Wong, who follows the company for Robert W. Baird & Company in Milwaukee. 
Because it has integrated its acquisitions into one operation, Schein is one of a very small number of health-care catalogs with complete purchase histories on each customer, Diane Cyr wrote in Catalog Age's November 1999 issue. "Each time a doctor or a dentist buys a new sterilizer, consults a financial analyst or has a chair repaired, Schein knows about it," she wrote.
The company's acquisition of the Sullivan Dental Company in Milwaukee in 1997 made it the dominant distributor in the $4-billion-a-year North American dental supplies industry, with about 40 percent of the market. 
"A lot of the smarter dentists now see themselves as small business owners and are going beyond what we call the 'drill and fill' business," Mr. Wong said. "They're offering cosmetic dentistry such as tooth whitening and want the latest equipment such as laser technology. Schein is very strong in all these areas."
Selling supplies to dentists remains the company's core business, although medical supplies are catching up. In 2001, the last year for which information is available, the company's sales to dental practices totaled $1.1 billion, or 43 percent of revenues; sales to doctors were $929.8 million, or 36 percent. International sales (16 percent), proprietary office management software (3 percent) and veterinary supplies (2 percent) accounted for the rest.
Mr. Bergman believes that supplying dentists is a good business to be in. "The number of Americans aged 45 to 65 is going to double over the next 20 years," he said. "These are prime years for needing dental work. And the number of Americans covered by dental policies is growing, too."
But the real growth potential is in medical sales, especially to offices and clinics, in Mr. Bergman's view. "The trend is for more and more procedures to be performed in the physician's office rather than in hospitals," he said. "And our population is aging, which also suggests there will be an increase in medical services."
Five years ago, medical products represented about 28 percent of the company's total sales; in 2001, that figure had risen to 38 percent. 
Mr. Bergman has also guided the company into expanded sales overseas, particularly in Europe. Totals in 2001 were $398 million or about 16 percent of Schein's revenues. In 1995, when Mr. Bergman took over, international sales totaled $108 million.
While some industry analysts expect that competition will catch up with Mr. Bergman eventually, for the moment he can look in his rearview mirror without undue concern.
"Stan is a professorial, laid-back kind of guy, but he might be the smartest businessman I know," Mr. Wong said. "In the end, you judge an executive by how the stock is doing. His is up fivefold over the past two and a half years, in what's been a brutal market. The record speaks for itself."

HEADLINE: Investing; 
Many May Not Feel Dividend Plan's Impact for Years

BYLINE:  By J. ALEX TARQUINIO 

 BODY:
MARK BROOK, 43, the owner of a home-building supply company in Oceanside, N.Y., is ecstatic about the possibility that most taxes on dividends will be eliminated.
 "There are taxes that are inherently stupid," he said. "The dividend tax is like the estate tax; it just doesn't make sense." Last year, Mr. Brook said, he earned about $40,000 in dividends on a portfolio of about $1 million. 
 On the other hand, Judith Berger, 59, a middle school teacher in the nearby Long Island community of Rockville Centre, said she does not expect to benefit from the proposal because she and her husband hold virtually all of their investments in tax-sheltered retirement accounts. "Like most of the middle class, we invest through our jobs," she said. "So it doesn't really change our investing strategy." 
While the main beneficiaries of elimination of taxes on dividends would be investors who hold stocks outside of retirement accounts, only about one-quarter of the adult population has such holdings, according to the Center for Economic and Policy Research in Washington. The wealthiest 1 percent of the population holds 53 percent of those stocks, the center said.
For wealthier investors, the dividend tax plan proposed by President Bush could have important implications. For people whose assets are mainly in retirement accounts, the issue is far less pressing, many financial advisers say. 
Many financial planners are counseling their clients against making major portfolio changes based on assumptions about a tax proposal when details -- and the chances of passage -- are far from certain. But some portfolio managers say it is not too early to start re-examining investment choices. 
Anna M. Dopkin, who manages the T. Rowe Price Growth and Income fund, said that with the tax proposal in mind, she is considering the purchase of stocks that could potentially increase their dividends, or begin paying them for the first time. These include Federated Department Stores of New York, and Altera, a semiconductor company based in San Jose, Calif.; both now pay no dividends. The fund does not currently own either stock.
Stocks that now pay high yields may not turn out to be good investments, she said. "In most cases, these are riskier stocks," she said. "The payout ratios may be too high and they might have to cut their dividend." 
Gary Schatsky, a New York City financial planner, said that while the tax plan might make dividend-paying stocks look more appealing as investments, they should not be directly compared with high-yielding assets like municipal bonds and real estate investment trusts, or REIT's.
"You have to compare apples to apples," he said. "You cannot compare municipal bonds with dividend-paying stocks." The bonds protect investor principal as long as they are held to maturity, he said, while equities, inherently riskier, can rise or fall.
Dividends on REIT's would not be tax-exempt under the Bush administration's proposal, but Mr. Schatsky said REIT's are often bought as an alternative to bonds. Because of their rich yields, often 7 percent to 8 percent, REIT's should be bought in retirement accounts, he said. 
Lee Rosenberg, a financial planner in Jericho, N.Y., that he is advising his clients to avoid making big changes because of the tax plan. He suggests that they adjust their portfolios by no more than 10 percentage points during the first quarter. For example, if investors have half their money in bonds, and believe that bonds might be hurt by the plan, they might want to go to 40 percent, Mr. Rosenberg said.
Long-term bond mutual funds, which had a big inflow of money in 2002, could be hit hard if the administration's proposal becomes law. While holders of individual bonds will recoup their principal if they hold the bonds to maturity, investors in bond funds could suffer an immediate capital loss because mutual funds are repriced daily.
Stock dividends earned by mutual funds would be tax-exempt under the proposal, but mutual fund shareholders might not gain much. Funds are required to pay out dividend income, but only after deducting operating expenses. The expenses of most funds effectively eliminate payments to investors; only 42 percent of domestic equity funds paid dividends in 2002, according to Morningstar Inc.
Patrick Dorsey, Morningstar's head of equity research, noted that some retirees might enjoy a windfall if taxes on their dividends were eliminated, but that younger shareholders who own stocks in taxable accounts could enjoy even bigger gains over the long run.
"It gives the folks in retirement a boost," Mr. Dorsey said. "If you're counting on this for income, and you're getting $4,000 in dividends, that's really $3,000 after taxes. There's a little difference, but it's not huge."
But an investor with 20 years before retirement would benefit from the power of compounding income. Say an investor owns a stock yielding 3 percent and reinvests the dividends. Assuming that the stock's price does not change, the cumulative total return after 20 years would be 80.6 percent without taxes, compared with 47.1 percent if the dividend income had been taxed annually at a rate of 35 percent. The difference would be even greater with a higher yield.
Of course, such advantages helped persuade millions of Americans to lock up their money in tax-sheltered retirement accounts in the first place. "There is going to be some tendency not to put so much into retirement accounts, if investors can get current income that's not taxed," said Robert E. Harrison, who runs the tax department of Richard A. Eisner & Company, a New York City accounting firm. 
Dean Baker, co-director of the Center for Economic and Policy Research, said that the tax plan could actually penalize investors in retirement accounts. While proponents of the plan have argued that it would cause a climb in stock prices, Mr. Baker said that it would likely be a one-time increase. And it would mean that future investors would have to pay more for shares. "If you buy a stock after the price has gone up, you are receiving a lower yield," Mr. Baker said. "And if you buy that stock in a retirement account, then you're not getting the benefit of the dividend tax cut." 
But even if taxes on dividends were eliminated, there would still be good reasons to make the maximum contribution to a 401(k) plan, Mr. Schatsky said. These include employer matching contributions and the ability to invest pretax dollars. 
Still, he acknowledged, the tax plan would make taxable accounts more important. The current advantages of such accounts include the ability to write off capital losses, which cannot be done in retirement accounts, he said. Nonetheless, several financial planners said that investors should not sell shares in retirement accounts simply to repurchase them in taxable accounts, incurring unnecessary brokerage fees. Rather, the advisers said, investors should shift their future purchases if the law changes.
Although the White House has said that the tax plan would spur investment, professional investors do not base their decisions on tax considerations alone. "I pick stocks that I think will do well on a total-return basis," Ms. Dopkin said. "Chasing high-yield stocks or dividend-paying stocks would be foolish. That's just one component of investing."

HEADLINE: Polish Pride, American Profits 

BYLINE:  By LESLIE WAYNE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
WHEN Aleksander Kwasniewski, the president of Poland, visits with President Bush at the White House on Tuesday, talk will inevitably turn to the F-16 fighter jet. Over the Christmas season, almost unnoticed, Poland announced it was accepting a $3.8 billion loan from Congress, the largest military loan in memory, to buy 48 of those Fighting Falcons.
 The scheduled lunch between the two leaders will cap a campaign by the Lockheed Martin Corporation that began six years ago and swung into high gear under Mr. Bush. The intense wooing to persuade the Poles to choose Lockheed over two European arms makers began last July, with a state dinner, one of only two since Mr. Bush took office, to honor Mr. Kwasniewski. It continued with a steady stream of visits by high administration officials to Warsaw, telephone calls from Mr. Bush to Mr. Kwasniewski and promises of a bigger role for Poland in strategic alliances with the United States and on the world stage. 
 Congress, eager to win the votes of Polish-Americans, kicked in with a loan package at rock-bottom terms. And Lockheed sealed the deal by corralling scores of other American companies to participate in an investment consortium that it says will pump billions into the Polish economy. 
"The U.S. pulled out all the stops to win the sale," said Peter C. Evans, a specialist in export financing at the M.I.T. "The idea was that if Poland goes with the U.S., the rest of the NATO expansion countries would, too. It's a pretty cushy deal and it just sailed through Congress."
The Poles are understandably pleased with the outcome of their bid to modernize their air force. In Warsaw last Thursday, at celebrations organized by Lockheed and the United States Embassy, Poland's prime minister, Leszek Miller, donned an air force uniform and was taken up for a spin in an F-16, and two other F-16's were put on display at the Warsaw airport. Once back on earth, Mr. Miller gushed that he would remember the ride "until the end of my life."
With national security, national pride and profits all part of the mix, the deal hardly lacks critics. In picking Lockheed's F-16, Poland rejected both the Mirage 2000-5 fighter jet made by Dassault Aviation of France and the Gripen, made by Saab of Sweden and BAE Systems of Britain, much to the consternation of European economic ministers, particularly in France, who have been complaining loudly ever since. 
Yet in the competition for a shrinking European military dollar, the packages offered by Lockheed's rivals were less attractive. In a quotation widely reprinted in the European press after the announcement on Dec. 27, Jean Wessener, a spokesman for the European Defence Industries Group, a Brussels-based group representing European arms makers, said: "The Americans are extremely good. They use any method they can to try to kill the European aircraft industry."
THE anger has not dissipated. For three days last week, Le Figaro, the Paris daily, published letters from readers accusing the Poles of being bad Europeans, especially after having just been invited to join the European Union next year.
On these shores, meanwhile, some critics say the loan is a perfect example of corporate welfare and of how the Iron Triangle of Congress, the Pentagon and military contractors work hand in glove to get what they want. Others question whether Poland can afford fancy military hardware when its economy is in its worst shape since the end of Communism there 13 years ago. 
It is also uncertain whether the extraordinary package of economic investments, called offsets, being put together by Lockheed, will live up to its billing. Worth at least $3 billion, the package includes deals to assemble F-16 engines in Poland, make investments in Polish steel mills and shipyards and create high-technology ventures in Poland by Lockheed and dozens of American companies it has lined up.
All foreign arms sales in recent years carry similar promises, intended to generate enough economic activity so that the purchasing country can pay for the gear. But opponents of the Lockheed offsets contend that they could well result in a transfer of American jobs to lower-wage Poland and a seepage of important technologies.
Such concerns, however, have been lost amid the trans-Atlantic self-congratulations. For Poland, the F-16 deal speaks to national pride, to defending the borders of a country ravaged by war and to getting the kind of first-class military equipment that will secure its position in the modern world and cement its ties to the West. As a condition for entering NATO in 1999, Poland promised to upgrade its military and decided to replace its Soviet MIG-21's.
"This is important because it is a sign of Poland coming out of another age," said Przemyslaw Grudzinski, Poland's ambassador to the United States. "It is only logical to change our major weapons systems to Western-made weapons systems. We want to be a mature member of NATO."
Mr. Grudzinski is keenly aware that the United States needs friends in Europe with a war looming against Iraq. "In these international circumstances," he added, "Poland emerges as an excellent ally of the United States." Addressing skeptics of the offsets, he called the package crucial to the deal but acknowledged that there was a lot of work yet to do to shape them.
For the Bush administration, the F-16 deal deepens a relationship with a staunch ally at a time when many countries are becoming more hostile to the United States. As some countries cool to the United States military on their soil, Poland could provide a new option.
For Lockheed, it is a chance to save jobs at a Texas plant that has been churning out F-16's, each with a $40 million price tag, for more than 20 years. Now that the United States Air Force has plenty of them, the only area for sales growth for this cash cow is overseas.
Lockheed and industry analysts also say the Poland deal was crucial to cracking a Fortress Europe mentality -- and could open doors as Lockheed begins to market the next-generation fighter jet, the Joint Strike Fighter, to NATO countries.
"The Poland deal was a real plum," said Philip Finnegan, the director of corporate analysis at the Teal Group, a military industry consulting firm based in Fairfax, Va. "It keeps an American fighter line running. Poland was a key country in Central Europe and a key potential ally. For European arms manufacturers, it's a real setback."
FOR those reasons, the deal breezed through Congress without a word of opposition -- even though direct loans for military sales were halted in the mid-1990's after many countries failed to repay them. Most foreign countries, like the United Arab Emirates, South Korea and Taiwan, now pay cash for American military equipment. Israel and Egypt do, too, but use direct foreign aid from the United States. At $3.8 billion, the Poland loan is larger than the last decade's worth of direct military loans to all countries combined.
And it is so sweet that Pentagon officials say they do not expect to ask Congress for another like it. The money will come from the Treasury, not the Pentagon budget. It covers 100 percent of the cost of the jets, not the 85 percent more typical of commercial loans. The interest rate will be at a below-market 5.92 percent fixed rate, calculated from the 10-year Treasury note, even though the loan is for 15 years.
No principal payments need be paid for the first eight years, and Lockheed does not have to post a performance bond, which helps the company's balance sheet. Other fees usually associated with government loan programs were also waived.
"The United States is eager to continue its domination of the U.S. arms market," said Rachel Stohl, a senior analyst with the Center for Defense Information, a military research group in Washington. "So you see these huge incentive packages to make the arms sales more attractive. These packages allow countries that cannot afford U.S. weapons to buy them at reduced costs and have the taxpayer pay up for it."
IN other words, they smack of corporate welfare. "We don't want our companies to lose out to other countries," said Ivan Eland, a military analyst at the Cato Institute, a free-market policy group in Washington. "But why should the taxpayer subsidize it? That may help individual companies in the U.S., but it does not help the taxpayer. It is corporate welfare. It's an indirect transfer from the taxpayer to Lockheed Martin."
The man driving the deal at the Pentagon -- Lt. Gen. Tome H. Walters Jr. of the Air Force, director of the United States Defense Security Cooperation Agency -- could not disagree more. In an interview last Tuesday, just before leaving for the Warsaw ceremonies, he bristled at the corporate-welfare charge. 
To General Walters, the issue is national security -- providing American planes, training, logistical support, doctrine and interoperability with an important ally, and one with a rich air force tradition, besides. During World War II, the Polish Army decamped to England and, from there, carried out crucial bombing raids in Europe. 
"My responsibility is not to flack for a commercial entity, but it is to pursue national security interests," General Walters said. "We are working with countries that are our friends to build influence in peacetime so we will have access to the region when we need it in time of crisis.
"Lockheed is a successful company," he added. "It does not need my help. Its responsibility is to its shareholders. My job is not to work for Lockheed shareholders, but for the secretary of defense and the president."
General Walters's strongest pitch appealed to Polish aspirations -- that by buying the F-16, it was sidling up to the United States, not the few countries with European fighter jets.
"I told the Poles they had the potential to be front-line leaders in NATO," General Walters said. "They could join with the U.S. Air Force and 23 other countries and 8 NATO countries that fly the F-16. Or, they could have the Gripen and have interoperability with Sweden and South Africa."
If that pitch was hard to resist, so was the rich offset package. "Poland needs to offset the cost of the deal by introducing into the Polish economy many of these new investments," said Mr. Grudzinski, the Polish ambassador. "We hope the offset deal would have considerable impact in bringing renewed investment by U.S. corporations and midsized enterprises and bring Poland a wave of new technology."
Although the World Trade Organization frowns on these arrangements, on the grounds that they distort trade, they are not forbidden for military contracts. In fact, Lockheed already has offset programs totaling $30 billion in 27 counties and went into Poland like Santa Claus. Though reluctant to talk about the arrangements, the company has posted them only in Polish on its Warsaw Web site, www.f-16.pl -- making no mention of them in its news releases here.
The offsets from Lockheed and its industrial partners, which Lockheed pays, include subcontracts for Poles to make commercial jet trainers as well as parts for business aircraft like the Gulfstream and Piper for export to the United States and to make the Pratt & Whitney engine for the F-16 engine. There is also a venture with Accenture for a new technology company in Lodz, and a partnership with the University of Texas to start a technology accelerator at the University of Lodz. 
Others include setting up a $70 million technology venture capital fund in coordination with the Sandia National Laboratories in New Mexico, which Lockheed operates for the Department of Energy; environmental and water treatment projects with the Polish unit of CH2M Hill Inc., and an agreement with Northrop Grumman for more subcontracting in Poland as well as for projects to provide Poland with more telecommunications technology. 
Many of these proposals are still in the negotiating stages.
Critics say the companies and countries involved in offsets make a Faustian bargain. The selling country may lose jobs and face more low-cost imports -- which has prompted organized labor to oppose them.
Many say these offsets push countries that are short on cash, like Poland, into buying armaments that their economies may not be able to afford or accepting goods and services they do not need.
"The F-16s in Poland have a lot of symbolic value," said William D. Hartung, a senior fellow at the World Policy Institute at the New School University in New York. "And the Poles want to get this technology. But absent the offset financing, this would have been a hard sell. The Poles are spending significantly on the military when they have so many domestic needs."
Ann Roell Markusen, a public policy professor at the University of Minnesota who has written extensively on offsets, said the country receiving the benefits could suffer if the goods and services it received were determined by an arms deal and not real economic needs. 
"When products come into a country and it is tied to an arms transfer, that is not normal economics," she said. "It is tied to a corporation wanting to make a huge amount of money, not because that service or that technology has merit."
For the Poles, eager to to stand shoulder to shoulder with the United States and to emerge from the shadows of war and occupation, the Congressional financing package and the offsets created a unique opportunity.
"Poland can now be a partner in arms in a way that was not possible until now," Mr. Grudzinski said. "We see the world as a dangerous place and, unfortunately, that creates lots of opportunity."

HEADLINE: Airline's New Diet Has RivalsWatching 

BYLINE:  By EDWARD WONG 

DATELINE: TEMPE, Ariz. 

 BODY:
WHO knew that beef jerky and chicken Kiev could rival tea leaves and tarot cards as portents of the future?
 But ever since America West started an experiment last Monday to sell food aboard flights, other airlines have been trying to divine the industry's fate in how the meals are received. 
 The willingness of America West's passengers to pay $3 to lick ice cream at 30,000 feet is being looked upon as a significant test of whether ailing airlines can charge passengers for things that were once included in the price of a ticket.
Desperate for revenue, big airlines with nationwide hub-and-spoke systems -- the so-called network carriers -- have tried levying, with varying success, surcharges for fuel, paper tickets, standby flights and extra or oversized baggage in the last few months. America West's proposal is one of the most audacious, if only because airline food is the punch line of so many jokes about bad cuisine. 
"I think it's an interesting experiment, and we're certainly watching it to see how it fares," said Jeffrey A. Smisek, executive vice president for corporate affairs at Continental Airlines. But Continental, he added, had no plan to start charging for meals on its flights.
It does not surprise people in the industry that America West is willing to try new ways to generate more revenue. In the span of a year, the airline, the country's eighth largest, has become a pace setter, provocateur and guinea pig for an industry in transition. It was the first network carrier to simplify its fare structure and ease restrictions on cheap tickets, and it beat its rivals applying for -- and getting -- a federal loan guarantee.
Whether travelers will ultimately accept this latest experiment remains to be seen -- about one-quarter of passengers on test flights bought box meals last Monday and Tuesday.
But industry experts credit America West for being willing to be creative, even at the risk of irritating passengers who used to get food free. Its goal, which is shared by other network carriers, is to match the success of Southwest, JetBlue Airways and other low-cost carriers. All of America West's recent efforts have been directed at turning the airline into what W. Douglas Parker, its chief executive, calls the country's "second-largest low-fare carrier."
What has emerged so far is a sleeker if occasionally ungainly hybrid.
America West's costs are lower than those of its network rivals, but not as low as Southwest's. It is sticking with its hub-and-spoke model, rather than adopting Southwest's approach of flying directly from city to city; as a result, it cannot use its planes as efficiently. It will for now keep using a mix of plane types, resulting in higher labor and maintenance costs than airlines that use only one type of plane.
It has also failed to achieve anything close to the name recognition of JetBlue, which through aggressive marketing has made itself synonymous with cheap fares and friendly service. Yet Wall Street analysts estimate that America West lost $139 million, or $4.21 a share, in 2002 on an estimated $2.04 billion in sales; they forecast that the loss will narrow to $51 million, or $1.50 a share, this year.
Still, America West's intense efforts to woo passengers have given its competitors something else to chew over amid one of their worst slumps ever. And now come the $5 cinnamon buns and $10 chickens Kiev.
In many ways, America West is the perfect lab rat for all these experiments. With 884 daily flights, most of which connect to two big hubs in Phoenix and Las Vegas and a tiny one in Columbus, Ohio, it is small enough to make quick, sweeping changes. Its biggest rival in the two large hubs is Southwest, so it has the chance to test its initiatives against the industry's standard for success.
At the same time, America West, which was founded in 1981, has little to lose in terms of reputation. It has already been in bankruptcy once, from 1991 to 1994, and it alienated many of its customers when a spate of mechanical problems in 2000 forced it to cancel 6 percent of its flights.
"At least they've been trying some creative things that haven't been seen in the industry, and you have to give them credit for that," said Jim Corridore, an analyst at Standard & Poor's. "They're making some great strides in cutting their cost structure, but they're still losing a lot of money.
"If America West wants to follow the Southwest model," he added, "they have to go full bore with it. They're not going to get much closer to the Southwest model unless they abandon some of the costly hubs and abandon some of their markets. They need to become a smaller airline."
The reinvention of America West began with the overhaul of its fare structure last March, a result of a project led by J. Scott Kirby, 35, executive vice president for sales and marketing.
Mr. Kirby, a graduate of the Air Force Academy who once worked as an economist for the Pentagon, was promoted to his current position a day before terrorists hijacked four airliners and crashed them in New York, Washington and rural Pennsylvania. The collapse in air traffic after the attacks forced him to scramble just to keep America West in business, but he was able to turn to the airline's long-term reorganization within a few months.
In fall 2001, America West got some financial breathing room. By mid-November, it had become the first airline to apply for a federal loan guarantee under a $10 billion aid program set up by Congress after the terror attacks. Mr. Parker was told in late December 2001 that the Air Transportation Stabilization Board, which administers the program, would give the airline a $380 million loan guarantee on a $429 million loan if it would promise to keep labor costs under control -- and give the government the option to buy up to 33 percent of its stock in the future.
America West's application, and the government's demands on it, prefigured similar requests from US Airways and United Airlines, as well as a host of smaller carriers. US Airways got conditional approval for a $900 million loan guarantee. United's application for a $1.8 billion guarantee was rejected early last month, forcing the airline to file for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection.
Working feverishly, Mr. Kirby's team eventually came up with numbers that led to what he called "the most heavily analyzed decision we ever made" -- dumping the old fare structure for a simplified model. All requirements for Saturday-night stays were dropped, and unrestricted walk-up fares -- the kind popular with business travelers -- were cut by around 70 percent. One-way fares now cost no more than $400.
THOUGH Southwest and other low-cost airlines had long operated with this kind of system, this was the first time that a network carrier had tried to copy it. Business travelers embraced the move. America West's rivals gave it the evil eye.
"Clearly we've done some things that have upset other airlines," Mr. Parker said as jets swooped over palm trees outside the tinted windows of the company's boardroom here. "I think upsetting your competition is not a bad thing. We're trying to serve our employees and shareholders. If I were at the other airlines, I would not necessarily do what America West has done, and I might be upset at America West for doing it."
Competitors have not blindly copied America West, but they are watching it closely and reacting swiftly. The day America West put its new fare structure in place, Continental, Delta Air Lines and Northwest Airlines drastically cut fares on routes where America West was the main nonstop carrier. Continental also dropped a code-share alliance that it had had with America West since 1994.
Mr. Parker has said that his rivals' actions are anticompetitive, but his rivals dispute that accusation.
This winter, several other airlines have moved in the same direction, starting their own experiments with simpler fares.
Last Monday, United made deep cuts in unrestricted fares on direct flights from its hubs in Chicago and Denver and on thousands of flights in smaller markets. American Airlines, and Continental immediately matched those cuts. Jamie Baker, an analyst at J. P. Morgan Chase, said those routes represented 32 percent of total domestic sales.
Delta and American Airlines have similar, though more limited, experiments in other markets. On Nov. 14, for example, American reduced unrestricted fares and simplified its fare structure on 23 "city pairs," or routes, then expanded that to more than 400 last month. Sonja Whitemon, a spokeswoman for American, said the company had based its move on its own needs rather than on what America West had done.
MR. KIRBY, the marketing executive, said America West's fare overhaul was bringing in more passengers who travel on short notice. The airline's revenue per available seat mile generated by full fares was up 1 percent in the second quarter and 14 percent in the third quarter over the comparable periods last year, he said.
But he added that what had worked for America West might not work for other network carriers because only 5 percent of America West's revenue had come from full fares before its structure change. That contrasts with 10 percent for the industry over all, according to the Air Transport Association, the industry's main trade group. This means most other airlines risk losing more revenue if they try to lower their full fares systemwide.
"With the system they operate, on low-yielding routes, it's a perfect formula for them," Raymond L. Neidl, an analyst at Blaylock & Partners, an investment bank in New York, said of America West. "With their size and their market, it's something that's worked for them."
America West started its experiment of charging for food on a dozen daily short flights from Phoenix. Flight attendants began selling snack boxes with items like hot sandwiches, chips and cookies for $3 to $5. This week, the experiment will expand to a dozen medium-length flights. In the third and final week, America West will ask long-distance passengers to pay $10 for meals like chicken Kiev served on china.
Mr. Parker said one gauge of success will be whether the airline can cover the cost of providing meals, which runs $250 to $300 a flight. Jeffrey D. McClelland, executive vice president for operations, said that two days into the experiment, 20 to 30 percent of passengers on the test flights were buying the food. "We expect it'll go up a little bit as we go to long-haul markets," he said.
Though European low-cost carriers like Ryanair already sell food aboard flights, analysts are skeptical that America West will recoup its costs. They say Southwest's success has shown that passengers want nothing more than to get from one place to another as cheaply as possible. Besides, they say, why would passengers buy an airline meal when they can get food from a real restaurant in the airport?
"At least somebody at America West is thinking outside of the box," said Joe Brancatelli, an advocate for business travelers who writes an online newsletter. "But the airlines should do what they do best. They fly people. Stop trying to be the department store. Don't sell me food; don't sell me entertainment."
American Airlines has determined that selling food on flights would be too complicated and expensive, and it is in early talks with concessionaires to sell food at gates, said Todd Burke, a spokesman for American. Northwest, though, is planning to sell food aboard some flights in a month-long trial starting on Wednesday.
SELLING sandwiches may be symbolically significant, but it is only one of the issues facing America West. A larger challenge is to whittle its cost structure so that it can continue to offer cheap fares and compete effectively with Southwest in Phoenix and Las Vegas. In the first half of 2002, it spent 8.61 cents flying one seat one mile, according to Back Aviation Solutions, an airline consulting company. That was less than any network carrier, but still almost 17 percent higher than the 7.37 cents spent by Southwest.
Industry analysts point to several obstacles that prevent America West from slimming its operations. Because it operates using hubs, for example, its planes spend more time on the ground to allow passengers to connect -- 50 to 55 minutes, according to Mr. McClelland. Southwest's planes have a turnaround time of 20 to 30 minutes.
America West flies its planes an average of 9.3 hours a day, versus 10.9 hours at Southwest, according to Back Aviation. Airlines, of course, cannot collect revenue when their planes are idle.
With three types of planes in its fleet, America West also spends more on labor and maintenance than do low-cost airlines that use only one type of plane. Mr. McClelland said the company had been working to switch its fleet entirely to Airbus A319's and A320's, but that fell through after the Sept. 11 attacks.
America West has also had a tougher time dealing with its unions than has Southwest, and its mechanics' and flight dispatchers' contracts are up for renegotiation this year. It reached a tentative agreement last month with one union, the Air Line Pilots Association, but only after rancorous talks that required federal mediation.
Finally -- and this may matter more to travelers than to anything else -- it ranked eighth in on-time performance in November, according to the Transportation Department. That gets to the heart of what passengers want from their air travel experience. Given the choice, would they rather pick an airline that sells a $5 cheese omelet sandwich, or one that has a better track record flying them to their destinations by the promised hour?
As Mr. Brancatelli observed, "I don't know anyone who makes the decision on flying based on the food they get."
