HEADLINE: NEWS SUMMARY 

 BODY:
 INTERNATIONAL A2-8

Deaths as Election Nears: 9 Palestinians, 2 Israelis
Nine Palestinians and two Israelis were killed in fighting across Israel and the occupied territories, as diplomatic efforts to stop the violence stalled. In one of the bloodiest incidents, two Palestinians and one Israeli soldier were killed in a gunfight after the Israelis spotted a group of militants who they said were crossing into Israel from Egypt. A1

Prime Minister Ariel Sharon of Israel dismissed Yasir Arafat's appeal for a pre-election halt to attacks on Israeli civilians. Palestinian officials prefer Mr. Sharon's opponent, Amram Mitzna, who has said he would dismantle settlements in the West Bank and Gaza Strip and reopen negotiations with the Palestinians. A6

Iraqi Kurds Battle Militants
Iraqi Kurds are bogged down in a war against Muslim militants while they await a decision on whether the United States will attack Saddam Hussein. The fight has strong parallels and ties to the war in Afghanistan, though on a smaller scale. A1

Talks With South Korea
Assistant Secretary of State James Kelly began consultations with officials in Seoul, South Korea, as the North maintained its combative statements. Mr. Kelly met with North Korean officials in October and later said they had admitted conducting a secret nuclear weapons program, which North Korea denies. A10

Modernizing a Chinese City
In Chongqing, China, construction crews are burrowing through mountains to create 600 miles of superhighways, four new railway lines, an urban light rail system and a new airport. Engineers are also promising parks, drinkable tap water and riverside promenades for the city's 30 million residents. A1

Japan Appeals for Russian Oil
Junichiro Koizumi made the first visit of a Japanese prime minister to Russia's Far East in almost a century because of a struggle with China over Russian oil. Mr. Koizumi openly appealed for the construction of a 2,500-mile oil pipeline that would bypass China, bringing Siberian oil to the Sea of Japan. A3

HEADLINE: Disney Breaks Ground for Hong Kong Park 

BYLINE:  By THOMAS CRAMPTON, International Herald Tribune

DATELINE: HONG KONG, Jan. 12 

 BODY:
Executives from the Walt Disney Company broke ground here today for what they described as the company's most culturally sensitive theme park.
 Shortly before using a golden shovel to turn over a spade of dirt in a recently completed landfill, the chief executive of Walt Disney, Michael D. Eisner, said the park would be a "spectacular entry into southern China." 
 "This park will become profitable sooner than our projections," Mr. Eisner said without elaborating. 
The project, on the outlying Lantau Island, will be Disney's first new park outside the United States since Disneyland Paris, originally called Euro Disneyland, faced initial low attendance and criticism. European visitors complained that open-air rides were more appropriate for Southern California, and public outcries forced the park to reverse its policy against serving alcohol. The company's other overseas theme park is in Tokyo.
"Paris taught us that we always have to listen to our consumers to be sure the park fits within their cultures and desires," the president of Walt Disney Parks and Resorts, James A. Rasulo, said.
"We do find that children like to be greeted in their own language," Mr. Rasulo said. "Our park will be trilingual, with English, Cantonese and Mandarin." 
The park will also be tailored to Hong Kong's drizzly subtropical climate, executives said.
"We learned a lot about weatherization issues in Paris," said Tom Morris, vice president for creative development at Hong Kong Disneyland. "In Paris we needed to do more about making it warm and dry. In Hong Kong we will need to provide shade and protect people from the rain."
The Hong Kong park will have more covered attractions and rainproof dining space than other Disney theme parks, Mr. Morris said. The centerpiece will be Sleeping Beauty's castle and other Disney icons. Changes for cultural reasons will include food, festivals and park layout.
The park will have one restaurant serving Western food, with other outlets offering noodles, Asian barbecue and stir-fried dishes. Festivals celebrated will include Chinese New Year and the autumn lantern festival. Although visitors will enter the park on Main Street USA, one of the two hotels will be designed in Victorian style with Chinese elements.
There will also be a large garden designed for photo opportunities with Disney characters, as well as areas for relaxation.
Disney may be the first big-name competitor to break ground in China, but theme parks are by no means a new concept. Shenzhen, adjacent to Hong Kong, has more than half a dozen homegrown theme parks of varying quality.
In addition, a Disney rival, Universal Park Resorts, a unit of Vivendi Universal of France, signed a deal last month for a movie theme park in Shanghai that will open around the same time as Hong Kong Disneyland.
The deal for the Hong Kong theme park was originally negotiated in the wake of the Asian financial crisis in 1997. The Hong Kong government, eager for an economic and moral lift, took a 57 percent stake in the Disney park in the hopes that the project would attract tourists and provide jobs. Disney invested 2.45 billion Hong Kong dollars, or $314 million, for a 43 percent stake.
Last July, Hong Kong officials learned that Disney was in discussions for a similar project in Shanghai. Mr. Eisner played down discussions about other parks in China.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Members of the Walt Disney staff set up a welcoming line yesterday at groundbreaking ceremonies at the future site of Hong Kong Disneyland. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: Basra Journal; 
For This Delicacy, Brand Recognition Is a Problem

BYLINE:  By NEIL MacFARQUHAR 

DATELINE: BASRA, Iraq 

 BODY:
The hundreds of packages of dates stacked on the cement factory floor and metal shelves of the venerable Al-Moosawi Company are remarkable for one curious absence. 
 The label does not mention they are Iraqi. The brand itself, "Dubai Dates," is misleading enough, but the name "United Arab Emirates" runs up one side of the package decorated with a drawing of a date bouquet. 
 Anyone handling the packages -- and their predominantly Russian labels signal their ultimate destination -- would have no idea they were grown around this southern port city. 
That is the whole point, of course. Iraqis resort to subterfuge to avoid United Nations sanctions preventing exports of a product once viewed by the cognoscenti as more desirable than even the country's crude oil.
"Nobody wants to hear about anything called Iraqi dates, or for that matter about anything made in Iraq," lamented Fathi Atallah Raja, the Baghdad spokesman for the Iraqi Date Processing & Marketing Company, a semiprivate collective that handles all sales.
To a certain extent, the story of Iraq's dates mirrors the Iraqi experience since Saddam Hussein assumed control. What was once a thriving industry finds itself inexorably fading after 23 years filled with war, economic sanctions and a negligence driven by the pursuit of industrial development and other, more lethal projects. 
Iraqis crow that the reputation of their dates was once such that Americans set sail with a whole shipload of date palm saplings to plant in California in the 1930's. Exports of the dates spanned the globe. 
War wrought the first devastation. Millions of trees in what Iraq boasts was once the largest date forest in the world, on the Fao peninsula, just south of here, were either burned or felled by shrapnel during the raging battles of the 1980-88 war with Iran. 
What were once majestic stands of palms are gone, replaced by a stunted, nightmarish landscape of decapitated trunks and blackened stumps. The former population of 16 million date palms around Basra is now estimated at 3 million.
The Persian Gulf war also took its toll, with a mysterious outbreak of disease afterward that some trace to depleted uranium shells. 
Iraqi scientists identified the disease as a fungus, fusarium, that attacks the crown of the tree, causing it to topple and leaving the flaccid trunk weirdly twisted. It is known around here as Mad Palm Disease. 
"The heart of the palm turns from white to black and it creates a bad smell," said Abbas Mahdi Jassim, director of the Center for the Study of Date Palms at the University of Basra. "We link it with the war because we didn't know this disease before."
The only way found to prevent the spread has been to fell the trees and burn them. Mr. Jassim, who earned a doctorate in horticulture from Kansas State University in 1988, is trying to regenerate tens of thousands of trees through tissue culture in test tubes. On several occasions, the chemically intensive process has attracted the attention of United Nations weapons inspectors trying to determine whether the medium in which the tiny sprouts grow might have a more sinister use. 
Dates have long been a staple around the region's deserts -- they are rich in minerals and vitamins and last for months without refrigeration. The Koran includes no fewer than 18 mostly laudatory references to dates.
Sitting around the lunch table with a group of Iraqis talking about dates is vaguely reminiscent of, say, the French discussing cheese. The official date encyclopedia lists 627 varieties in Iraq, and everyone champions a favorite.
Great nostalgia for the finest Iraqi dates lingers throughout the Arab world. A Saudi household wishing to show a guest particular honor will bring out a basket of the exquisite Barhi variety, now cultivated there. Egyptians of a certain age, when hearing that a traveler is going to Iraq, will urge, "Bring back dates."
Growers in the Emirates and Saudi Arabia have bred millions of Iraqi date palms, becoming the main suppliers of the finer varieties that have all but disappeared in Iraq. Growers here sniff that others can never replicate the combination of conditions that give Iraqi dates their luscious, chewy quality.
"Sure other countries can grow the trees, but the dates of Basra have a special taste," boasted Sayid Abdel Rida al-Moosawi, the patriarch of the clan that founded Basra's first date processing factory in 1959. 
Mr. Moosawi rails against what he calls American piracy in the gulf, stopping Iraqi products like dates -- exports are now less than one-fifth what they were before the Iran-Iraq war. 
He demurs on the subject of the bogus labels, however. "I seem to remember they are marked as made in Iraq," he said during an interview in the sprawling, turquoise-domed mosque that his family built in downtown Basra. "Besides, the Americans watch any ships moving from Iraq's territorial waters and they can confiscate the cargo whatever the trademark."
But Mr. Raja of the collective says Iraqis gamble on a variety of methods to evade the blockade, including phony labeling or shipping the dates on Iranian-flagged ships. (Similar methods have been used with oil.) 
The United Nations bans all exports from Iraq except under the oil-for-food program. 
A Western envoy in Baghdad acknowledged that the United Nations did not pay terribly close attention to contraband dates. It interdicts much of what leaves Iraq by sea, but the land borders are fairly porous, especially for products that are not exactly going to supply the secret wealth Iraq would need to develop weapons of mass destruction. 
As with other fields where they excelled, Iraqis dream that after the sanctions are lifted and peace returns, they will reassert their domination of the market in fine dates. 
"One day we will regain the same reputation, the same position," predicted Mr. Moosawi. "It will probably take 25 years to get back where it was."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Fighting during Iraq's war with Iran in the 1980's wiped out millions of date palms, including these near the Shatt al Arab waterway, south of Basra. (James Hill for The New York Times) Map of Iraq highlighting Basra: War and disease have ravaged Basra's date industry.

HEADLINE: Mrs. Clinton Put Past Behind in Trip Across Aisle 

BYLINE:  By CARL HULSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 

 BODY:
He tried to impeach her husband and hated her health care plan. She was not thrilled when he complained about post-Sept. 11 aid to New York.
 Yet, in a case study of how legislative objectives can trump ideology, Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton, Democrat of New York, and Don Nickles, Republican of Oklahoma, teamed up last week to help deliver added unemployment benefits to millions of Americans. 
 It took concessions from both, since Mr. Nickles and his Republican colleagues had for months opposed a costly expansion of the federal jobless program while Mrs. Clinton and other Democrats had pressed for an even bigger package. And at the end there was some partisan skirmishing that nearly killed the measure and left Mr. Nickles and his new Senate leader, Bill Frist of Tennessee, unhappy on Dr. Frist's first day on the job. 
"That little wrinkle at the end caused a lot of anxiety," Mr. Nickles said.
That problem aside, Mrs. Clinton said she found it rewarding to work with Mr. Nickles, whom she considers an expert in Senate matters and a straight shooter.
"I happen to like him," Mrs. Clinton said, adding a rueful acknowledgment of her reputation in some parts of the country. "I am reluctant to say that because I am sure that will hurt him in Oklahoma."
Allies of the former first lady say the unemployment negotiations should put to rest a central concern expressed when she ran for the Senate -- that she was such a polarizing figure from her years in the White House that she would be unable to work with opposition senators who had led the effort to remove President Bill Clinton from office.
"During the campaign, one of the most frequently asked questions of her was how and whether she would be able to productively exist in a body that had so recently voted to impeach her husband and how she would be able to get along with people like Don Nickles," said Howard Wolfson, who was her campaign communications director. "She was absolutely able to work with Republicans as well as Democrats to get this done."
Mr. Nickles said the sometimes difficult road traveled by the $7.2 billion unemployment bill signed into law by President Bush on Wednesday only hours after it passed the House provided some lessons for how the parties can cooperate.
"I can work with Hillary and I can work with Ted Kennedy," Mr. Nickles said. "You can philosophically be in different directions, but it is still important to come together to get our Congressional business completed." 
Mrs. Clinton said she did not dwell on her previous clashes with Congress; what mattered to her now, she said, was building Senate relationships that could help her legislatively.
"Somebody you disagree with today you may agree with tomorrow but disagree the next day," she said, adding that some colleagues have turned out differently from what she expected. "I have been pleasantly surprised by many of the people whom I didn't know or only knew by some unfortunate or unflattering experience in the past."
The unemployment program had been a bone of contention for months between Congressional Republicans and Democrats in the run-up to the November election. Democrats, trying to shift the political dialogue from security to economic issues, repeatedly pushed for consideration of greater aid to people who were using up their 26 weeks of state aid. Each time, Mr. Nickles objected, citing the $17 billion cost.
During the post-election lame-duck session, the door to compromise opened. On Nov. 14, Mrs. Clinton again raised the unemployment expansion on the floor and Mr. Nickles again objected, leading to a brief but sharp debate in which the Democratic lawmaker expressed an interest in trying to work out a deal with the Republican. She then caught up with him in a hallway and offered to scale back the package significantly to try to preserve benefits for 800,000 people who might lose them as of Dec. 28. Their staffs began talking.
Five hours of negotiations that day that also involved the Republicans Peter Fitzgerald of Illinois and Arlen Specter of Pennsylvania and the Democrat Maria Cantwell of Washington produced an extension of federal unemployment coverage, allowing people an additional 13 weeks. The bill passed at 10:20 p.m. But the celebration was short-lived. House Republicans had their own, more limited extension, and they refused the Senate plan. The extension died as the 107th Congress adjourned.
Republicans came under pressure to act quickly when the new Congress convened and Mr. Bush, who had not intervened in November, urged lawmakers in mid-December to act immediately when they returned. Last Monday, Mr. Nickles put in a call to Mrs. Clinton, asking to renew their partnership. He offered to support a longer extension of the program, through May, and a deal was put together for the first order of business on Tuesday.
But events did not go exactly as planned. When Dr. Frist, taking the floor for the first time, sought to pass the bill by unanimous consent -- meaning no one was expected to object -- Mrs. Clinton rose to offer an amendment to extend coverage to another one million people who had used up their benefits.
Aides say her intent was simply to raise the issue and lay the foundation for a future push for more coverage. But it touched off a flurry of calls by her fellow Democrats for additional coverage and prompted an unexpected objection that stalled adoption of the bill for a couple of hours. Dr. Frist was plainly annoyed and caught by surprise at the sudden partisanship. 
"The response to her amendment got out of hand, to her surprise and mine as well," said Mr. Nickles, who said some Democrats were apparently itching to give Dr. Frist "a hard time."
Mrs. Clinton acknowledged a "bit of a flare-up" that she attributed to miscommunication among lawmakers. "There was just a lot going on," she said. "The final result was we got the legislation through."

HEADLINE: Judging the Tax Plan: Four Families Shrug 

BYLINE:  By PETER T. KILBORN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 

 BODY:
How has a new round of proposed federal tax cuts stirred the emotions and economic aspirations of American families? The answer from four of them seems to be: not very much.
 A carpenter, a clerk, a surgeon and a software engineer were interviewed with their families by The New York Times two years ago, just before the last tax cuts took effect. Reached again this week, after President Bush proposed new tax cuts as part of a $674 billion, 10-year economic plan, they said they were working harder and longer than ever in today's bleaker economy. The 2001 cuts, which included a $300 refund check, have made little difference in their lives, these taxpayers said, and they do not expect any new cuts the president and Congress agree on to matter much either. 
 The families expect to get back $100 here, $1,000 there, they say, but not big money. 
Most of these families own little taxable stock, so they said the biggest cut President Bush proposed last week, ending the tax on stock dividends, rang hollow. Tax cuts or no tax cuts, no one is talking of splurging. 
For the moment, debates about federal income taxes that thunder in Washington stir much less interest among these families than influences beyond taxes do. Federal taxes have changed little compared with shifts in jobs, wages, debt, medical expenses and utility bills. And with most states running up their biggest budget deficits in decades, families face state income and sales tax increases that could exceed anything they get back from Washington.
In the face of those changes, some families are not merely cutting back on trips and meals out. They are making hard, life-reorienting choices, such as buying cheaper houses.

The Clines of Austin
"We've scaled way, way down," said Tasha Cline, 37, of Austin, Tex. By any numerical measure, she and her husband, Robert, 41, should be on Easy Street. A colon and rectal surgeon, Dr. Cline cleared $250,000 last year. But that was $30,000 less than two years earlier because of higher expenses, said his office manager, Bessie Crissman.
The cost of Dr. Cline's medical malpractice insurance, for example, rose $5,000 last year and will rise another $10,000 this year, to $23,000, Ms. Crissman said. The rent went up $5,000 last year, salaries for his office workers rose $7,000, their health insurance, $5,000.
"We have a two-way squeeze -- limited reimbursement from Medicare and managed care," Dr. Cline said. "I'm a sole practitioner, so I can't negotiate with big insurance companies. It's 'take it or leave it.' "
The decline hits home, where the Clines are raising six children, ages 2 to 8. A year ago, they sold their house in central Austin for $799,000 and bought another for $580,000. A house in their old neighborhood with enough bedrooms, Mrs. Cline said, would have cost $1 million. 
"We got a fifth bedroom," said Mrs. Cline, much cheered by the move. "It's on a smaller lot, and it doesn't have a pool. But the taxes are less. The utilities are less. Our neighbors are wonderful." 
But the squeeze goes on. Mrs. Cline's monthly spending budget is $3,000, or $36,000 a year, the same as three years ago. "I let the nanny go in September," she said, saving $26,000 a year. No sooner had she completed payments on her 1997 Chevrolet Suburban in July than it started breaking down. Since November, she said, she had spent $2,700 on repairs. 
In their budget calculations, the Clines give little thought to federal income taxes. They have not felt the last cuts at all, Dr. Cline said.
Accountants at Deloitte & Touche, who looked at the tax status of the four families interviewed for this article, said lower tax rates, primarily, could save the Clines $4,500 a year.

The Taylors of Atlanta
The economy batters Barney Taylor Jr., 34, and his wife, LeMeeche, 28, of Atlanta much more than taxes, and right now things look uncommonly promising for the software engineering business Mr. Taylor opened 10 years ago. In his case, it is not America's economy that has ignited his business. It is Nigeria's. 
Mr. Taylor said recent sales of software and government security systems to Nigeria had allowed him to build the professional staff of his company, Thirteen Scribes Inc., to 10 from 4 two years ago. "We're still growing," he said. "I'll probably hire 16 more next month."
Mr. Taylor declined to say what he earned. In the late 1990's, his best years, he made about $100,000 annually, but he turned some of that into a business making low-cost computers for children. It was unprofitable, so Mr. Taylor has changed the business from production to computer training for the young. 
Two years ago the Taylors, parents of a son, Kahlil, 2 1/2, were talking of moving from an apartment where they pay rent to a house of their own. Instead, they have moved to a larger apartment in a nicer neighborhood. 
First, Mrs. Taylor said, she wanted to go to massage therapy school so she could earn a decent wage. In November, she found bookkeeping work for three days a week with a chiropractor. In addition she gives a massage there once or twice a week for $50 each.
She finished school last month, so a house is back on the agenda, she said. But there could be delays. The Taylors' medical expenses, some not covered by insurance, have climbed with care for Kahlil and a skin-cancer scare for Mrs. Taylor. She has completed payments on her 1998 Mitsubishi Mirage but has student loans to pay off.
Deloitte & Touche estimates that proposed tax credits and cuts, and some relief from the way the tax system penalizes married couples, could save the Taylors about $2,300 this year.

The Villas of Helena
Carrie Villa of Helena, Mont., might gain $100 from the president's tax proposal, Deloitte & Touche estimates. She makes $9.36 an hour as a full-time accounting clerk at the Montana Department of Natural Resources and Conservation and $7.80 an hour working 16 hours a week at Wal-Mart.
A divorced mother of three, ages 21, 15 and 13, Ms. Villa, 42, earns about $20,000 a year, low enough to exempt her from federal income taxes and benefits from the cuts. Instead, she is eligible for the earned income tax credit, about $2,300.
She is grateful not to be "one of all those people who have lost jobs." But getting along is a penny-pinching grind. While her wages change little, she said: "My electricity went up $16 a month two months ago. My cable went up $5 a month to $60. I'm thinking of dropping that. 
"My health insurance is going up. I was paying $93 a month and that's going up $40. That's out of pocket." The deductible on the health insurance is rising this year, too, to $435 from $300.
To cope, Ms. Villa moved from an apartment she lived in two years ago to a trailer. A boyfriend she shared it with moved on, so she is planning to move again to reduce her $625 monthly rent. She has chopped up her credit cards, on which she owed $7,200 two years ago. "They're all gone," she said. "This Christmas, I only spent cash. I won't be paying for Christmas for years to come. 
"I'm trying to go back to school," she said, "so I can get a better job." Right now her only obvious way of raising her wages a bit is by hurrying shoppers through her Wal-Mart check-out line. "You can get raises if you go faster," she said.

The Ducharmes of Alfred
Stephen Ducharme, 37, the carpenter, and his wife, Lisa, a waitress and bartender, live in Alfred, Me., about 25 miles south of Portland. They have three children, 14, 4 and 2, and together make around $50,000, which they consider middle class. The government, Mr. Ducharme said, "should be helping people who have a hard time making a meal."
Under the current child tax credit, the Ducharmes save $600 from their taxes for each child, and President Bush would raise that to $1,000.
"Now I know $400 is a lot of money, but we go through that in a week," Mr. Ducharme said. "It's not enough to get all excited about."
The Ducharmes seem to represent the brightest side of the economy. "Recession?" said Mr. Ducharme, who earns about $25 an hour. "I don't see that as a problem. Work up here was bouncing off the walls until three months ago, when the cold weather came, and we're getting a lot of calls for the spring." 
The $1,000 that Deloitte & Touche says the Ducharmes might save under the Bush tax program is not meaningful enough to be important in their family's calculations, they say. "The only thing I look at is my job building houses. Whatever I'm doing, it's working up here."

HEADLINE: A Wily Contender, But Unlikely Winner, Eyes the Presidency 

BYLINE:  By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 

 BODY:
The Rev. Al Sharpton has run for office three times from New York, and has lost each time. He has been embroiled in polarizing disputes throughout his career, including the handling of his personal finances and his involvement in a racially charged rape case that a jury found to be a hoax. Even the ever-energetic and indefatigable Mr. Sharpton acknowledges it is unlikely that he will ever be elected president of the United States.
 Not to say Mr. Sharpton is not going to try. 
 At 48, Mr. Sharpton is joining the field of Democratic candidates for president. He is planning to create a presidential exploratory committee on Jan. 21, and is already delivering speeches across the nation, preparing to open an office in Washington and offering opinions on everything from North Korea to deficit spending. 
"I'm very serious about this," Mr. Sharpton said between cellphone calls over breakfast at the Four Seasons in the Georgetown section of Washington the other day. "I'm not just talking about Sharpton getting a position in the White House. I'm talking about fighting for the soul of the Democratic Party."
Aides in competing presidential camps describe Mr. Sharpton's candidacy as little more than a distraction, a quest on the fringe that will ultimately have little bearing on the Democratic presidential competition.
Yet Democrats acquainted with Mr. Sharpton's style and skills suggest that might be a miscalculation. Many Democrats say he could prove to be a constant and potentially unwelcome complication for the other Democrats seeking to challenge President Bush.
For two decades, Mr. Sharpton has shown an unflagging talent for winning attention for himself and his causes. (He was on the NBC News program "Meet the Press" for 17 minutes this morning.) His wit, bluster and bravado make him endlessly quotable, bolstering his reputation as a ruthless political street fighter.
As the only black candidate in a crowded field, Mr. Sharpton said, he would do well in states with large black populations. In particular, he said, he might win the important South Carolina Democratic primary, an assertion that did not seem outlandish to other Democrats, who noted that 40 percent of the South Carolina Democratic electorate is black.
"He clearly has some potential to get a significant number of delegates, especially in the Southern states," said David Bositis, senior policy analyst with the Joint Center for Political and Economic Studies, a research group that deals with African-American issues.
Mr. Sharpton is putting the others on the spot by raising issues they have avoided: calling for all Confederate flags to be taken down in South Carolina and Mississippi, for example. 
He tears into the credentials of his rivals with all the enthusiasm of a Republican, calling for the ouster of Terry McAuliffe, the Democratic Party chairman, asserting that his party has abandoned its liberal roots and planning for a prominent speaking role at the Democratic convention in Boston in 2004.
"His rivals will have an impossible time dealing with him," said Mark Green, the Democratic mayoral candidate who lost in New York last year in no small part because of Mr. Sharpton. "At the end of the day, they will have to get 50 percent plus one and attract white, black, Latino and swing voters. All he has to do is attract a strong niche of voters and he's free to attack others when they are loath to respond in kind for fear of offending his niche."
David Axelrod, a Democratic consultant from Chicago who worked in New York during the mayoral race, said: "Sharpton is largely an unknown to the political community in Washington, and his role is being understated here. Anyone who knows him knows that he is a very, very smart and clever politician. I don't think people are fully grasping his capacities."
Referring to the other presidential contenders, Howard Wolfson, the executive director of the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee, said, "These guys have no idea what they are in for." 
Over a bowl of oatmeal and bananas one recent morning, Mr. Sharpton displayed no reticence about pointing out the deficiencies of his party and its candidates.
"I'm operating from the premise that the Democratic Party lost not only the White House but the Senate and the Congress because their strategy has been to go to the right to get new voters," he said. 
He criticized the Democratic Leadership Council, the moderate group of Democrats that launched the presidential candidacy of Bill Clinton and has close ties to four of the 2004 Democratic candidates. 
"They never regained the Congress," Mr. Sharpton said. "So how long do you keep going over a new strategy that doesn't work? They are no longer the new Democrats. They are the old Democrats. We had another debacle in 2002, we're going to give them another shot? That's crazy."
Mr. Sharpton predicted that he would walk into the convention with an army of delegates disenchanted with the party's move to the center. He would, he said, thus command the same influence and attention that the Rev. Jesse L. Jackson enjoyed when he ran for president based on a similar appeal in 1984 and 1988.
"Politically, that gives me tremendous leverage," Mr. Sharpton said. "I don't want to do a whole interview like I'm not trying to win -- I don't want that kind of article. But assuming, in the unlikely occurrence I don't win" -- Mr. Sharpton paused and chuckled -- "someone who is the winner and the chair of the party would have to sit down with that bloc of voters and deal with it."
But would Mr. Sharpton really be in a position to make these demands?
Many Democrats described the Sharpton candidacy as little more than his latest attempt, this time on the national stage, to win publicity for himself, and contributions to his civil rights organization, the National Action Network.
Mr. Sharpton disputed that, though he could barely contain his delight as he raised the prospect that he might before long be traveling with his own detail of Secret Service agents.
And several Democrats said that if Mr. Sharpton were really treated as a serious candidate, he would have difficulty surviving questions about, for example, his income taxes, or his advocacy of Tawana Brawley, who claimed in 1987 that she had been abducted and raped by a gang of white men. The case was judged a hoax by a grand jury, and Mr. Sharpton was found to have defamed a white prosecutor whom Ms. Brawley accused of being involved in the attack. Mr. Sharpton was fined $65,000.
"If his opponents and voters view him as a normal presidential candidate, he's disqualified," Mr. Green said. "Because he's 0-for-3 in elections for lesser office, never breaking a third of the primary vote, and a jury held that he slandered a law enforcement official."
Referring to Senator John Kerry of Massachusetts and Senator Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut, Mr. Green asked: "Could Kerry or Lieberman stay in the race with that history? His rivals and commentators and voters should view him as a serious variable, but not a serious candidate."
Mr. Sharpton pre-emptively raised, and dismissed, the issue of how the Brawley case would affect his candidacy. "Brawley is a New York media question," he said. "The problem with my Brawley critics is my life didn't end there." 
Here in Washington, it seems as if he is stopped at almost every corner by someone who recognizes him -- evidence, Mr. Sharpton said, that in this field of relatively unknown Democratic candidates for president, he is the celebrity.
"Let's face it, other than Lieberman, you don't have a national household name, other than me," he said. Senator Lieberman is to formally announce on Monday that he is forming his own presidential exploratory committee.
As was evident by his prominent place on the "Meet the Press" set this morning, Mr. Sharpton will encounter little difficulty finding speaking platforms. And he knows how to make the most of his moment.
Asked about Senator Kerry, whom Mr. Sharpton described as the Democratic front-runner, Mr. Sharpton noted the paucity of blacks among Massachusetts's elected officials, and said he read a newspaper article the other day about racial profiling there.
"Where is Kerry in his home state?" Mr. Sharpton asked. "If I'm going to be in the debates, he's going to have to talk about that."
Mr. Lieberman, he said, was "an opponent of affirmative action," a characterization that does not square with how Mr. Lieberman describes his own views on the subject. Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri "stood with the president on the war -- and was part of the leadership that was absolutely defeated in 2002."
He saved his harshest words for Senator John Edwards of North Carolina, a trial lawyer who, Mr. Edwards's advisers argued, posed the greatest threat to Mr. Sharpton's hopes of a strong showing in the South.
"This guy got rich fighting for the regular guy," Mr. Sharpton said. "So I'm going to ask him at the debates: name one regular guy you fought for that you didn't get paid for. With a Sharpton-less race, he's gotten an easy ride."
The platform and the party's candidate, he said, should oppose a war in Iraq, the death penalty and the tax cuts pushed by President Bush, and should champion affirmative action. He said he would push for the ouster of Mr. McAuliffe as the party chairman, calling him a "nice man" who had failed.
When Mr. Sharpton finished a rather contentious interview on "Meet the Press," his host, Tim Russert, bid him farewell by declaring: "To be continued: We look forward to covering you on the campaign trail."
Mr. Sharpton's eyes lit up and he grinned broadly. "I will be looking for you, Brother Russert," he said.

PROFILE
Alfred Charles Sharpton Jr.

BORN: Oct. 3, 1954, in Brooklyn, N.Y.

HOMETOWN: Brooklyn.

EDUCATION: Samuel Tilden High School, three years at Brooklyn College (no degree).

CAREER HIGHLIGHTS: Ordained as a Pentecostal minister at the age of 10, 1964; youth director, Operation Breadbasket, New York, 1969-71; founder and president, National Youth Movement, 1971-86; founder and president, National Action Network Inc., 1991 to present. Ran for United States Senate from New York in 1992 and 1994, and ran for mayor of New York City in 1997.

FAVORITE PRESIDENT: "Take the war in Vietnam out, and Lyndon Johnson is my favorite president. Civil Rights Act, Voters Right Act, worked with Adam Clayton Powell."

FAMILY: Married to Kathy Jordan; two daughters.

This is the sixth article of a series about the prospective candidates for the Democratic presidential nomination in 2004.

HEADLINE: Koizumi Visits Energy-Rich Russian Region, Seeking Oil 

BYLINE:  By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: KHABAROVSK, Russia, Jan. 12 

 BODY:
Almost a century after Japan beat Russia in the Russo-Japanese war of 1905, Junichiro Koizumi today made the first visit of a Japanese prime minister to the Russian Far East, a sprawling, resource-rich region that stretches from Siberia to disputed islands north of Japan.
 This time it was not territorial conquest but a geopolitical chess game with China over Russian oil that brought Mr. Koizumi to this 19th-century railroad city, where ice sculptures glittered in subzero temperatures. Donning a fur hat in the Arctic cold, Mr. Koizumi, leader of the world's second-largest oil consumer, openly appealed for the construction of a 2,500-mile oil pipeline that would bypass China, bringing Siberian oil to the Sea of Japan. 
 "Russia, especially its Far Eastern region, has great energy potential, which must be fully used," Mr. Koizumi told reporters, echoing arguments he made in Moscow to President Vladimir V. Putin earlier in his four-day trip. Bringing Siberian oil east for the first time, the $5 billion pipeline would be three times as long as the Trans-Alaska pipeline and would carry one million barrels of oil a day.
The pipeline has a potential of cutting Japan's dependence on Middle Eastern oil to 65 percent, from 83 percent today, according to Japanese estimates. Speaking in a city that was occupied by Japanese troops in 1918, Mr. Koizumi argued that energy cooperation would help bind together Russia and Japan, two countries that have yet to sign a peace treaty closing their last armed conflict, World War II.
"Japan must import most of its oil from abroad," the Japanese leader told reporters. "There is much that we can do for each other."
Mr. Koizumi also cited Japan's participation in the largest foreign investment project in Russian history: a 10-year, $22 billion project to develop huge oil and natural gas reserves off Sakhalin Island, directly north of Japan. Japanese companies have already invested $1 billion of their planned $8 billion share.
Pointing to a natural cooperation between Japan, a major energy user, and Russia, a major energy producer, he said, "The development of the Sakhalin shelf is one example of energy partnership."
An alternate, shorter pipeline route, designed to bring Siberian oil to fuel industries in northern China, puts China and Japan in direct competition over Russian resources.
Outside official meetings today, Japanese diplomats argued that Russia had geopolitical reasons to go with the Sea of Japan route: a need to counterbalance China. The Japanese hoped to play on Russians' insecurities about their Far East, an economically stagnant, underpopulated colony of about five million Europeans in Asia.
"High-ranking Russians are very cautious not to mention the threat out loud," one Russian-speaking Japanese diplomat said, alluding to China.
"But if you are a realistic Russian, you see you have the longest border on earth," the Japanese diplomat continued. "And on the other side of that border is the world's fastest-growing economy, fastest-growing defense budget, fastest-growing use of energy, and a big, big population."
Russia's late-19th-century nation-builders pushed the Trans-Siberian railroad through this city in 1897, echoing transcontinental railroads in Canada and the United States. Today, the Japanese say that building a pipeline through here to the port of Nakhodka would consolidate Russia's presence on the Pacific.
Indeed, many residents of the Russian Far East will admit that, while Japan was their paranoia of the past, China is their paranoia of the future.
In a nod to the past, Mr. Koizumi laid flowers today on a peace memorial built for thousands of Japanese prisoners of war who died while held in Russia after World War II.
But in this city, where local newspapers routinely carry reports of the police catching Chinese migrants sneaking over the frozen Amur River, Oleg I. Lekhovitser, the regional government spokesman, noted with pride that Khabarovsk keeps illegal Chinese immigration strictly "under control."
Viktor Ishayev, governor of the Khabarovsk region, complained a few weeks ago to Vremya Novosti, a Russian newspaper: "America bombed Japan, but at the moment Japan invests most in America. Japan has invested $620 billion overseas over the last 26 years, out of which the U.S. has received 42 percent, Russia .054 percent, and the Russian Far East .025 percent."
Today, minutes after Mr. Koizumi's official jet took off from here in snow flurries, Mr. Ishayev fielded a question from a Russian reporter who asked, wide-eyed, "Could Russia end up supplying 20 percent of Japan's oil needs?"
"Yes, again it proves that there is now trust between the two countries," said Mr. Ishayev, a veteran of years spent on a government commission that tried in vain to get a peace treaty signed, despite a dispute over four of the Kurile Islands.

HEADLINE: THREATS AND RESPONSES: ASIAN ARENA; 
U.S. Envoy Starts Discussions in Seoul on North Korea

BYLINE:  By SETH MYDANS 

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, Monday, Jan. 13 

 BODY:
Assistant Secretary of State James A. Kelly began consultations with South Korea's president-elect and other officials today about the nuclear threat from North Korea, as the North Korean government maintained a barrage of bellicose statements. 
 There were other developments in the United States and Russia on Sunday indicating that a diplomatic solution might be a bit closer. Gov. Bill Richardson of New Mexico, the former United States ambassador to the United Nations who talked with North Korean representatives last week, said he expected low-level talks to begin between the United States and North Korea at the United Nations. And the Russian Foreign Ministry expressed some optimism about a possible settlement of the crisis. 
 Mr. Kelly, who is responsible for East Asian and Pacific affairs, met with President-elect Roh Moo Hyun at the presidential Blue House. 
The Bush administration has said North Korea must dismantle its nuclear programs, a path it has abandoned, before there can be any talks about aid and improved ties. 
At a news conference before meeting Mr. Roh, Mr. Kelly, responding to a question about the potential for regional cooperation on energy matters, said, "Once we get beyond nuclear weapons, there may be opportunities with the U.S., with private investors, with other countries to help North Korea in the energy area."
Mr. Kelly's arrival on Sunday began his first visit since October, when he traveled to Pyongyang, North Korea's capital, and met with officials there. He later said they had admitted conducting a secret nuclear weapons program. Tensions have risen since then, and in the last three days North Korea has announced that it plans to withdraw from the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty and that it may resume a suspended program of missile tests.
Hours before Mr. Kelly's arrival here on Sunday, North Korea pressed an earlier denial that it had ever admitted conducting a nuclear weapons program. "The claim that we admitted developing nuclear weapons is an invention fabricated by the United States with sinister intentions," said a North Korean newspaper, Rodong Sinmun, as quoted by the South Korean news agency Yonhap.
Such a program would violate a 1994 agreement in which the United States promised to provide energy supplies if North Korea froze its nuclear program. In December, Washington halted oil shipments under the deal, and experts said North Korea would soon be suffering the effects of severe energy shortages.
Declaring the 1994 agreement void, North Korea removed seals placed on one of its nuclear plants and expelled two inspectors from the International Atomic Energy Agency who were verifying the country's compliance. The agency, based in Vienna, now has the right to make a report of noncompliance to the United Nations Security Council, which could then impose sanctions.
North Korea has said such actions would amount to a "declaration of war." Employing an image common in North Korean threats, Rodong Sinmum said today, "If the United States evades its responsibility and challenges us, we will turn the citadel of imperialists into a sea of fire."
On Saturday, North Korea reported that a million people had rallied in Pyongyang to support what it called "a life-and-death battle" against the country's enemies.
For its part, South Korea repeated that it was seeking a diplomatic resolution to the standoff. "The government's consistent position is that it will do its best to resolve the North Korean nuclear issue peacefully through diplomacy," said Yim Sung Joon, a South Korean national security adviser, who had just returned from a visit to Washington.
Statements of concern and calls for peaceful negotiations have come from around the world since North Korea's announcements in the past three days. "It is important that North Korea be steadfastly worked upon to gain a peaceful solution," Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi of Japan was quoted as saying today as he met with officials in Russia.
In an appearance on the ABC News program "This Week," Mr. Richardson said on Sunday that he agreed with the Bush administration that it should not "engage in an immediate, direct dialogue at the time the North Koreans are talking about 'holy wars.' " He said he expected "the next step to be at the United Nations, at a low level -- some technical talks."
Mr. Richardson, who the administration has said is not speaking for the United States government, also called for "a bilateral, nonaggression, binding pact that basically says the United States is ready to agree that North Korea is not going to be treated in an aggressive hostile action, in other words that we are not going to attack North Korea, in exchange for some of the steps that are needed." Those steps, he said, include discussion of a freeze on work at North Korea's nuclear reprocessing facilities to ensure peaceful use, and allowing international inspectors back in. 
"The North Koreans said they're ready to do that," he continued. "But only after a negotiation."
Russia, thought to be one of the countries best able to influence North Korea, has outlined a compromise proposal for easing tensions in talks with the United States, South Korea, China and France. A spokesman for the Foreign Ministry, Aleksandr V. Takovenko, said today that "the main elements of the package settlement are taking shape," but that negotiations continued.
The proposal calls for North Korea to abandon any nuclear-weapons programs and strictly observe the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty, as well as the agreement in 1994 to suspend its weapons programs in exchange for assistance in constructing nuclear power plants. At the same time, Russia is calling for multilateral and bilateral talks between North Korea and other countries, including the United States, aimed at providing North Korea with guarantees of its security, a crucial North Korean demand. The proposal also calls for the resumption of relief assistance and economic aid, which the United States, South Korea and Japan suspended after the disclosure of North Korea's weapons program last fall.

CORRECTION-DATE: January 17, 2003

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about meetings between James A. Kelly, the United States envoy, and South Korea's president-elect, Roh Moo Hyun, misstated the location. It was Mr. Roh's office, not at the Blue House, the presidential mansion.

SUBJECT: NUCLEAR WEAPONS (94%); TALKS & MEETINGS (90%); UNITED NATIONS INSTITUTIONS (89%); NUCLEAR ENERGY (89%); ARMS CONTROL & DISARMAMENT (89%); MILITARY WEAPONS (89%); INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS (89%); FOREIGN RELATIONS (78%); US PRESIDENTS (78%); EMBASSIES & CONSULATES (78%); NUCLEAR POWER PLANTS (78%); ENERGY & UTILITY POLICY (78%); US FEDERAL GOVERNMENT (77%); PRESS CONFERENCES (77%); STATE DEPARTMENTS & FOREIGN SERVICES (76%); EMBARGOES & SANCTIONS (76%); POWER PLANTS (73%); FINES & PENALTIES (68%); TREATIES & AGREEMENTS (63%); MISSILE RESEARCH & DEVELOPMENT (63%); TERRORISM (59%) UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS; ATOMIC WEAPONS; TERRORISM

HEADLINE: THREATS AND RESPONSES: DIPLOMACY; 
North Korean Talks? U.S. Weighs the Possible Price

BYLINE:  By STEVEN R. WEISMAN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 

 BODY:
For weeks, while North Korea has stepped up its actions and threats over its nuclear and military programs, Bush administration officials have wondered whether the North would also send word that it might be willing to discuss ways to pull back from the crisis.
 But now that the North Koreans have sent such a signal, through unofficial talks last week with Gov. Bill Richardson of New Mexico, administration officials must decide whether to open direct negotiations with North Korea or dismiss Mr. Richardson's efforts. 
 Officials said President Bush approved the New Mexico talks with two North Korea diplomats even though some advisers were against them. It is unclear whether he will allow official talks.
Much depends on how much faith the administration puts in the willingness of the main North Korean envoy in the New Mexico talks, Han Song Ryol, to discuss ways of freezing activity at the plutonium-producing nuclear reactor at Yongbyon and to talk about the status of North Korea's program to enrich uranium into weapons-grade fuel at its other plants.
On the ABC News program "This Week," Mr. Richardson said today that the North Koreans were "being belligerent in preparation, I believe, for a negotiation."
"They always do that," he added. "They did say to me that they're ready to negotiate the verification of some of their nuclear-reprocessing facilities. They did say that they would talk to the administration about the uranium enrichment facility. They did say they wanted to improve relations with the U.S."
But because the price for such steps by North Korea is not clear, it is questionable whether the Bush administration will respond positively. American officials said that such vague talk was not reassuring without North Korea signaling a willingness to dismantle those programs.
The Bush administration does not want to be seen as making any kind of offer as a quid pro quo for such steps, though many specialists say that any improvement in relations with North Korea would have to lead to such benefits down the road.
Officials familiar with the New Mexico talks said Secretary of State Colin L. Powell recommended approving them, making the conciliatory gesture of lifting travel restrictions on the North Koreans.
Mr. Powell has generally taken a tough stance on North Korea but is said to favor diplomatic contacts and to oppose further economic sanctions, while a faction led by Vice President Dick Cheney is convinced that isolation and economic pressure are the only way to get it to respond -- or, alternatively, to implode under the stress as the Soviet Union did. 
The administration was reluctant to have Mr. Richardson, a United Nations envoy for the Clinton administration, play a mediating role, said an official close to the New Mexico talks. But with the Bush administration having already reversed its approach on talks, dropping its earlier demand for actions to dismantle its nuclear programs before even indirect conversations, let alone negotiations, could take place, it now appears possible that a meeting at the United Nations could take place.
China, Russia, Japan and South Korea are considered likely to encourage the administration to make a positive response, diplomats say.
Mr. Richardson tried to get the North Koreans to let him say that they expressed "a willingness to have better relations with the United States." Mr. Han was said to have resisted such an expression until the second day of the three-day talks.
The North Koreans were also said to have emphasized to Mr. Richardson their security concerns and their desire for guarantees that the United States would not attack them, rather than asking for food, economic or energy assistance, the focus of their interests when he met with them in the 1990's.
That emphasis could be significant since administration officials say they are quite prepared, as an eventual part of a deal with North Korea, to include some form of nonaggression guarantees, putting in writing the statements that Mr. Bush has been making since the current crisis began last October.
If the administration does take seriously Mr. Han's offer of talks, the next step may be technical discussions at the United Nations that would pave the way for more substantive talks.
Another question is whether Mr. Richardson, who came to know Mr. Han while both were serving at the United Nations, will continue to play a role. The North Korean delegation was said to have asked for him to do so, but that is considered unlikely given the Bush administration's undisguised antipathy for its predecessor. Indeed, when Mr. Richardson praised Mr. Powell at his news conference on Friday, the governor smiled and said he hoped that the secretary's remark would not hurt him.
On the other hand, Mr. Han was said to have told Mr. Richardson that the North Koreans did not trust the Bush team because of its harsh statements about North Korea. Mr. Bush's oft-repeated pledge not to attack was having less effect than his inclusion of North Korea in an "axis of evil" with Iraq, a nation that appears to them to be targeted for imminent attack.
The North Koreans reached out to Mr. Richardson before he took office as governor on Jan. 1, asking him to be their messenger to the Bush administration. At a reception for governors at the White House, Mr. Richardson mentioned the North Korean feeler to a Bush aide. Mr. Powell later called him in New Mexico to give the green light.

HEADLINE: Trenton Mulls Tax Increase For Wealthiest 

BYLINE:  By LAURA MANSNERUS 

DATELINE: TRENTON, Jan. 10 

 BODY:
While President Bush promotes income tax cuts that would benefit the wealthiest taxpayers, some New Jersey Democrats are quietly reviving the idea of raising taxes on the same people.
 A discussion born of desperation is growing as Gov. James E. McGreevey approaches his State of the State address on Tuesday, and the announcement of his budget plan three weeks after that. The shortfall for the year beginning July 1 is estimated at $4 billion, about one-sixth of the current budget. 
 Many legislators say some variation of the "millionaire tax" expected in Connecticut can be sold here, despite New Jersey's famous aversion to raising taxes.
"It's on the table, believe me," a member of the Democratic-led Assembly said. "No matter what anybody tells you, at the end of the day it will still be on the table."
It may not seem politically daring to ask for more from taxpayers like Steve Forbes and Jon Bon Jovi, but the prospect of higher income taxes -- for anyone -- has been unmentionable in Trenton for a decade. Last spring, when Mr. McGreevey and legislators were exhausting possibilities for closing a multibillion-dollar budget gap, an income tax increase was not among them.
Mr. McGreevey still vows not to touch the income or sales taxes. But this year promises to be even than last, since the easier revenue sources have already been tapped.
In a much less serious bind, Gov. John G. Rowland of Connecticut recently spun around on the issue, agreeing to an income tax surcharge on incomes over $1 million. Mr. Rowland, a Republican, vetoed the same measure eight months before.
In New Jersey, the Assembly speaker, Albio Sires, touched off both consternation and applause when he suggested raising the top income tax rate, which is now 6.37 percent on individual incomes over $75,000 a year and joint incomes over $150,000. In a television interview two weeks ago, Mr. Sires suggested raising the rate on those making more than $200,000 a year.
"I heard his comments and damned near fell off my chair," said William G. Dressel, the director of the New Jersey State League of Municipalities.
Mr. Dressel said such a proposal, if tied to property tax relief, would probably be well received by his members. They are are still fuming over the governor's freeze on state aid to local governments and school districts and expect it to continue. Last year, property taxes rose by an average of 7 percent across the state.
Mr. Sires, a Democrat, said he had not met with Mr. McGreevey about a new high-end tax bracket. But Mr. Sires said that recently, "I saw the governor at two events and I whispered in his ear.
"I whispered, 'It only affects 2 percent of the population.' "
Mr. Sires, who is also the mayor of West New York, also said he had gotten "a great response" from local officials.
The Republicans, who hold half the seats in the State Senate, insist that they will not approve an increase. "There are very few economists that prescribe higher income taxes, or any taxes, for that matter, during a recession," said Senator Joseph M. Kyrillos Jr., the Republican state chairman. "More than most times, I think it's a particularly bad idea."
But some lawmakers and lobbyists say that even Republicans are trading ideas for selling an income tax increase -- and getting political cover for it in a year when the whole Legislature is up for re-election.
And some Democrats remain openly critical of former Gov. Christie Whitman's cut in the top tax rate, which was 7 percent when she was elected in 1993. "You're talking to someone who voted against the Whitman income tax cuts to begin with," said Senator Bernard F. Kenny Jr., a Hoboken Democrat who is on the Budget Committee. "I voted against them three times."
"I find merit to a number of proposals out there that would raise the rate in the upper brackets half a point to a point," Senator Kenny said.
Voters have expressed a preference for any alternative to the hated property tax. In a Quinnipiac University Poll last month, 74 percent of those surveyed said they would rather see an increase in the state income tax. Even more, presumably, would rather see an income tax increase affect a small group they do not belong to.
In advocating a higher top tax bracket, many Democrats refer to a proposal by New Jersey Policy Perspective, a policy research group directed by a former Florio administration member, Jon Shure. That proposal would raise the top rate to 7 percent for joint incomes over $500,000 and to 8 percent for those over $1 million.
This week Mr. Shure announced a report by a Washington-based organization, the Institute on Taxation and Economic Policy, that described an "unfair, regressive tax system" in New Jersey. The report found that families earning less than $19,000 a year pay 12.4 percent of their income in state and local taxes, largely because of the sales tax, while the wealthiest 1 percent, those making over $571,000 a year, pay 8.2 percent of their income.
Of the 32 other states that have progressive income taxes, 20 have higher top rates than New Jersey, according to the National Conference of State Legislatures. Most of those impose the top rate at much lower income levels, however, some at $20,000 or $30,000 a year. (New York's highest personal income tax rate is 6.85 percent for individual incomes over $20,000.)

HEADLINE: 2 Plan Counteroffers for Safeway of Britain 

BYLINE:  By SUZANNE KAPNER and ANDREW ROSS SORKIN 

DATELINE: LONDON, Jan. 12 

 BODY:
Wal-Mart Stores and J. Sainsbury of Britain are each drawing up plans to make a counteroffer for Safeway, Britain's fourth-largest supermarket chain, which last week agreed to be bought by William Morrison Supermarkets, a smaller rival, for $:2.7 billion, or $4.3 billion, in stock.
 The board of Sainsbury, a big rival grocer, met today and agreed to continue working on an offer. The chief executive, Sir Peter Davis, is expected to update investors when Sainsbury announces its sales results for the Christmas season on Monday, people close to the company said. Wal-Mart, which owns Asda in Britain, is also considering its options. 
 Sainsbury is the second-largest supermarket chain in this country, while Asda is third. Though both trail Tesco, the market leader, by a wide margin, analysts said they are big enough to face antitrust hurdles in their effort to acquire Safeway.
To avoid such problems, Wal-Mart, America's largest discount retailer, and Sainsbury had initially considered making a joint bid, and then dividing Safeway's 490 stores, people involved in the negotiations said. But those discussions broke down in October, after Wal-Mart insisted on keeping roughly two-thirds of the stores.
Since then, these people said, Sainsbury has begun sounding out private equity firms, including Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, about forming a partnership to bid for Safeway.
William Morrison is smaller than Safeway, and its offer, which has the backing of Safeway's board, is not expected to draw a lengthy antitrust review. Executives from William Morrison are expected to make their case to Safeway shareholders in meetings this week.
"We will explain the advantages of the deal to shareholders, customers and employees," a William Morrison spokesman said. Representatives from Asda, Sainsbury and Safeway declined to comment today.
If Wal-Mart proceeds with a bid, it is expected to make it all in cash, while Sainsbury would probably offer a mix of cash and stock. The offers are expected to exceed $:3 billion, or $4.8 billion, people close to the companies said.
Britain's supermarket industry has become fiercely competitive since Wal-Mart bought Asda in 1999 and introduced the concept of everyday low prices. Today, price wars among the biggest chains are common as the chains battle for customer loyalty.
Analysts have expected Wal-Mart to expand its presence in Britain, as it seeks to take advantage of economies of scale that would allow it to negotiate the best prices from suppliers. But some have questioned whether Safeway makes a good fit. Safeway stores tend to be smaller than Asda's and more of them are in cities, where Asda is predominantly in the suburbs and rural areas. Until 1987, Safeway was owned by Safeway Inc., which is based in Pleasanton, Calif.

HEADLINE: As Cases of Induced Labor Rise, So Do Experts' Concerns 

BYLINE:  By JANE E. BRODY 

 BODY:
A number of obstetrical experts are becoming increasingly concerned about the growing number of pregnant women whose labors are induced for no apparent medical reason. Since 1990, the proportion of births resulting from an induced labor has doubled: one baby in five is now born after the birth process has been started by a drug.
 In about half of these cases, the reason for induction is not related to any medical problem in the woman or her unborn baby, said Dr. William F. Rayburn, an expert in maternal and fetal medicine at the University of New Mexico Health Sciences Center in Albuquerque. 
 Rather, a decision to induce labor is often reached for reasons of convenience to the mother, the family or the doctor. In some cases, women worried about the baby's health may exert pressure; in other cases, doctors may fear medical liability for waiting, Dr. Rayburn and his colleague, Dr. Jun Zhang, wrote this year in the journal Obstetrics and Gynecology, after reviewing the research on the topic. 
"Now more than ever, obstetricians are concerned about anything going wrong," Dr. Rayburn said. Increasing numbers of lawsuits have so escalated the cost of malpractice insurance and the burdens of litigation that many obstetrician-gynecologists have abandoned obstetrics altogether.
In most hospitals, Dr. Rayburn and Dr. Zhang reported, the instances of induced labor now exceed the combined number of Caesarean deliveries, vaginal births after a previous Caesarean and vaginal deliveries requiring forceps. The numbers are even higher in many community hospitals, where more than 40 percent of births are induced, with as many as three of four done for no compelling medical reason, according to a review of 7,000 consecutive inductions published in 1999 in The American Journal of Obstetrics and Gynecology.
Induced labor greatly increases the costs and health risks of childbirth because time spent in labor in the hospital is longer, and the need for Caesarean deliveries is greater, Dr. Karen E. Kaufman, an expert in maternal and fetal medicine at Northwestern University Medical School, and her co-authors at Northwestern and the University of North Carolina reported in an analysis in October in The American Journal of Obstetrics and Gynecology. 
"Induction increases the length of labor and often increases the need for pain relief because of the more prolonged labor," Dr. Rayburn said in an interview.
Induction results in Caesarean deliveries, he said, when the cervix fails to dilate or dilates very slowly or stops before full dilation, or when the woman becomes too fatigued to push the baby out or when the resulting contractions are too strong for the baby to tolerate them well. Caesareans after inductions are particularly common in first pregnancies, he said.
So why do so many women ask to be induced?
"Most women just want to get their pregnancies over with," said Dr. Deborah A. Wing of the University of Southern California. "They consider it abnormal if they go one day past their due date. They don't realize that the due date is merely a suggestion."
Dr. Kaufman cautioned, "Women should not be asking to be induced just for the sake of convenience."
In an uncomplicated single-birth pregnancy, it is more economical to wait up to two weeks past a woman's due date before trying to induce labor, the researchers from Northwestern and North Carolina wrote.
But, they noted, induction of labor has "potential tangible benefits" because delivery prevents the possibility that the fetus will die before birth, which occurs in 1 pregnancy in 1,000 among women past their due dates who wait for labor to start naturally.
The team acknowledged that the best way to deal with a pregnancy lasting beyond 40 weeks had never been clearly established.
Doctors who favor induction argue that waiting longer increases the risk of a Caesarean delivery because the fetus gets too big for a vaginal birth, and they also cite the risk of stillbirth and complications.
Those who favor waiting for labor to begin naturally point to studies showing that induction increases costs of childbirth and the need for Caesarean deliveries when induced labors fail to progress normally.
For women whose labor is induced before their due dates, or when a due date cannot be firmly established, Dr. Wing said, "there is a small increase in the number of newborns who must be placed in intensive care because of pulmonary complications" related to prematurity. 
There are well-established medical reasons for inducing labor before a woman's due date, Dr. Rayburn said in an interview. They include medical problems in the pregnant woman, like diabetes or high blood pressure; pregnancy-related problems, like premature rupture of the membranes that encase the unborn baby, or a placenta that begins to detach from the uterine wall; and fetal problems, like an irregular heartbeat, retarded fetal growth or insufficient amniotic fluid bathing the fetus.
The current ability to detect fetal distress has raised the rates of both labor induction and Caesarean deliveries.
There are also "soft indications" for inducing labor, Dr. Rayburn said. These may include a woman who is overly anxious because of a previous pregnancy problem, a woman who lives very far from the hospital or a woman with a history of rapid delivery who is at risk of giving birth before reaching the hospital. 
When there is a medical reason for inducing labor, the potential benefits greatly outweigh the risks, the experts said. The benefit-to-risk ratio is less clear when the reasons for induction are psychological or social. Some working women, for example, want the convenience of a planned delivery. 
"Obstetrics has become very consumer-driven," Dr. Wing said. "When a woman can't get what she wants from one doctor, she'll go to another, so economics is driving the issue a bit." But she added: "Spontaneous labor is always preferable. The Caesarean section rates are doubled anytime you try to force the process along. You don't know what you will end up with."
Experts also condemned the practice of some doctors to administer an induction agent and send the woman home, telling her to return when labor is well established.
"Inductions should always be done in a hospital and the woman should be monitored continuously for uterine contractions and for the response of the fetal heart rate to those contractions," Dr. Wing said.
Some concern has also been raised about the use and abuse of certain induction agents. The drug most often used for cervical ripening -- the process of softening the cervix that allows it to dilate -- is misoprostol, a prostaglandin marketed as Cytotec. It is approved by the Food and Drug Administration for the treatment of ulcers, not for labor induction, and its use in obstetrics is considered "off label" but legal; once a drug is approved for one purpose, it can be used by doctors for other reasons.
Dr. Rayburn said misoprostol was "very inexpensive and effective, but requires close monitoring to detect changes in the cervix and excessive undesirable uterine activity." This drug sometimes causes uterine contractions that are more frequent and powerful than normal labor and has occasionally resulted in rupture of the uterus, particularly in women who have had previous Caesarean deliveries. 
In August 2000, Searle, which markets Cytotec, cautioned doctors about administering the drug to pregnant women, noting that off-label use of the drug had resulted in reports of uterine rupture, hysterectomy and the death of women and babies. The warning prompted some hospitals to restrict the use of misoprostol for inductions.
Still, it is considered the drug of choice for labor induction, and when given in low doses and coupled with close monitoring, most obstetricians in this country believe it is safe, Dr. Rayburn said. Alternative agents, Cervidil and Prepidil, are much more expensive, he said.
Dr. Rayburn said that more research needed to be done on the circumstances under which inductions were performed and on the effects of induction on cost and long-term health of mothers and babies.
Meanwhile, he added: "There is nothing better than a natural spontaneous labor. Women should exercise patience and not be overly demanding about having their labor induced." When women are considering induction or when their doctors recommend it for nonmedical reasons, he suggested that women get second opinions.

CORRECTION-DATE: January 20, 2003

 CORRECTION:
An article in Science Times on Tuesday about the rising incidence of induced labor misstated the publication date of an article in the journal Obstetrics and Gynecology that cited the trend. It was last year, in July, not this year.

HEADLINE: Front Row 

BYLINE:  By Ruth La Ferla 

 BODY:
Uncertainty in the Meat District
 "Thank heaven, our business is good," Jeffrey Kalinsky declared, his elation almost palpable. Mr. Kalinsky, the owner of Jeffrey New York, a pioneering outpost of hip on West 14th Street, said that his designer-brand shoes and accessories have kept his store aloft, drawing a steady influx of customers to this gritty neighborhood on Manhattan's western rim. 
 In the last year, high-end stores like Stella McCartney and Alexander McQueen have followed, along with newcomers like Scoop, Jussara Lee and RubinChapelle, each setting up shop in the meatpacking district in the hope of thriving as Jeffrey has. Not all, however, will fare as well. 
On a Saturday afternoon this month, prime shopping time for most New Yorkers, foot traffic in the area had thinned to a trickle, an unsettling indication that for fashion retailers, the meatpacking district, its groovy image notwithstanding, leaves a lot to be desired. 
"On weekends, traffic used to be very strong for us," said Laura Mady, a partner in Boucher, a closet-size jewelry boutique on Ninth Avenue. "Now, on a busy day, we might get 30 people." 
Renata Bokalo, an owner of Auto, a three-year-old housewares and fashion accessories store, is also feeling shaky. "We opened in the 90's, when everyone had money, and we did well," Ms. Bokalo said. "Lately, I'm nervous. We are definitely feeling the recession." 
Yvonne Chahine, president of Stella McCartney North America, which is owned by the Gucci Group, was more optimistic, reporting that when the store opened last fall, traffic was great. "We were getting 1,400 or 1,500 customers a day," she said. She maintains that the shop is still healthy but concedes that on a good day, it sees an average of only 350 people.
A slack economy, combined with the falloff in tourism after the World Trade Center attacks, has taken its toll on the neighborhood, and tiny independent fashion boutiques have been the first to feel the pinch. "Tourists used to account for 40 percent of our business," Ms. Mady said. "After 9/11, we lost most of that."
Not all, of course, is gloom. The proximity of tenants like the Milk photography studios and the Sperone Westwater gallery bring out the fashion vanguard, said Laura Pomerantz, a partner in PBS Reality Advisors. But, she added, a trickle of shoppers will not sustain a business that is dependent on foot traffic. "Those businesses may be better off elsewhere," she said. Nevertheless, as she observed, the area draws a "very focused fashion-driven shopper who knows what she wants -- the same type that made SoHo successful years ago." 
Ms. Pomerantz has enough confidence in the area, where rents range from $50 to $80 a square foot, to show it to prospective fashion clients. "The meat district is happening," she said, "but there are going to be some growing pains."

'Make Me Rasta'
Not long ago a young man, a tourist from Poland, sauntered into Dreadlocks Inc., a hair salon on the Lower East Side, gazed at a portrait of Bob Marley on the wall, then wheeled toward the owner. "Make me rasta," he ordered. 
Randi Sabel, the owner of the salon, was not at all taken aback. "These days, my clients come from everywhere," she said. "I've never seen so many people -- Asian, Caucasian, Turkish, even Mexican -- from every type of racial background, asking for dreadlocks. They're back with a vengeance."
As Ms. Sabel spoke, she wrapped tufts of artificial hair into the locks of Vicki Tay. Two years ago, Ms. Tay, a Japanese-American, forsook her pin-straight bob for shoulder-length woolly coils. A window designer for Diesel, Ms. Tay, 24, is one of Ms. Sabel's growing number of Japanese clients. "I've always had an obsession with dreadlocks," Ms. Tay said. "It comes from a passion for the culture." 
Not all fans of locks share that passion. A few blocks uptown, Lior Hermon, 23, a tourist from Israel, stood toying with his caramel-color locks. Was he interested in reggae? "Not really," he said, twirling a 12-inch tendril in his fingers. "These," he said, "they're just a hobby. I play with them all day."
