HEADLINE: City to Resume Recycling Of Plastics 

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL COOPER 

 BODY:
New York City is poised to resume recycling plastic this summer and save a significant amount of money thanks to a New Jersey company's bid to pay the city for its crumpled water bottles and deli containers, city officials said yesterday.
 The Bloomberg administration suspended the recycling of glass and plastic last July, arguing that the program cost too much money -- and yielded too little environmental benefit -- to justify its existence in the current fiscal crisis. 
 But under a compromise reached between the administration and the City Council, the city will resume its plastic-recycling program this July and its glass-recycling program in July 2004. 
The sanitation commissioner, John J. Doherty, said at a City Council hearing yesterday that the city is on target to meet the July deadline for restarting plastic recycling. He added that the city stands to save a significant amount of money compared with the previous program.
Mr. Doherty said the city hopes to sign a contract in the next two months with a small New Jersey recycling company, Hugo Neu Schnitzer East, that has offered to pay the city $5.15 per ton for plastic and metal garbage, instead of charging for the service. Other, bigger garbage firms, he said, wanted to charge the city more that $67 a ton for removing plastic and metal refuse.
"It's very encouraging," Mr. Doherty said of the bid. If the contract goes through, he noted, the city would save more than $70 a ton on plastic recycling. Over all, however, it would still cost the city money: Mr. Doherty said the money the city would get from Hugo Neu Schnitzer East would not be enough to offset the high cost of collecting the plastic. Still, he described the bid as the best offer the city has had since it passed a law requiring recycling in 1989.
City officials said they were confronting a harsh reality when they suspended glass and plastic recycling: they were spending tens of millions of dollars a year for a program that still wound up putting a great deal of refuse into landfills.
But Comptroller William C. Thompson Jr. released a report in December suggesting that the city was not saving as much money by suspending recycling as it had hoped. The report said that since suspending recycling, the Sanitation Department had reduced its garbage-collection runs by less than 2 percent.
The new contract will not earn the city much money. The city collects a little over 100,000 tons of metal and plastic a year, so at $5.15 a ton it would stand to make a little over half a million dollars. The real savings would be that the city would no longer have to pay firms to remove its recyclables. And by taking plastic out of the regular trash collection, the city would no longer have to pay the high price of exporting it, one truck at a time, to out-of-state landfills.
Councilman Michael E. McMahon, a Staten Island Democrat who is chairman of the Council's Sanitation Committee, said the proposal was a win-win deal. "You've got good news for the environment and good news for the economy," he said.
Mark A. Izeman, a lawyer at the Natural Resources Defense Council, a conservation group, said, "In tight budgetary times, it makes perfect sense for the city to seize opportunities like this to begin lowering New York's astronomical waste disposal costs."

HEADLINE: Stimulus for Lawyers 

BYLINE:  By PAUL KRUGMAN; E-mail: krugman@nytimes.com

 BODY:
My colleagues on the editorial page dubbed the Bush administration's proposal to eliminate taxes on corporate dividends "The Charles Schwab Tax Cut." Indeed, the idea seems to have originated in remarks Mr. Schwab made last summer in Waco. But a closer look suggests that it should actually be called the "Tax Complication Act of 2003": it will do little if anything to create jobs in the economy as a whole, but will be a bonanza for tax lawyers and accountants.
 In fact, even some of the lobbyists you would have expected to cheer the plan now believe that it is so complex as to be unworkable. 
 By now you've probably read a lot about the economics of the administration's plan; all the criticisms are true. The plan has nothing to do with stimulus, since less than a dime on the dollar will arrive in the next year. Its benefits are almost ludicrously tilted toward the very, very affluent. (Exercise for readers: Explain how the administration can claim that the average family receives a $1,083 tax cut, when 80 percent of families will receive less than $1,000, most less than $300.)
But you may not be aware of the huge technical problems with the plan's centerpiece, an end to taxes on dividends. 
The slogan was simple enough: "No more double taxation." Corporations, it was said, pay taxes on their profits -- so let's not tax the same income again, when it's paid out as dividends. But the slogan was simplistic. On one hand, in our loophole-ridden system many profitable corporations pay little or no profits tax (and the new plan, by the way, will still leave corporations eager to exploit every loophole they can). On the other hand, retirement accounts, which receive most of the dividends paid to middle-class investors, are already sheltered from taxes.
A simple end to dividend taxation, then, would be a blatant giveaway to the rich: it would allow some wealthy investors to pay no taxes at all. That's too much, even for the Bush administration. 
So the actual plan is much more complicated: Dividends will be tax-free only if the company that pays them is deemed to have paid sufficient profits taxes. 
That's only a minor complication, but it gets worse. Companies that reinvest their profits complained about the plan. So there's another fix: when companies choose not to pay the allowed amount of tax-free dividends, the dividends not paid will be counted against capital gains for stockholders, reducing their taxes when they sell the stock. This makes sense, sort of; but it means that individual taxpayers will have to maintain elaborate records, and it also opens substantial new possibilities for abuse.
Are you confused? So are the experts. 
For 90 percent of Americans, none of this matters, because they will get little or nothing from the dividend tax exemption anyway. But among the minority who might expect to gain, many will find their tax cut chewed up by fees for lawyers and accountants.
The really big question, however, is what this will do to tax collection. 
Bear in mind that the I.R.S. is already severely overstretched; for years Congress has starved the agency of resources, and officials privately concede that it is doing an increasingly poor job of policing tax evasion. Yet if a dividend tax exemption will make it complicated to file taxes, it will also make it harder -- much harder -- for the I.R.S. to enforce the rules. Tax lawyers are already devising schemes to exploit the many new loopholes the plan would create. 
So here's a prediction: If the dividend tax exemption is put into effect, the rules that supposedly prevent abuse -- that prevent wealthy individuals from avoiding any taxation at all -- will be subject to extensive evasion. Will the I.R.S. get the resources it needs to police that evasion? Don't be silly. So both the true budget costs of the plan and its tilt toward the wealthy will be bigger than even the harshest critics now assert.
It's tempting to attribute this mess to sheer incompetence: George W. Bush liked what Charles Schwab said, and nobody dared tell the emperor the truth about his wardrobe. But maybe the mess is deliberate. Is this just another clever step on the way to a system in which only the little people pay taxes? 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: BUSINESS TRAVEL: ON THE ROAD; 
How One Air Commuter Made the Sky a Classroom

BYLINE:  By Joe Sharkey; On the Road appears each Tuesday. E-mail: jsharkey@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
"I JUST put my headphones on and put in the CD-ROM. I would also do a lot of reading on the plane. Sometimes I'd even manage to write a complete paper. It was a practical way for me to spend my time," said Morgan Hezlep.
 Easy for her to say. Ms. Hezlep, 31, is one of those industrious people you sometimes see on planes -- the ones who actually manage to get work done in an airline seat. 
 She is so good at working on planes that she got her college degree while commuting cross-country for over two years, from San Diego to Boston. Thus she is a role model for those of us who give up in despair on the idea of using our laptops the minute the big fat guy in the aisle ahead cranks his seat all the way down into our tray tables.
"I started off always flying coach, and I managed to do the course work and get things in on time," said Ms. Hezlep, who is now in law school in San Diego after completing her bachelor of science degree last May. "I'm a petite person, so I basically fit in a coach seat and have just enough room to work, even if the seat in front is reclined all the way. I usually found a way to use my laptop and prop up a book." 
In late 1999, with only a handful of college credits under her belt, Ms. Hezlep decided to complete her degree while continuing to work as an Internet-technology specialist in the medical industry. Her company, in Southern California, assigned her to work with a client in Boston, the Dana Farber Cancer Center.
Not wanting to move to Boston, she decided to wing it after discovering that she could get her degree through an online degree program from St. Leo University near Tampa, Fla. It is affiliated with the University Alliance network operated by Bisk Education Inc. and allows adults to pursue college studies long-distance while continuing their careers. Lectures are on videodiscs and online, and tests and teacher consultations are conducted on the Internet.
Early in January 2000, Ms. Hezlep started both a new job and a new college.
Two and a half years later, having bagged about half a million frequent-flier miles and a couple of hundred hours of academic credits, she got her degree in computer information systems just about the time the contract in Boston had ended.
"I was strictly a United flier," she said. After a few months into her cross-country odyssey, she had logged enough frequent-flier miles to start qualifying for regular upgrades from steerage to either Economy Plus -- the higher-cost seats with a little more legroom in the front of the coach cabins on United Airlines flights -- and even occasionally to first or business class.
The drill required heads-up planning. Laptop batteries had to be charged before the weekend commutes. Since classwork and exams were usually due on Sunday nights, scheduling was especially crucial on the weekly Sunday morning flights from San Diego to Boston, with connections in Chicago or Denver.
"You're behind three hours before you start, naturally," she said. "I got to know my airports, including where to hole up in a corner and work on layovers and through weather or mechanical delays. Finally, I joined United's Red Carpet Club, so I could have a guaranteed place to use my laptop and get e-mail."
Security-screening delays that snarled airports after the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11, 2001, added new challenges because "any time you spent waiting in line was not productive time," she said.
What about that bane of the young female flier, the overly chatty (usually male) seatmate?
Slipping in the male pronoun with subtlety, Ms. Hezlep acknowledged: "Sometimes the person beside me would see the software on my screen, or see me doing work on the laptop and consulting a book, and he would say, like, 'Oh, you're going to school? That must really be hard on an airplane.' You'd try to accommodate them and reply politely and then go back to your work, but still you're thinking, Can't you tell that I'm studying?"
In dealing with true serial-chatters, sometimes the only polite way to get some peace was to wait for food to arrive. "This didn't happen often, but when it did, there was always the opportunity. When they served the meal, he would finally stop talking to start eating," she said. "I would forgo the meal myself and use the opportunity to study, and then as his tray was being cleared away, I would feign going to sleep myself till he dozed off. Then I'd be able to work again." Sympathetic flight attendants, who miss nothing, would sometimes slip her snacks.
"I have to admit there were times I complained to myself" about the drudgery, "but the truth is I thrived on it," she said.
For business travelers who do try to work on planes, even if they're not grinding out a college degree, conditions have been worsening lately.
On some airlines, upgrades are harder to obtain. With fewer planes in the skies as airlines shrink schedules, some flights are more crowded than ever. Worse, in a growing trend, many airlines are using more 50-seat regional jets on routes once served by full-size airliners. As the airline consultant Michael Boyd notes in a list of predictions for 2003 in his current weekly newsletter (www .aviationplanning.com): "From an ergonomic standpoint, these are not aircraft well-suited to long-haul passenger service. There's a limit to human endurance."
Ms. Hezlep said she did her best to achieve a degree of comfort under challenging circumstances, but she would not want to try it again under current conditions. "I consider myself to be pretty organized, and I can fake it pretty well when I'm not. But I'm very glad I did it when I did," she said.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS TRAVEL; 
Frequent Flier to Rental Driver Has Its Price

BYLINE:  By DAVID JONES 

 BODY:
Hertz, the world's leading rental car provider, has quietly begun imposing a modest fee on customers who want to collect frequent-flier miles, a move that some experts say could help it recoup millions of dollars in marketing costs.
 Avis Rent a Car has decided to follow suit, and several other major rental-car companies are considering doing the same. And one major player is even thinking about pulling out of some airline frequent-flier programs altogether. 
 Though Hertz's new surcharge, which it began on Oct. 1, is only 50 cents a day, up to a maximum of $2 per rental, it is the latest sign of the rental-car industry's struggle to stay profitable amid a severe business slump. It is also likely to cause grumbling by business travelers, who believe they are being nickel-and-dimed by companies that are loath to raise prices directly. 
Similarly, while airlines and big corporations are grudgingly accepting the move as a fait accompli, they are not happy about it.
Aside from supplying badly needed revenue for Hertz, the surcharge can also be viewed as a sign of declining confidence in airline mileage programs from a once prominent customer that would not have dared do this in the boom days, when airline mileage offers were in avid demand by hotel, car rental and other retail customers.
"The cost of participating in these programs is a significant drain on profitability" for rental companies, "even more so now when general volume is down," said Neil Abrams, president of the Abrams Consulting Group, a firm in Purchase, N.Y., that specializes in the rent-a-car industry.
Hertz, a subsidiary of Ford Motor, says the new fee is only one of several tough financial decisions it has been forced to take because of weak demand since the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks. Last April, Hertz eliminated base commissions paid to travel agents for certain car rentals made with corporations and government agencies, though not those with other business customers or leisure travelers.
Richard Broome, a spokesman for Hertz, which is based in Park Ridge, N.J., said that the company believed that airline frequent-flier programs were a legitimate cost item that needed to be reviewed. Hertz, like other rental-car concerns, pays a fee for every mile a frequent flier collects from an individual rental. Mr. Broome would not discuss how much money Hertz pays to participate in frequent-flier programs, though American Airlines officials say the general rate for frequent-flier partners is about 2.2 cents a mile. Under many airline agreements, a frequent-flier accrues a minimum of 50 miles a day.
Hertz had worldwide rental car revenue of $3.8 billion in 2001 and, according to industry experts, books millions of rental-car transactions a year. Avis, the second-largest airport rental-car company in the United States, with 21 percent of the market, books about 16 million rental-car transactions a year.
With costs rising faster than rental rates, Mr. Broome said, Hertz had to find additional revenue and believed that it was fairer to impose the 50-cent-a-day fee on the one-third of its customers who collect frequent-flier points than to impose a surcharge on everybody. Airline customers represent 90 percent of Hertz's business, and Hertz has about 28 percent of the American airport rental-car market, according to Abrams Travel Data.
Already, several of Hertz's rivals have either decided to duplicate its move or are considering doing so. The Cendant Car Rental Group, based in Parsippany, N.J., which operates Avis, decided last week to impose a fee on customers who take part in its frequent-flier airline loyalty programs, though it has not yet determined the amount or the starting date, according to Ted Deutsch, a Cendant spokesman. He said Avis officials spent several weeks discussing the fee with various airline partners and determined that it would have to take steps to remain competitive with Hertz and other rental companies.
He said a similar plan would probably be put into effect at Budget Rent a Car, which Cendant acquired last year, though a final decision has not been made. "I think the different travel industry companies recognize we're in a pretty dynamic environment," Mr. Deutsch said. "It doesn't signify that we're valuing those relationships less. Our success is very tied into the success of the airline business."
ANC Rental, based in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., and the parent of National Car Rental and Alamo Rent a Car, is considering whether to impose a similar fee, and says it might even go a step further by pulling out of some airline frequent-flier programs. ANC, which is operating under Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection, said it was meeting with its 14 airline frequent-flier partners as well as 30 corporate travel accounts to determine which direction it will go.
One exception to the trend is the Dollar Thrifty Automotive Group, which says it has no plans to match the fee.
The big rental-car companies first began offering customers points for airline frequent-flier clubs in the 1980's as a way to lure them away from cheaper rivals and to keep them loyal. The strategy worked at first, but as the low end of the industry took up the practice, the competitive edge was lost. "It was a matter of time," said Mr. Abrams of Abrams Consulting and a former Hertz executive.
Most of Hertz's airline partners grudgingly agreed to accept the fee after several months of negotiations, Mr. Broome said, though American Airlines, the nation's largest airline, refused.
"We thought it was philosophically against what we thought was the right thing to do to charge Advantage members for miles," said Tim Kincaid, a spokesman for American, which has 45 million frequent-flier members of American AAdvantage.
Instead of the new fee, American allowed Hertz to change the accrual rate for AAdvantage members to one mileage point for every $2 spent, compared with the previous one-to-one ratio. Officials at Delta Air Lines, the nation's third-largest carrier, said the new fees would not have any impact on its relationships with the rental-car companies.
Some frequent business travelers expressed frustration that they would have to pay for a program that was initially created to attract new customers. "I thought the point of these programs was to build loyalty," said Robin Bechtel, a frequent flier who manages communications for the North American Insulation Manufacturers Association in Alexandria, Va. Big corporations, which have been reducing travel expenses in a sputtering economy, generally view the new fees as the latest annoyance in a series of charges slipped in by service providers.
Curt Mattos, director of travel services at Charles Schwab in San Francisco, said his firm had a preferred-supplier contract with Avis and that he would try to renegotiate if his company had to pay another fee.
"There is work to be done in our business on creating a new revenue model, rather than continually sticking it to consumers," Mr. Mattos said.
Hertz officials say the new policy has not led to a loss of market share or caused a significant number of complaints from business travelers or corporate travel managers, though Hertz acknowledges it worried about those risks.
"You know that most of those fees are not fees that we'd like to impose," Mr. Broome said.

HEADLINE: G.O.P. Pledges an Effort on Race 

BYLINE:  By LYNETTE CLEMETSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 

 BODY:
In an effort to improve the Republican Party's image among African-Americans, party leaders agreed today to set benchmarks for the party to gauge how well it is doing in grooming black candidates, hiring black staff members and acting on issues of concern to black voters.
 They also promised to adopt a scorecard, to be vetted by black party advisers, to chart the party's progress on race-related issues. 
 The promises were made in a closed-door meeting at the offices of the Republican National Committee with more than a dozen black Republican business, political and religious leaders, as a way to mend fences after the December controversy surrounding Senator Trent Lott and his glowing remarks about Senator Strom Thurmond's segregationist campaign for president in 1948.
"What we've realized out of that painful moment is that we have a unique opportunity to implement real change," said Marc Racicot, chairman of the Republican National Committee, who attended the meeting along with Senator Bill Frist, the new majority leader. "This was the start of a broader discussion, a way to inventory the things we are doing right and those things we need to do better." 
Though meant to signal a fresh start on racial issues, the meeting could not escape some nagging grievances of the past. Just last week, one of the meeting's attendees, Shannon Reeves, the secretary of the California state party, accused Republican leaders of using blacks as "window dressing" to cover for racists within their ranks.
Mr. Reeves's statement, sent by e-mail to party members, was prompted by the disclosure that the vice chairman of the California Republican Party, Bill Back, included in a 1999 edition of his newsletter an essay written by a conservative research analyst suggesting that the country would have been better off had the South won the Civil War. 
Mr. Back, who has said he "strongly disagreed" with the essay, is running for state party chairman. Mr. Reeves has called on him to drop his bid.
Mr. Reeves did not raise his protest of Mr. Back's candidacy at today's meeting. "It wasn't my meeting, so I yielded to the leadership," he said. But he said he did address the general issue of what he called "recurrent obstacles" faced by black Republicans. 
"When you withstand the things we do as black Republicans, and you still stand firm with the party, that's commitment," said Mr. Reeves, who is also president of the N.A.A.C.P. chapter in Oakland, Calif. "It's time for the party to recognize that and consider our advice very carefully."
The meeting included presentations on issues including building bridges to black churches and business owners. Robert J. Brown, a marketing executive, spoke of a pamphlet he uses with corporate clients about how to avoid racial slurs and code words and suggested that the Republican party run workshops on eliminating incendiary language from its speech. 
Another theme at the two-hour session, those who attended said, was encouraging party leaders to call on black members to represent the party on a broad variety of issues.
"The Republican Party has to change its apparatus from the grass-roots level on up," said Armstrong Williams, a syndicated columnist who organized today's meeting. "When the issue is war or the economic stimulus package, we need to be in on those meetings and out there representing the party's positions. Don't just call us when the issue is race." 
For all the tense topics on the agenda, participants said, there was also acknowledgment of strides the party has made. Mr. Williams noted that more than 25 percent of high-ranking officials in the Bush administration are black. 
Participants also praised the contributions by Dr. Frist, who owes his leadership position to the gaffe by Mr. Lott.
"He was very involved, asking for specific suggestions, wanting to know if he could call and ask our advice on how to implement changes," Mr. Reeves said of Dr. Frist. 
Democrats have been quick to dismiss the Republicans' new efforts at reaching out.
On the floor of the Senate today, Senator Tom Daschle, the Democratic leader, said that with Dr. Frist's new leadership, "there may have been a change of face, but there has not been a change of heart." 

GRAPHIC: Photo: Armstrong Williams, a columnist, left, Senator Bill Frist, the majority leader, and Marc Racicot, chairman of the Republican National Committee, at a break in a meeting of black and Republican leaders yesterday. (Stephen Crowley/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: SHAKE-UP AT AOL: THE INTERNET; 
Resignation May Help Ground a Visionary Medium

BYLINE:  By AMY HARMON 

 BODY:
Anyone checking e-mail on AOL these days will probably be confronted with multiple entreaties to try the company's broadband service, the keystone of America Online's new determination to charge a premium for online information and entertainment.
 If there is symbolic meaning to Stephen M. Case's decision to step down as chairman of the world's largest media company this week, it may lie in the message underscored by the insistent marketing: it is time for the online service to start pulling its own weight. 
 Mr. Case, an archetypal Internet visionary, became famous for his grand notions of how the infant online medium would change the world. But even as many of those visions achieved degrees of reality over the last decade, the online industry is still struggling to turn them into a viable business. 
At AOL Time Warner and dozens of other media companies, tolerance for talk of digital revolutions and electronic frontiers has long since worn thin.
And investors, no longer willing to coddle a not-so-new technology, are pressing for Internet companies and the online divisions of media conglomerates to be held to a grown-up standard of profitability. 
Analysts note that self-appointed Internet visionaries at other media companies, like Jean-Marie Messier at Vivendi Universal and Thomas Middelhoff at Bertelsmann, have already been ousted as their boards acted upon investor unrest. 
"We're at the point where media companies are realizing, 'We can't subsidize our online operations ad infinitum; they have to start paying their way,' " said Jonathan Gaw, an Internet analyst at the market research firm IDC. "Steve Case clung to the vision and didn't pay enough attention to the practicalities." 
Most Internet companies, including AOL, became a lot more practical after the stock boom ended. In many ways, Mr. Case's departure is simply the culmination of a process that began when the AOL service began to drag down AOL Time Warner's share price nearly two years ago. 
In some ways, AOL's problems are a legacy of its own practice of giving away easy-to-use disks that provided Internet access to anyone with a computer, modem and telephone line. And for years, the online service benefited from the rapid acquisition of customers for its dial-up service, on which it had a healthy profit margin. But more recently, the migration of many subscribers to faster broadband services has meant that the company will make less money for each subscriber, unless it can persuade them to pay an additional fee for exclusive online access to its content -- in many cases material from other AOL Time Warner properties, like Time magazine and Warner Music. 
But in some important respects, analysts say that AOL's problems are also emblematic of the Internet industry as a whole. As a social phenomenon, the Internet has been a big, big hit. An ever-growing number of users -- in 103 million United States households, according to Odyssey Research -- sign onto the Internet to e-mail one another and to find information on almost any conceivable subject. But few seem willing to pay for anything other than access to their e-mail. 
"The Internet transforms the way the world works, that is true," said Harold L. Vogel, a media analyst and author of "Entertainment Industry Economics."
"The question," he said, "is how do you make money on it, and that is still unanswered." 
As in any industry after a period of rapid growth, companies like AOL are facing market saturation and slowing subscriber growth -- although the online industry has reached a plateau in an unusually short period. The standard approach to coping with the maturation phase of a business life cycle, economists say, is to innovate by reducing costs and improving quality. But the economics of the Internet may leave little room for that. 
"With the Internet, the normal life-cycle problems are compounded," said Ari Ginsberg, a professor of entrepreneurship at New York University's Stern School of Business. "You've got a customer that's already not accepting very much cost. How do you improve quality and charge a decent price?" 
Moreover, some industry analysts argue that while people may well pay cable television companies for on-demand movies, the Internet has never been about mainstream media, and perhaps never will be. In other words, one of the main rationales for the merger of AOL and Time Warner might have been a fallacy. 
"Most people don't go online to see Warner movies or read Time Life magazines or watch CNN," said Vin Crosbie, managing partner of Digital Deliverance, a consulting firm. "They go online to communicate with one another and find information and content of interest to them that they can't get from mass media." 
And yet, there are signs that Mr. Case's long-held dreams of digital convergence may ultimately be borne out -- whether or not on America Online's terms. Innovation, some analysts argue, is already taking place with high-speed Internet access and entertainment increasingly being delivered in digital form.
Consumers spent $43 billion in online retail sales last year, according to comScore Networks, an Internet research firm. Nearly 20 million homes have broadband connections to the Internet. And online advertising, while still small, is growing at a much faster rate than cable television advertising did in its first few years, noted Michael Zimbalist, executive director of the Online Publisher's Association, a consortium of companies that includes Tribune Interactive and New York Times Digital. 
"The if-you-build-it-they-will-come mentality has certainly been completely tempered by a pragmatic business approach to investment," Mr. Zimbalist said. "But look at this unbelievable shift in consumer behavior. If the Internet had only been treated as an interesting sidelight for the past seven years, that never would have happened."

HEADLINE: City for Rent 

BYLINE:  By Christopher Hawthorne; Christopher Hawthorne is a contributing editor at Metropolis magazine.

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO 

 BODY:
After four years on the East Coast, my wife and I have returned to the San Francisco Bay Area, where both of us grew up. While we were in New York waiting out the dot-com boom, San Francisco had been transformed into an unrecognizably frenzied place where jobs were plentiful but apartments were not. From friends who stayed behind, we heard stories about open houses in which apartment hunters showed up early, dressed well and clutched leather-bound folders holding their credit reports, checkbooks, pay stubs -- even renters' resumes, listing their references and touting their monk-like living habits.
 I knew it couldn't last. The people who came during the boom came for the jobs, not for the city. Sure enough, with the local economy limping along now -- employment in the Bay Area fell by 87,000 people last year -- the scene here is drastically different. 
 On a recent Sunday afternoon, I visited six open houses and saw a total of 11 apartments. I crossed paths with exactly one other prospective tenant, a guy in his 30's who said he was waiting to be "wowed" before he committed to a place. As a forlorn landlord told me that day, three or four years ago anybody could get a job here but nobody could find a place to live. Now the opposite is true.
The residential vacancy rate, which dropped as low as 1 percent during the boom, has climbed to about 7 percent. The average rental price for a two-bedroom, one-bathroom apartment in larger complexes in San Francisco has fallen by more than $650 a month over the last two years, to $1,930 from $2,597. (Meanwhile, rents in Los Angeles County rose in the third quarter of 2002 by 3 percent, the largest quarterly increase in two years.)
The number of San Francisco apartment listings on the popular Web site Craig's List, a sort of Internet bazaar, has jumped about ten fold since the fall of 2000. Bay Area apartment ads on the site, which trailed city job listings in daily volume as recently as two years ago, now outnumber them by about six to one.
Landlords have responded to sagging demand by borrowing strategies from car dealers and appliance salespeople -- offering cash rebates of several hundred dollars and other move-in bonuses. Recently one landlord advertised a $500 rebate and a free DVD player or microwave (tenant's choice) upon lease signing. Another countered with a $200 Ikea gift certificate.
My own day of lonely apartment-hopping began in the Marina district, on the northern edge of the city. In one building I wandered through three empty apartments. A flyer was taped to the wall in each place in which the original rental price had been crossed out and a lower number scrawled in the margin. A little later, on a busy stretch of Bay Street, a landlord told me that the two-bedroom apartment he was now having trouble filling at $2,000 a month used to rent for $2,500. The previous tenants were dot-commers, he said. Though they had lost their jobs several months before, it had taken a few months for them to face reality and move out.
That lag time is one reason rental prices continue to fall more than a year after the Bay Area economy appeared to hit bottom.The last dot-com holdouts are finally cutting their losses now and moving into cheaper, smaller apartments or back in with their parents -- or leaving the city altogether. The result, though painful for landlords right now, can only be good for San Francisco in the long term. This is a city that has always attracted dreamers, but instead of fly-by-night entrepreneurs we need newcomers for whom the city itself is actually part of the dream.

HEADLINE: State Can't Afford to Let Court System Remain Inefficient, New York's Chief Judge Says 

BYLINE:  By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr. 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 13 

 BODY:
After 10 years at the helm of the state's highest court, Judge Judith S. Kaye said today that she felt a sense of frustration and urgency over the Legislature's failure to streamline the state's court system.
 Judge Kaye has called again and again for a reorganization of the New York trial courts, but in this year's annual address on the state of the judiciary she cast her argument in economic terms, saying the current, cumbersome system cannot be afforded in such hard fiscal times. 
 "We need to simplify our byzantine court structure, a maze of 11 separate trial courts, each with its own separate jurisdictional universe," said Judge Kaye, the chief judge of the Court of Appeals. "We need to eliminate the costly, incomprehensible barriers and inefficiencies." 
Judge Kaye, 64, also took the Legislature to task for not raising the fees of court-appointed defense lawyers for 17 years. The pay of $40 an hour for work in court and $25 an hour for work outside court has discouraged many lawyers from volunteering for such assignments, leading to needless delays and shoddy representation for the poor, she said.
"It's terrible for clients, terrible for the courts, terrible for all of us, terrible for society," she said.
Judge Kaye sprinkled her hourlong address with several announcements. She said people would now be able to pay fines through the mail, rather than going to court, for minor offenses like illegal fishing or walking with an open beer. She also announced that people can now pay court-imposed settlements with a credit card.
In keeping with her longtime push to make the judiciary more efficient through administrative changes, Judge Kaye said she would expand a pilot program that consolidates under a single judge various cases relating to the domestic violence troubles of an individual family. The project created four Integrated Domestic Violence Courts, which deal with divorce proceedings, criminal trials, protection orders and custody cases. Within three years, all domestic violence cases would be handled in a similar manner, Judge Kaye said.
She said she had developed a plan with Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg to place an additional eight judges on the overburdened Family Court in New York City, increasing that bench to 55 judges from 47.
Addressing elections of judges, Judge Kaye said she was forming a commission, headed by John D. Feerick, the former dean of Fordham Law School, to look into ways to make judicial elections less partisan and to reduce the no-holds-barred style of electioneering that allows judicial candidates to mislead voters about their opponents. She said Mr. Feerick would also investigate public financing for judicial campaigns.
"Judges' campaigns are not like other people's campaigns," she said after her speech, adding that judicial candidates should meet standards that are higher than customary in politics.
Also high on Judge Kaye's list of priorities for this year is an effort to determine why more than 80 percent of people called for jury service are never put on a jury. She said she would form another commission to investigate ways to improve that record.
"What a waste of time," she said. "What a waste of dollars."
Since 1997, Judge Kaye has submitted to the Legislature various versions of a constitutional amendment that would reorganize the state's trial courts from top to bottom, but none have passed. The latest version would condense eight of the courts into one tier.
For the plan to succeed, the Legislature would first have to pass the amendment in two consecutive sessions. Voters would then have to approve it. In her speech, Judge Kaye argued that the proposal would save at least $131 million, a sum some lawmakers dispute.
Judge Kaye also announced that she would commission the Nelson A. Rockefeller Institute of Government at the State University of New York at Albany to analyze by year's end just how much money could be saved by streamlining the courts.
"Hopefully, this study, at long last, will provide impetus for the necessary legislative relief that has so long eluded us," she said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Judith S. Kaye, chief judge of the New York State Court of Appeals, before her address yesterday in Albany. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Testing Group Ends Effort To Make Profit on Web Site 

BYLINE:  By TAMAR LEWIN 

 BODY:
The College Board is abandoning a highly publicized foray into the for-profit world after raising $30 million to establish one of the most popular education-related sites on the Internet.
 The board, which administers the Scholastic Assessment Tests, had hoped that the for-profit venture, collegeboard.com, would grow into a major educational resource on the World Wide Web, financed largely by advertisers with a wide variety of commercial links for things like opening a bank account or buying and selling dorm-room furniture. 
 The board's president, Gaston Caperton, said the board had bought out the outside investors and intended to fold the Web site back into the parent organization's nonprofit operations. 
"We didn't have the capital to compete in a field where there was a lot of competition," said Mr. Caperton, a former governor of West Virginia who became president of the College Board in July 1999. 
But he added that the venture had paid off by helping the College Board enter the Internet age. "Without that outside investment, we would have been left behind."
In fact, collegeboard.com leads the pack, attracting far more hits and business than the education sites run by the Princeton Review, ACT, Peterson's and others. It offers extensive information about colleges and financial aid, study tips, study aids, and the opportunity to register for the SAT reasoning, Advanced Placement and SAT subject tests online. About two million students -- two-thirds of those who take the tests -- use online registration. In October alone, there were more than 32 million college searches on the site. 
It has been far less successful financially. The site is only now approaching the break-even point, and with the bursting of the Internet bubble, Mr. Caperton said, the for-profit venture ceased to make sense. 
"The investors didn't push me or anything, but we recognized that there was not going to be the opportunity for capital return that they'd expected," he said, "and it became clear to me that the best thing was to buy it back."
As governor of West Virginia, Mr. Caperton won praise for bringing computers into the schools. But in 1999, when he announced that he would bring the stodgy 100-year-old College Board into the highflying world of Internet start-ups, there was widespread concern that the move would lead to increased commercialization of education. 
Occasionally, the site has been an aggressive marketer: last fall, for example, students who registered for College Board tests online received a tantalizing e-mail message announcing that their scores were available online but that to see them early, they would have to pay $13. After a barrage of criticism, the College Board dropped those messages.
"We made a mistake, and when it came to my attention, I was embarrassed, and we stopped," Mr. Caperton said. "And while people had great fears at the beginning, especially about the advertising, I think there is a general agreement now that this is a very useful site that really helps students get the information they need.
While the College Board is retreating to its nonprofit roots, the other testing giant, the Educational Testing Service, has been moving toward a corporate model since Kurt Landgraf, a former DuPont executive, became president two years ago.
E.T.S., which designs the College Board tests, now recruits heavily from the corporate world, pays corporate-style bonuses and derives a growing portion of its revenue from a wholly owned for-profit subsidiary, the Chauncey Group International. The subsidiary specializes in certification for corporate, military and government groups, including nursing and cosmetology licensing exams and Microsoft certification tests.
"The Chauncey Group has revenues of about $85 million, up from about $25 million just a couple of years ago, and we're in the process of acquiring a public company, with e-business with Internet capability, that will increase its size by 25 percent," Mr. Landgraf said. "While the College Board continues to be our largest and most valued client, representing about 20 percent of our $850 million total business, from a gross revenue point of view, it's less dominant than it used to be. E.T.S. is diversifying into a whole variety of areas."
E.T.S.'s other wholly owned for-profit subsidiary, ETS Technologies, a business focused on automated essay-scoring, is being closed and will be folded back into the nonprofit organization later this year. 
Both Mr. Landgraf and Mr. Caperton say that while their organizations are following diverging paths, they remain comfortably linked. 
Indeed, the two men are completing negotiations on a new five-year contract, under which E.T.S. will continue to create the College Board tests, and the College Board will continue to administer them.
Some adjustments are in the works, though. Under the new contract, the College Board will reclaim several tasks, including marketing the tests, finding and paying the proctors and providing customer service.
"We want to be able to serve our customers ourselves, letting E.T.S. focus more on what they're best in the world at, which is creating tests," Mr. Caperton said.

HEADLINE: THREATS AND RESPONSES: ASIA; 
AIDES DECLARE U.S. 'WILLING TO TALK' IN KOREA DISPUTE

BYLINE:  By HOWARD W. FRENCH 

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, Jan. 13 

 BODY:
Faced with narrow options for dealing with North Korea and strained ties with South Korea, a senior Bush administration delegation signaled its willingness today to pursue dialogue to resolve the nuclear crisis on the Korean peninsula.
 While stressing its desire to listen closely to the views of the incoming South Korean president, Roh Moo Hyun, the delegation, led by James A. Kelly, the assistant secretary of state for East Asian and Pacific affairs, made the most conciliatory sounds from the United States toward North Korea heard after weeks of rising tensions. 
 In a news conference here today, Mr. Kelly even contemplated economic assistance to the impoverished dictatorship once its nuclear weapons programs were ended. 
"We are of course willing to talk," he said. "Once we get beyond nuclear weapons, there may be opportunities with the U.S., with private investors, with other countries to help North Korea in the energy area."
Mr. Kelly's language, both on North Korea and in his discussions with Mr. Roh, reflected a delicate balancing act in which Washington, preoccupied with Iraq and confronted with unappealing military options in Korea, has been nudged back from a position of unwillingness to engage with the North.
Mr. Roh, a political disciple of the incumbent president, Kim Dae Jung, campaigned on the need for continued dialogue with the North and was sharply critical of what he called Mr. Bush's hard-line approach to the country.
His camp was boosted by a strong wave of anti-American protests here, and diplomats say the Americans' giving in to the president-elect's insistence that South Korea play a leading role in shaping allied policy toward North Korea may be the price of maintaining the health of the 50-year-old alliance between Washington and Seoul. 
Today, after a one-hour meeting with Mr. Kelly, Mr. Roh said, "The South Korea-U.S. alliance was precious, is now still precious and will continue to be important in the future."
Mr. Roh's spokesman, Lee Nak Yon, also quoted the president-elect as saying: "We now need the United States Forces Korea, and the U.S.F.K. will also be necessary in the future. I hope that the United States will remain our ally in the future."
Mr. Kelly, speaking to reporters after the meeting, called the election of Mr. Roh "a great opportunity to improve, to build upon the alliance for the next 50 years." 
Spokesmen for Mr. Roh said the president-elect had expressed concerns to Mr. Kelly about reported United States plans for sanctions against North Korea for ending international surveillance of nuclear power plants suspected of being used for its atomic weapons programs. One spokesman for Mr. Roh said Mr. Kelly had assured him that neither sanctions against North Korea nor a military attack were currently being contemplated in Washington. 
When Mr. Roh, a labor lawyer, was an activist in this country's democracy movement two decades ago, he advocated the outright withdrawal of the 37,000 American troops stationed in South Korea. The tenor of his comments today, however, is a far cry even from comments attributed to him last week.
"Although we don't know if it might take 10, 20 or 30 years, someone has to consider an independent defense," Mr. Roh was quoted as saying at that time by the newspaper JoongAng Ilbo. "Senior military officials have to prepare a plan for a special emergency situation when the U.S. Army moves away." 
Aides to Mr. Roh have expressed concern recently over the potential for a badly strained start to relations with the Bush administration and were eager to send a friendly and businesslike message to Washington even before the new government here takes office in February.
Along those lines, a senior aide to Mr. Roh said the president-elect planned to visit United States troops before his inauguration, in a gesture of recognition of their importance for the defense of this country.
Members of Mr. Roh's transition team said Mr. Kelly's delegation had pressed for the earliest possible visit of the new South Korean leader to Washington after his inauguration on Feb. 25. But mindful of the strains between the outgoing president, Mr. Kim, and the Bush administration, which many say date to a poorly prepared visit to Washington shortly after Mr. Bush's inauguration, Mr. Roh's aides sounded cautious.
"I think President Kim's visit with President Bush gave us a lesson, and there is more homework to be done between the teams," a senior transition aide said. "We are not going to have a repetition of the visit between Mr. Kim and Mr. Bush. Hopefully it will be much more productive. Our hands are full right now with the deteriorating nuclear issues, and there must be close coordination."
The United States has said North Korea must dismantle its nuclear programs before there can be any talks about aid and improved ties.
The White House spokesman, Ari Fleischer, said today that North Korea's weapons dismantling must be "verifiable" and "irreversible."
"North Korea wants to take the world through its blackmail playbook, and we won't play," he said. "It's up to North Korea to come back into international compliance with their obligations."
North Korea indicated today for the first time that it might reconsider its withdrawal last week from the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty.
Pak Ui Chun, North Korea's ambassador to Russia, said at a news conference in Moscow that his nation could rejoin the pact if its demands were met for changes in inspections by the International Atomic Energy Agency. 
His remarks, though laced with invective against the United States, appeared to open the door for a negotiated solution to the confrontation. 
"This issue should be resolved taking into account the situation that has taken shape after North Korea's withdrawal from the treaty," Mr. Pak said, according to the Interfax news agency.

HEADLINE: History Channel in Deal With School System 

 BODY:
The History Channel is forming a partnership with the city's school system to provide added resources for teaching history.
 The partnership will be formally announced today by Caroline Kennedy, the school system's new chief executive of the Office of Strategic Partnerships, and Dan Davids, executive vice president of the History Channel. 
 The company, based in New York, will help develop curriculum for the Tweed Academy program at the Department of Education's downtown headquarters.
Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has said he hopes to bring students from all over the city to the Tweed Courthouse for lessons in New York City's government, economics and history. 
Although the History Channel has sponsored smaller projects in schools elsewhere, this is the first large-scale effort with a school system, officials said. 
About 300 schools will get a video library with programs focusing on the city, like documentaries on building the Empire State Building and the Brooklyn Bridge. 
"If you love history and have a nice teacher and a good textbook, that's about all you need," said Libby O'Connell, who is in charge of the History Channel's education department and will help to develop the curriculum for the city. "But a lot of 13-year-old kids don't get excited about history."
The channel will also provide three $1,000 grants for history teachers and three $1,000 student scholarships for students especially interested in history.

HEADLINE: Lieberman Announces Run For the White House in '04 

BYLINE:  By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

DATELINE: STAMFORD, Conn., Jan. 13 

 BODY:
Senator Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut, who rose to national prominence as Al Gore's running mate two years ago, announced his own campaign for president today, declaring that the "American dream is in jeopardy" because of threats of domestic terrorism and the economic policies of President Bush. 
 With his announcement, delivered 22 months before Election Day at his former high school in this suburb 35 miles north of New York City, Mr. Lieberman became the first Democrat to declare unequivocally that he was running for president in 2004. He did it with a relatively brief but hard-hitting speech in which he portrayed Mr. Bush's White House as relentlessly partisan and Mr. Bush's policies as a threat to the security and economic well-being of the nation's middle class. 
 "Today, unfortunately, that American dream is in jeopardy, threatened by hate-filled terrorists and tyrants from abroad, and a weak economy that makes it harder for people to live a better life here at home," he said. "For too many Americans, the middle class of which I've spoken is drifting out of reach." 
He said the president had failed to do enough to protect the nation against further terrorist attacks. The president's policies, he said, are too often "driven by extreme ideologues in the administration or major financial interests." He pledged that as president he would raise the nation "above partisan politics and put our country first."
Mr. Lieberman, a three-term senator, said he would file papers to form a presidential exploratory committee, becoming the fifth Democrat to move in that direction. But he left no doubt that there was nothing exploratory about what he was doing.
He assembled his family, friends, former classmates and teachers in a cramped lecture hall in this city where he was born 60 years ago. From there, he went on to speak to a class of high school seniors, eat lunch at a diner in front of revolving crews of television cameras and, finally, return to his childhood home to plow through a day of interviews.
"Today I am ready to put our country first, to fight for what's right for the American people. I'm ready to protect their security, to revive their economy and to uphold their values," Mr. Lieberman said, his face glistening with sweat under the hot lights set up for the event. "Yes, I am ready to announce today that I am a candidate for president of the United States in 2004."
As applause filled the room, Mr. Lieberman pumped a fist in the air and said, "And I intend to win."
Mr. Lieberman's decisive move this far before the election caught some Democrats by surprise and set him apart from the field. Aides to the other candidates say they have concluded that it is far too early to engage in the formal ritual of a campaign announcement now, arguing that whatever a candidate says now -- no matter how much attention it draws -- will be forgotten well before the first Iowa voter turns out at a caucus a year from this month.
Mr. Lieberman is more conservative than his likely competitors. Some Democrats said that his ideology should make it easy for him to distinguish himself from his opponents and make him a particularly strong candidate to run against Mr. Bush in a general election. But it could make for some rough going for Mr. Lieberman in the primaries, since Democratic primary voters are typically more liberal than the electorate as a whole.
Some of the differences between Mr. Lieberman and his opponents were on display today. He was fulsome in his praise of Mr. Bush's policy toward Iraq but argued that the president had not been firm enough in his dealings with Korea. Like the other Democrats in the race, Mr. Lieberman was critical of Mr. Bush's tax-cut plan, but he said he was intrigued by Mr. Bush's call to eliminate the dividend tax, even though it "doesn't do anything to help get us out of the rut our economy is in today."
Mr. Lieberman also acknowledged the friction he has created among Democrats in the entertainment world with his crusade against what he described as excessive sex and violence in Hollywood. 
"I raise some points of view that may not be traditionally Democratic, including a consistent record of support for a strong defense and a willingness to use our military to protect our security and advance our values," Mr. Lieberman said this afternoon, sitting with a small group of reporters at the dining room table of his childhood home. (His mother, Marcia, who is 88, sat in the kitchen over a table laden with rugelach urging "nosh" on the reporters traipsing through her kitchen on the way to talking with her son.)
This was, by any measure, a full-fledged announcement speech. Yet the theatrics that framed it were notably different from the usual, in a way that reflected the rather mild public personality of this candidate. While most candidates take and leave the stage at an announcement speech to thumping, adrenaline-pumping rock or dance anthems, Mr. Lieberman's speech was framed with the kind of soft jazz one normally encounters in the waiting room of a dentist's office.
Mr. Lieberman's candidacy will be different in another way that makes his prospects particularly difficult to fathom. If elected, he would be the nation's first Jewish president, and his own advisers say they are uncertain how much of a complication that might pose for him -- even though Mr. Lieberman said he was confident that Americans were past the point where that would be a problem.
"I'm asked this question more by the media than voters as I go along," he said. "If there are questions, I'm happy to answer them. I'm running as an American who happens to be Jewish, and not the other way around. As I said, this is all about putting our country first."
Mr. Lieberman is a practicing Orthodox Jew and observes strictures on his working and dietary habits. For example, he is prohibited by Jewish law from working on the Sabbath, which begins at sundown on Friday and extends through sundown on Saturday. 
Mr. Lieberman said today that the strictures on working would not interfere with his ability to serve as president because Jewish law allowed him to do things for the betterment of others -- a definition that he said would permit him to deal with pressing presidential obligations.
Campaigning is another matter. "I will not campaign during the Sabbath -- that's been a rule that I have followed for a long time," he said.
As a candidate for vice president, with decidedly fewer demands on his time than that on a presidential candidate, that was not a problem. But Mr. Lieberman got a reminder of how much more complicated that could be this time around this week. He turned down an invitation to attend a Saturday night county dinner in Iowa that is being attended by at least three of his rivals: Senator John Kerry of Massachusetts, Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri and former Gov. Howard Dean of Vermont.
As Mr. Lieberman himself has said, it is doubtful that he would be in the high-profile position he is in today were it not for the decision by Mr. Gore to select him as his running mate. Mr. Lieberman offered warm words for Mr. Gore today, noting how close the two came to winning last time and saying he welcomed Mr. Gore's support in 2004. At least some advisers from Mr. Gore are signing up with Mr. Lieberman.
Yet Mr. Lieberman seemed to take pains to make clear that he was sailing off in his own direction. Asked how he might campaign differently, he noted that in 2000, he largely had to follow the dictates of the Gore campaign, something that at times clearly left him uncomfortable.
"So this gives me an opportunity to do it my way," he said.
At another point, Mr. Lieberman seemed to be pointedly drawing a contrast with Mr. Gore, who was frequently criticized by Democrats for changing course and tactics to accommodate public opinion polls.
"Some mornings when I wake up, I may not know exactly where I am," Mr. Lieberman said. "But I promise you this: I will always know who I am and what I stand for."
In an interview later, he said he had not intended to knock Mr. Gore.
Repeatedly, Mr. Lieberman underscored what he described as the partisanship in the White House.
"These are not ordinary times for our country," he said. "Therefore those of us who seek our highest office or hold it can not practice ordinary politics."

HEADLINE: Fight Looms Over Who Bears the Biggest Tax Burden 

BYLINE:  By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 

 BODY:
A sop to the rich, or soaking the rich?
 As President Bush tries to sell Congress on his $674 billion plan to reduce taxes, much of the looming battle will be over two starkly opposed views about who actually bears the tax burden in America -- and who should. 
 To hear White House officials and Republican lawmakers tell it, today's tax system places a hugely disproportionate burden on the rich. Citing data published every year by the Internal Revenue Service, they noted that the top 1 percent of taxpayers pay a seemingly staggering 37 percent of all federal income taxes.
 By contrast, they say, the bottom 50 percent of taxpayers pay little or nothing. Many working poor people get money back, thanks to the expansion in recent years of tax breaks like the child tax credit. 
 "The income tax is paid almost entirely by the well-to-do," R. Glenn Hubbard, chairman of the White House Council of Economic Advisers, said in a speech last month. "In light of these figures, academic discussions of the progressivity of the income tax often have a 'missing the forest for the trees' feel to them."
Democratic lawmakers and other critics say this argument is wrongheaded, because it fails to take into account the impact of payroll taxes for Social Security and Medicare. These taxes account for almost as much money as federal income tax revenue, but they hit middle-income and lower-income workers much more heavily than the rich.
According to estimates by Citizens for Tax Justice, a liberal research group in Washington, a complete accounting shows that the wealthiest 1 percent of taxpayers earned about 18 percent of all income in 2001 and paid about 25 percent of all federal taxes. "It's a little progressive, but we're not talking about communism here," said Robert S. McIntyre, director of the group.
What nobody disputes is that President Bush's plan would provide by far the biggest benefits to the very rich.
The administration estimates that about 40 percent of the tax cuts under its overall plan would flow to people with incomes above $200,000 a year -- fewer than 5 percent of all taxpayers.
The centerpiece of the plan -- to eliminate most taxes on stock dividends, would itself cost about $300 billion over 10 years. Since the bulk of taxable dividends are received by a small segment of wealthy families, analysts estimate that about 42 percent of the tax benefit from that move alone would flow to the top 1 percent of taxpayers.
The looming fight about who pays what is likely to be one of the biggest, bitterest political battles of the year. But the debate is not only about the distribution of wealth.
It is also about the basic purposes of the tax system, about its role in promoting economic growth, its efficiency in bringing in revenue and its usefulness in promoting particular social goals or economic interests.
Is the tax code supposed to redistribute wealth, either directly from one pocket to another or indirectly through spending on schools, health and highways?
Is its main purpose to promote economic growth? Or is it simply to raise money in a way that is efficient and somehow "fair?"
The most important question may well be the one that is most avoided: the likelihood that the tax cuts will create huge deficits for years to come, even as the nation girds for a costly war with Iraq and just a few years before the costs of Social Security and Medicare are due to escalate sharply because of the aging of the baby-boom generation. 
If those costs end up being paid for by adding to payroll taxes -- which are imposed at the same rate for rich and poor alike and then mostly capped when a person's income exceeds $87,000 -- the tax burden would shift dramatically onto the shoulders of middle-income workers.
 Even beyond conservative circles, many experts consider the distributional issues of taxation to be a red herring. In pursuit of a progressive tax system that placed heavier burdens on those who earned more money, the government imposed a top tax rate of 70 percent in the late 1970's.
Few people paid taxes at that rate, however, because the system had become so riddled with loopholes and special preferences that the wealthiest one-fifth of taxpayers faced an average rate of about 35 percent.
 When Congress, prodded by former President Ronald Reagan, sharply cut the top rate to 28 percent in 1986, it also eliminated most forms of tax shelters. That move, rather than easing the tax burden on the rich, actually helped shift the burden toward the wealthy. Tax rates edged up again under the first President Bush and once again under President Bill Clinton. At the same time, Congress passed legislation that expanded the number of special deductions and credits available to lower- and middle-income workers.
 Those changes, combined with the economic boom of the 1990's, had a contradictory impact on taxpayers. The rich became richer, wealth became more concentrated at the top and tax payments by the very rich skyrocketed.
 According to the I.R.S., the combined adjusted gross income of the top 1 percent soared from $483 billion to $1.38 trillion over the decade. And even though real incomes climbed at most income levels, incomes at the very top climbed fastest of all.
 The I.R.S. estimates that the top 1 percent of taxpayers increased their share of total income from about 14 percent in 1990 to nearly 21 percent in 2000.
 But even though the richest taxpayers now account for a bigger share of federal revenue, some leading independent experts say the system has if anything become more beneficial to the rich.
 "It's true that their share of income taxes has increased, but their incomes have increased even faster," said Joel B. Slemrod, a professor of tax policy at the University of Michigan who has studied the structure of American taxes for years. "I think the system has become less progressive."
 Conservatives see the matter differently. They note that tax breaks for low-income and middle-income families have been expanded in numerous ways over the past 20 years, which is why the lowest-earning half of all households pays only 4 percent of all taxes.
 "I don't know anybody who disagrees with the general proposition that over time fewer and fewer people are paying any income taxes, and that is the result of conscious policy decisions," said Bruce Bartlett, a longtime advocate of supply-side economics and former staff director of the Joint Economic Committee in Congress.
 Led by Mr. Hubbard, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, White House officials are also arguing that the distribution of tax benefits needs to be seen through the prism of "life-cycle" analysis.
 Put simply, the idea is that many people naturally jump from one income level to another as they progress through their careers. The people who earn the least today are not necessarily the people who will still be at the bottom 10 years from now.
 "It is important to recognize the mobility of taxpayers across tax brackets," Mr. Hubbard said in a speech last month. It is normal, he said, for people to begin their careers in low-income jobs, rise into higher brackets and then fall back again when they reach retirement. Their incomes can surge and fall back as a result of business successes and stock market losses.
 But experts say the empirical evidence is mixed. Much of it is based on data collected on individuals over many years by the University of Michigan's Panel Study of Income Dynamics.
 Numerous studies have found that nearly half of people in the top or bottom fifth of income earners moved to a different level within 10 years. But other analysts caution that many of those changes are less dramatic than they appear -- a person who rises from the 79th percentile to the 80th may have jumped to a new group but experienced only a modest increase in earnings.
 Researchers using the same data have also found that people who start out in poor families move up more slowly than others, while people who start off in wealthy families drop back more slowly. And experts report that mobility up and down the income ladder has diminished significantly recently in the United States.
 But perhaps the biggest reason for skepticism, said Mr. Slemrod at the University of Michigan, is that incomes vary almost as much within any particular age group as they do for the population theory as a whole. 
 "I think the idea that people who are dirt poor are just going through a bad patch does not really fit the facts," Mr. Slemrod said.
 To the extent that Mr. Bush and Congress are determined to cut taxes, analysts say it is difficult to come up with reductions that are both sizable and equitably distributed. 
 Mr. Bush clearly tried. In addition to speeding up rate reductions and eliminating taxes on corporate dividends, both of which provide much more relief to high-income people, he called for an immediate increase in child tax credits and immediate measures to offset the "marriage penalty" on two-income households.
 But because so many people pay few or little income taxes already, it is difficult to cut their taxes much more. Meanwhile, in a trend that has received little attention, the share of federal revenue generated from corporate taxes has shrunk from 11 percent in 1987 to 8 percent now.
 Supporters of Mr. Bush's plan say they are not worried, noting that American voters complain little about income inequality and that Democrats failed to rally much opposition against Mr. Bush's first set of tax cuts in 2001.
 In part, Republicans say, that is because many middle-income people think that they too will be wealthy. But distribution issues are also abstract. People may grumble in principle about millionaires saving tens of thousands of dollars, but in practice they may be more drawn to the promise of an additional $400 rebate for every child in their family.

HEADLINE: O'Neill Expresses Doubts About Tax Cut 

BYLINE:  By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 

 BODY:
Paul H. O'Neill, in his first public comment since President Bush fired him last month as Treasury secretary, has criticized the president's plan to eliminate taxes on stock dividends as something "I would not have done."
 His remark came in an interview broadcast on Sunday by the television station KDKA in Pittsburgh. And though Mr. O'Neill tried to avoid saying anything more on the issue, his comment is consistent with reservations he expressed while still in Washington about broad tax cuts. 
 Mr. O'Neill, who had kept his home in Pittsburgh and returned there soon after being ousted in early December, had refused to talk in public until last week about his departure. He continues to turn down requests for interviews from the national news media.
In his interview in Pittsburgh, Mr. O'Neill strove to avoid criticizing President Bush and kept his comments about the tax plan extremely brief.
Asked whether he supported the elimination of taxes on stock dividends, which is the centerpiece of Mr. Bush's economic plan and accounts for nearly half its estimated cost of $674 billion over 10 years, Mr. O'Neill said he saw some value in the move but "I would not have done it." 
Mr. O'Neill had hinted at his discomfort with sweeping tax cuts before his departure. He was skeptical about the need for any broad stimulus, noting in November that many parts of the economy were holding up fairly well. His own approach, he told a group of executives at a public meeting of the United States Chamber of Commerce in November, was to select carefully tax breaks that might help the segments of industry having the most trouble.
Mr. Bush's proposal, by contrast, provides broad tax reductions for individuals and very few measures aimed directly at business.
Though he strove to be a loyal member of Mr. Bush's economic team, Mr. O'Neill said during his confirmation hearing in 2001 that he was skeptical about the wisdom of big tax cuts -- even though President Bush would soon propose his own tax package that year, which eventually passed.
In his interview with KDKA, Mr. O'Neill made it clear he was bitter about the entire swirl of politics and media in Washington.
"It's all about sound bites, deluding the people, pandering to the lowest common denominator," he said. "I didn't adjust, and I'm not going to start now."
A plain-spoken man who had been chief executive of Alcoa, Mr. O'Neill periodically created stirs with seemingly flip comments about policy toward the dollar, the intelligence of Wall Street traders and the wisdom of lending money to Brazil.
"Real leadership requires you to stick your neck out and have a point of view," Mr. O'Neill said in the interview, adding that people in Washington "don't really have the courage of their convictions."
He stopped short of criticizing or even commenting about President Bush or the administration. 
"I'm determined not to say any negative things about the president and the Bush administration," he said. "They have enough to do without having me as a sharpshooter."

HEADLINE: 3 Facing Extortion Charges in Abduction of Financier 

BYLINE:  By RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD with SHAILA K. DEWAN 

DATELINE: GREENWICH, Conn., Jan. 13 

 BODY:
Three people were charged today with conspiracy to commit extortion in connection with the kidnapping of one of Wall Street's most successful financiers, but many questions about the case remained unanswered.
 The three, Shemone Garth Gordon, 23, of New Haven, Devon Harris, 19, of West Haven, and an unnamed juvenile were charged in a sealed complaint with conspiracy to violate the federal Hobbs Act by participating in the 30-hour abduction last weekend of Edward S. Lampert, the chairman of ESL Investments here. Prosecutors said a fourth suspect was being sought. 
 Mr. Lampert, 40, named one of the 300 richest people in the country by Forbes magazine, was kidnapped Friday night and released "physically drained" but otherwise unharmed before dawn Sunday, the authorities said. The F.B.I. took the three men into custody that night. 
Investigators remained tight-lipped about a motive for choosing the victim, and only the barest of details emerged in a hearing in federal District Court in Bridgeport before Magistrate Judge Holly B. Fitzsimmons, who ordered the two men held without bail. The complaint was sealed because of the charges against the juvenile, who appeared separately before the judge in a cleared courtroom.
Both men, who prosecutors said had previous convictions for the possession and sale of drugs, were assigned public defenders because they said they could not afford lawyers. They answered softly when the judge asked rudimentary questions about knowing their rights. They wore street clothes. Mr. Gordon appeared in a blue-checked shirt and glasses, and Mr. Harris was in a black hooded jacket. 
James Finnerty, an assistant United States attorney, said investigators found a shotgun and a mask at the Days Inn motel in Hamden, Conn., where the men were found on Sunday night. He said Mr. Gordon "had control" of the weapon. But the authorities did not disclose how the lives of the men and Mr. Lampert had intersected, or how they had planned to extort from him.
Francis O'Reilly, Mr. Harris's lawyer, said "It appears to be a random thing," but he would not discuss the case further. When asked why the men had released Mr. Lampert, he replied, "the speculation is they got scared."
Mr. Lampert manages more than $5 billion in assets. His clients have included some of America's wealthiest people. He Lampert has a personal worth of $800 million and is the 288th richest American, according to Forbes magazine.
Steve Lipin, a spokesman for Mr. Lampert, said he had no comment. People at ESL Investments declined to comment, and a security guard barred reporters from entering Mr. Lampert's gated Field Point Park neighborhood. Residents here, in one of the wealthiest towns in the country, take security seriously, so much so that at one of Mr. Lampert's former residences, a man dressed in camouflage and wearing a Navy Seal hat nudged reporters away. 
But several residents and visitors said that while they were concerned, they did not know enough about the circumstances of the kidnapping to feel alarmed. 
"When something happens concerning someone that's wealthy it doesn't surprise people," said Jim Amburn, 50, a publisher from Stamford.
Wendy Ray, who was staying at the Days Inn where the three people were arrested, said officers evacuated the motel Sunday about 7 p.m. "The only thing they told us to take were our shoes," she said. 
Patel Patel, who cleans rooms at the motel, unlocked Room 132, where he said police officers spent hours poring over things. Today it remained in disarray: an empty pizza carton, soda bottles, a disposable lighter and red and black leather jacket lay on a bare mattress next to a pile of clothing and a portable radio. A bottle of cough syrup sat on a low bureau. The bathroom was covered in black dust. Mr. Patel said federal agents had dusted the area for fingerprints.
Experts in corporate and private security called Mr. Lampert's kidnapping unusual. Such crimes, they said, are more typical overseas.
But Kelly McCann, a managing director at Kroll Associates, the security firm, said he had seen an increase in calls from corporate chiefs and the well-to-do in recent years out of an overall increase in concern for safety and an economic slide that often yields disgruntled workers.
Even so, he said, abduction is often far from their minds. "A lot of people don't consider themselves as a target or they think abduction is so melodramatic," Mr. McCann said.
