HEADLINE: New Governors Discover The Ink Is Turning Redder 

BYLINE:  By JODI WILGOREN 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Jan. 13 

 BODY:
Moments after being sworn in this afternoon as Illinois's first Democratic governor in 26 years, Rod R. Blagojevich dropped the budget bomb: the estimate of the deficit he had campaigned against had doubled since his election, to more than $5 billion.
 Mr. Blagojevich recalled how John F. Kennedy expressed surprise upon becoming president that the nation's problems were every bit as dire as he had declared. But in Illinois, Mr. Blagojevich said today, "it's my sad duty to report to you it's worse." 
 As they take office this month, their scaled-back inaugural balls featuring barbecue and meatloaf instead of lobster and steak, the country's 24 new governors -- 12 Democrats, 12 Republicans -- face the worst state financial landscape since at least World War II. Many ousted incumbents by highlighting the fiscal mess, then returned from election-night victory parties only to find the gaps yawning much larger than they had expected. 
How the governors patch the deficits, and how voters react to the resulting service cuts and tax increases, will probably have large political implications. Statehouses are increasingly seen as the most promising breeding ground for national leadership, having produced four of the last five presidents and, in the 1990's, an array of celebrated policy innovators.
Politically, the Democratic Party in particular is relying on its governors, given its Congressional election defeats in November. The question is whether the party's rising stars can weather the dismal circumstances surrounding their young administrations.
"Part of this will be managing the expectations of those out there who believe that because there is a change of administration, there will be manna falling from heaven," said Jennifer Granholm, the first woman to become governor of Michigan, who has already been showcased in her party's weekly radio address and is a leading candidate to deliver the Democratic response to the State of the Union address.
The extent of the fiscal problems is staggering, with the collective shortfall for the current year estimated at $45 billion and a projected gap next year of $60 billion to $85 billion -- deficits of 5, 12, even 20 percent of the budget or more in some states. The latest fiscal survey of the National Governors Association is laced with scary adjectives: astonishing, staggering, massive, spectacular.
In Austin, Tex., this fall, at a meeting of the nation's newly elected governors, the introductions went Name, State, Size of Deficit, to which Janet Napolitano, Democrat of Arizona, added, "I think I'm going home to demand a recount."
Across the country, governors-elect have spent the last two months recounting dollars, not ballots, finding themselves forced to abandon colorful campaign promises in favor of dull necessities like debt rollovers.
Ms. Napolitano, who was sworn in a week ago facing a $1 billion shortfall in the $6 billion budget that she will present on Wednesday, said: " 'I Consolidated State Agencies' is hard to get on a bumper sticker. But you know what? We're all going to be doing it. It's a great opportunity to streamline, to show what you can do in a tough time, which is when leadership is really tested."
Since most states emptied rainy-day funds and other one-time sources like the tobacco settlement to balance last year's budgets, the new governors have spent their transitions surveying ugly options: layoffs, tax increases, new fees, program cuts. Those who pledged not to raise taxes -- like Mr. Blagojevich, Ms. Granholm and a fellow Democrat, Jim Doyle of Wisconsin, as well as Tim Pawlenty of Minnesota, a Republican -- face doing less with less. 
In Kansas, Kathleen Sebelius, a Democrat sworn in as governor today, enlisted 60 citizens for a line-by-line budget review that yielded 13 pages of recommendations, among them trimming newspaper and magazine subscriptions ($3 million in annual savings), ending a discount for the elderly at state parks ($267,000) and adding a $100 fee for public defender services ($2.1 million). Mr. Blagojevich's transition director, David Wilhelm, has wielded a knife over Illinois's $88 million, 14,000-automobile fleet and its 460-plus boards and commissions. Mitt Romney, Republican of Massachusetts, is serving without salary. Ted Kulongoski, Democrat of Oregon, announced at his inauguration today that he would cut his own pay 5 percent.
Even governors who overcame budget woes to win re-election face stark choices. On Friday, Gov. Gray Davis of California, a Democrat, proposed plugging a $36 billion gap with $8.3 billion in new taxes and drastic cuts in spending.
Gov.-elect Edward G. Rendell, Democrat of Pennsylvania, said in an interview the other day: "Everywhere I go, people say, 'Can we increase money for higher education?' And the answer is, For sure not this year. This morning I announced my secretary of transportation, and a reporter said, 'Can you guys increase state support for mass transit?' The answer is, Not this year."
"For the new class," said Mr. Rendell, a pragmatic former Democratic national chairman, "the hope is to administer the pain early. Short-run pain for long-run gain."
Though the limping economy and its attendant decline in sales- and income-tax revenue have created the rapid rise in deficit projections, state officials and other experts say the root of the problem is on the spending side. Health care costs, 30 percent of a typical state's budget, have been growing by 13 percent a year even when programs add no benefits or beneficiaries. The problem is exacerbated by unfinanced federal mandates, for programs like education and Medicaid, and an out-of-date revenue model.
"States have tax systems for a manufacturing economy in the 1950's, not for a service-oriented high-technology international economy for the 21st century," said Raymond Sheppach, executive director of the National Governors Association. 
For now, the mantra among the new governors is, "Crisis breeds opportunity," as Mr. Wilhelm, the Blagojevich aide, put it. 
At Blagojevich transition headquarters, Barry Maram, a lawyer who is among 2,000 volunteers on 17 policy committees, taped a huge chart filled with fine print on a conference room wall. Listed on the left was every state agency and department, and the columns were shaded to show the function of each. A dozen do purchasing. A gaggle manage financial resources. Umpteen handle personnel, information technology, public relations.
The idea underlying that overview was to eliminate the crossovers among departments. Mr. Maram also suggested that the state adopt a purchasing card to simplify acquisition of items costing less than $1,000. In addition, Carl Lingenfelder, a consultant, said that ideally the state's Central Management Services would bill other agencies for things like computer support.
Mr. Wilhelm, eyes glazing over, was eager to start slicing away at the state's cars and commissions.
"Boards and commissions are an outrage," he said. "What about cars? I asked somebody about cars, and they said, 'Cars? Hell, what about helicopters?' "
"We won't balance the budget with these things," he said, "but it's an important first step."
As in Illinois, transitions in many other states have been hobbled by the elusive nature of the deficit's size. 
In Kansas, next year's deficit seems to be $1 billion, but "each time they come up with another number, it's worse," said Nicole Corcoran-Basso, a spokeswoman for Governor Sebelius. 
In Michigan, Ms. Granholm campaigned against a $1 billion deficit but now finds herself $1.8 billion short in next year's $9 billion general fund. Though she barely mentioned the budget in her inaugural address, wanting to keep her remarks full of hope, she said it had been "the main underpinning of all discussions" in her transition.
In Arizona, Ms. Napolitano said budget matters had taken 85 percent of her time during the transition. In Kansas, Ms. Sebelius said it had seeped into every conversation, including those in which she tried to recruit new cabinet secretaries whose first act would be to cut their own pay.
Having been feted for taking back statehouses in Illinois, Michigan, Kansas and Wisconsin after long Republican reigns, the new Democratic governors are having to talk mainly about cutting government, typically a Republican issue. And their constituencies are hungry.
"It really delays some of the things that all of us get into government to do, to help people," said Marc Marotta, Wisconsin's new secretary of the Department of Administration, who found himself saying no repeatedly during six town-hall meetings in which people constantly suggested new ways to spend.
The governors' spin is that dire circumstances will allow them to act boldly.
"I took over as D.A. a justice system that was weak and corrupt and in ruins, and I took over a city that people had pretty much signed off on -- it was finished," said Mr. Rendell, a former mayor of Philadelphia. "Sometimes when you inherit a crisis, it's a little easier to move people to accept change."

HEADLINE: Budget Official Is Bush's Choice to Lead an Embattled I.R.S. 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 

 BODY:
President Bush today named Mark W. Everson, deputy director of the White House budget office, to run the Internal Revenue Service, reflecting the administration's belief that the embattled agency needs management help more than tax-policy expertise.
 Mr. Everson is an accountant and former corporate executive, but most of his government experience has been in managing large bureaucracies and applying technology to improving performance and cutting costs. The administration described his current role of deputy director of the Office of Management and Budget as "the president's chief management officer," and said that Mr. Everson's main task at the tax agency would be to make it operate more effectively and responsively. 
 "The position of I.R.S. commissioner is not a tax-policy position," said Ari Fleischer, the White House spokesman. "It really is a management position." Mr. Everson, he said, "has significant experience in financial management and technology issues, making him, in the president's judgment, very qualified to be the commissioner at the I.R.S."
Mr. Bush nominated one of his oldest friends, Clay Johnson, who has been White House personnel director, to replace Mr. Everson at the budget office. The move led to speculation that Mr. Johnson would eventually replace Mitchell E. Daniels Jr., the budget director, who has said he will soon decide whether to return to Indiana to run for governor. 
Mr. Everson, 47, is little known among tax lawyers, accountants and lobbyists in Washington. His nomination left them unsure what changes he might bring to the I.R.S., which has been buffeted in recent years by criticisms that it has cracked down too hard on taxpayers and tolerates too much tax evasion. If confirmed by the Senate, Mr. Everson would replace Charles O. Rossotti, who stepped down in November.
"He has one tough job," said Donald Alexander, who was commissioner of the I.R.S. from 1973 to 1977. "He has to try to turn things around in a way that won't enrage politicians who like to be enraged about the I.R.S., and at the same time make the I.R.S. more effective in the compliance area."
Mr. Everson has been deputy director of the budget office since August. Before that, he served for a year as controller of the Office of Federal Financial Management. He served for six years in a variety of positions in the Reagan administration, including deputy commissioner of the Immigration and Naturalization Service.
Early in his business career, he worked as an accountant and audit manager at Arthur Andersen. After leaving the Reagan administration, he worked for a decade as an executive at Pechiney Group, a French-owned aluminum maker, and then at SC International Services, a Dallas-based food services company.
"The agency's greatest problem remains information technology, so he's a good choice in that regard," . said Paul C. Light, an expert on the management of government at New York University and the Brookings Institution. "He's a surprise in the sense that no one would associate him with tax policy."
Mr. Everson has been involved in the administration's efforts to contract out more government functions to the private sector. That stance has led to considerable tension between the White House and unions representing government workers, including the National Treasury Employees Union, which represents 98,000 employees at the tax agency.

HEADLINE: WINE TALK; 
A Stroll Through the '21' List, Circa 1945

BYLINE:  By Frank J. Prial 

 BODY:
THE restaurant consultant Roger Martin began a long career in New York restaurants by checking coats at the "21" Club in the early 1950's while still a New York University student. Mr. Martin, who died on Dec. 4, went on to work for Restaurant Associates and Windows on the World, and for a time he ran his own place in the Hamptons.
 Last spring, when Food Arts magazine ran an excerpt from his memoirs, about his "21" days, it reminded me that somewhere I had my own "21" memento, a copy of the club's wine list from 1945, when it was known as Jack & Charlie's "21." I pulled it out. 
 Today, greasy spoons have wine lists. Fifty years ago, New York was a steak-and-potatoes town for the most part and wine sophistication, such as it was, was confined to a handful of restaurants and a couple of European-style hotels. The "21" Club was one of those places. Its celebrity-laden clientele may have consisted largely of whiskey drinkers and martini addicts, but the club was proud of its wine cellar. 
In 1945, any wine list was bound to be mostly French. The "21" list was no exception. But long before anyone else did it, "21" also offered wines from Italy, Spain, Germany, Hungary, Chile and Switzerland. And, yes, the United States.
Nowadays, recent vintages will predominate. Anything more than eight years old is special. In 1945, just the opposite was true. The youngest Bordeaux on the "21" list were nine years old -- from 1936 -- and many dated from the 1920's. In fact, it could hardly have been otherwise. World War II had ended earlier that year. Some of the best vineyards in Europe had been devastated, and wine shipments had virtually come to a halt. 
California and New York, which might have been expected to fill the void, had only begun to make fine wine in the 1930's and 40's, and very few people in watering holes like "21" were inclined to drink it. 
So "21" was selling its old wines, and what wines they were. Chateau Lafite-Rothschild 1934 was $11; so were the 1933 and the 1928. The 1924 was $9.50 and the 1920, a 25-year-old wine, was $14. The 1934 Haut-Brion was $10. The 1920 was $12.50 and the 1916 a dollar less. 
A magnum of Chateau Latour from the memorable 1929 vintage was $23 and a magnum of Chateau Margaux was $21, but a magnum of Mouton-Rothschild, listed among the Second Growths because it would not become a First Growth for another 28 years, was $25.
The depth of the restaurant's Bordeaux cellar was exceptional: five vintages of Chateau Brane-Cantenac, the youngest being 1929; six of Gruaud Larose; five of Pichon Longueville; six of Chateau Margaux going back to 1904 ($17.50); and eight vintages of the famous Sauternes, Chateau d'Yquem, from 1936 back to 1919, ranging in price from $8 for the 1936 to $18 for the 1920. 
A separate cellar held truly old Bordeaux, including the 1865 Lafite, made three years before Baron James Rothschild bought the estate, and Mouton-Rothschild 1869, made 16 years after Mouton had become Rothschild property. 
The Burgundy list was long and distinguished, with great wines like a 1934 Chambertin from Liger-Belair and a 1929 Clos de Vougeot 1929 from Mugnier priced at $8 and $11 respectively. The most expensive of the Burgundies was a 1929 Romanee-Conti from the Domaine de la Romanee-Conti for $18. Surprisingly, Beaujolais was not much cheaper than Burgundy. A 1933 Beaujolais was $7, a 1926 Fleurie $7.50, the same price as a 1928 Beaune or a 1934 Pommard Rugiens.
Wine drinkers who are just now beginning to discover German wines would be fascinated by the six pages of German rieslings "21" offered 58 years ago. On average, they were priced two to three dollars more per bottle than the Bordeaux. True, there were 15 Liebfraumilch, but there were dozens of fine estate wines under $15 and a priceless spatlese Moselle, a 1934 Bernkasteler Doktor, Dr. Thanisch, for $18.
Bear in mind that a full dinner at "21" might cost as little as $15 in 1945, and working men and women paid 35 or 50 cents for an adequate lunch at the Automat. Inflation would bring all of these fantasy prices more in line with what we must pay for these wines today. The Bernkasteler Doktor from a current vintage would sell for close to $100 in a restaurant, while contemporary versions of many of those $10 and $11 Bordeaux sell for $200 and more.
Most intriguing to me were the listings in the American wine section part of the old "21" list. Inglenook, Beaulieu Vineyards, Louis M. Martini and Wente Brothers are all represented. There is a nonvintage B.V. cabernet, four different cabernets from Martini and a sauvignon blanc from Wente. Inglenook is represented by a white wine and not by one of its memorable prewar cabernets. New York is represented by American grapes like Niagara, Delaware and Elvira, from Widmer's Wine Cellars in what the list spells as the "Canadaigua District."
The restaurant must have been nervous about offering American wines. Napa rieslings were described as "Alsatian type," a Wente chardonnay as a "Burgundy type" and a Martini cabernet from Santa Clara as a "Chateau Latour type." The Beaulieu Vineyards B.V. cabernet (Bordeaux type) sold for $3; most of the other American wines for about $4. 
These days at "21," $4 might get you a big smile from the coat checker, but not much more.

GRAPHIC: Photo: THE BOOGIE-WOOGIE YEARS -- The wine list from the "21" Club in 1945, when the restaurant was known as Jack & Charlie's "21" and dinner cost $15. (Tony Cenicola/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Getting Onto the Internet at 30,000 Feet or So 

BYLINE:  By EDWARD WONG

 BODY:
For many air travelers, flying has become an escape from the modern-day cyclone of phone calls, e-mail and instant text messages.
 But some of the world's largest airlines are now rolling out technology that allows passengers to surf the Internet, check e-mail and beam text messages to the ground. 
 Lufthansa Airlines, the German carrier, begins flying a Boeing 747-400 today between Frankfurt and Washington outfitted with Internet connectivity developed by the Boeing Company. Next month, British Airways plans to start a trial flight with the same technology between London and New York. Japan Airlines and SAS, the Scandinavian carrier, have signed contracts with Boeing to outfit nearly a dozen planes each to offer Internet service next year. 
Later this month, Cathay Pacific, the airline based in Hong Kong, will offer e-mail service on 40 planes using technology developed by Tenzing Communications, a small company based in Seattle that is partly owned by Airbus, Boeing's rival.
Another system, jointly developed by Tenzing and a company called ARINC, is already being used by Virgin Atlantic Airways, which has four planes that allow travelers to send brief text messages -- at $2.50 each -- that are typed out on video screens on the backs of seats. Virgin has a contract to install the system on its entire fleet by year's end; the technology has also been tested by Air Canada and Singapore Airlines.
The big question is whether passengers -- especially business travelers -- will pay to plug into the digital grid at 30,000 feet.
Those airlines that use Boeing's service, called Connexion by Boeing, expect to charge passengers $30 to $35 a piece for unlimited Internet access. Tenzing executives said airlines carrying its e-mail system, which does not allow Internet surfing, were expected to charge $10 to $20.
"It all depends on the pricing," said Robert W. Mann, an airline consultant based in Port Washington, N.Y. "Anything airlines can do to empower business traveler connectivity is good for the airlines. If they can do it while making a buck, so much the better. I think those things are doable, and I think business travelers will like them."
Both Boeing and Airbus, the European consortium based in France, announced their intentions to provide Internet connectivity during the height of the dot-com bubble. The three largest United States airlines said at the time that they were in contract talks with Connexion. But after the Sept. 11 attacks, and the slump in air traffic that followed, the airlines scrapped those plans.
The two aircraft makers nonetheless forged ahead with their projects, which are based on competing visions of what they think passengers want from Internet connectivity.
Boeing uses costly high-speed broadband transmission that allows Internet surfing because it says passengers want a full range of options. Tenzing and Airbus argue that most passengers just want an e-mail or messaging service.
"Jumping immediately to broadband is a significant financial risk and immediate financial investment," said Philippe Chenevier, vice president for special projects at Airbus. "It's like if you have a new territory and you build interstates with four lanes whereas you have only two cars."
Other companies also working on airborne connectivity are aiming their products elsewhere because they think the passenger market is too limited. Qualcomm has developed a broadband system that it hopes to sell to the federal government for security uses, said Jonas Neihardt, the company's vice president for federal government affairs.
Boeing and Lufthansa will be able to gauge whether their bet will pay off as the Frankfurt-Washington flight goes through its trial run in the next three months. Passengers will have access to the Internet in one of two ways: by running an Ethernet connection between their laptops and ports available on seats in first class, most of business class and the rear of economy class; or by using a wireless modem that taps into a "hot spot" throughout the cabin.
Lufthansa will not charge fees during the trial because it wants to see how passengers use the service, though the airline will ask each user how much he or she would pay, said Burkard Wigger, general manager of Lufthansa FlyNet, which is what the company calls its product.
Mr. Wigger said he expected Lufthansa to introduce the service more widely next year on long-haul flights, and to charge $30 to $35 a passenger using it.
The British Airways test will also run three months, starting on Feb. 18. But only passengers in the first three of four classes will have Internet access. And Boeing and British Airways have decided to charge about $35 a use during the trial.
"It will help us better ascertain passenger desire, how the meter will run and what to charge for the flight segment," said Scott Carson, president of Connexion.
For broadband, each plane has to be fitted with various hardware and two large antennas that shoot data back and forth between satellite transponders, similar to the transmission of satellite television. Boeing leases the transponders for $2 million each, said Bill Richards, Connexion's chief engineer.
Right now, Boeing leases only a handful of transponders, limiting Connexion's use to the North Atlantic. Mr. Carson said that as airlines in other parts of the world sign on, Boeing will increase the number of transponders to 50, then later to 80 or so. The company may eventually put its own transponders on satellites rather than leasing them, he said, a move that would cost tens to hundreds of millions of dollars for every installation.
Despite skepticism from Airbus and some industry experts, Mr. Carson said that "every study we've done over three and a half years has convinced us there is sufficient demand out there to justify this."
Most of the revenue from passenger fees will go to Boeing, and airlines will also pay Boeing to outfit their planes, Mr. Carson said.
"At the end of the day, I'm not sure I as a traveler would pay more to use the Internet on a plane," said Nicolas Owens, an aerospace analyst with Morningstar. "The market size I think is open to question. That said, I do see it becoming a sought-after and a standard type of feature as people realize the technology is out there."
Tenzing and Airbus are basing their product on existing satellite technology that airplanes use to communicate with the ground. This method is slower, but is cheaper and can be upgraded as demand increases, executives say. Neither Tenzing nor Boeing intend to offer Internet or e-mail access on flights lasting less than two to three hours because passengers on short hops probably would not pay for the services, executives say.
Tenzing has developed two products: a simple text messaging system and a more involved e-mail service. Virgin is equipping its fleet with the former, while Cathay Pacific has been testing the latter for about a year. It has signed on to outfit its entire long-range fleet with the technology.
Wendy Buck, a spokeswoman for Virgin, said the messaging system was preferable to Connexion because it allowed passengers without a laptop to send and, starting in March, receive text.
As for the e-mail service, Cathay Pacific and Tenzing will not charge passengers for another four months or so, even though they will offer the product on many of Cathay's upper-class cabins starting this month, said Eric Frederickson, Tenzing's marketing director.
Passengers will connect their laptops to a port on the seat and install software that allows them to choose one of two types of e-mail access. From their pre-existing e-mail accounts, they can download message titles that come with a few lines of text, similar to abstracts; or they can download just the titles and choose, at an extra cost per message, which ones to open.
Passengers will probably end up paying $10 to $20 a flight, said Alan McGinnis, chief executive of Tenzing.
There are limits on the kinds of e-mail accounts that passengers can use. Right now, only passengers with Pop 3 and Exchange 5.5 accounts can use the service. Companies like Yahoo and America Online have yet to make deals with Tenzing, although Mr. McGinnis said talks with such companies were continuing.
In the end, though, the fate of these projects will depend entirely on the fickle desires of business travelers. Take this traveler, whose behavior in the post-Sept. 11 era would no doubt cause executives at Boeing, Airbus and Tenzing to wince:
"I'm one of those who because of the security hassles have gone completely light and have abandoned my laptop," said Leonard S. Glickman, chief executive of the Hebrew Immigrant Aid Society and a frequent trans-Atlantic flier. "I rarely bother taking my laptop with me. With the combination of security hassles and increased enforcement of carry-on bags, I travel as light as possible now."

HEADLINE: COMMERCIAL REAL ESTATE; 
Not Going Green Is Called a Matter of Economics

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL BRICK 

DATELINE: ROCKVILLE, Md., Jan. 8 

 BODY:
The tools for constructing environmentally conscious, energy-efficient office buildings have existed for decades, but commercial developers have not adopted the principles of what is commonly called green or sustainable building because a compelling case demonstrating the economic rewards has not been made, according to specialists in real estate, finance, design, construction and environmental health and safety.
 "This is a concept that has sputtered along for 20 or 30 years," said Daniel R. Tishman, executive vice president of Tishman Realty Corporation. "It's an economic thing." 
 It is a phenomenon with parallels to the popularity of sport utility vehicles, except that buildings are responsible for more than 36 percent of the country's energy consumption, and transportation only 27 percent, according to the Energy Information Administration of the Department of Energy.
A movement is under way to promote green development as economically compelling, complete with a trade organization that sets standards and awards certifications to buildings under the Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design program administered by the private U.S. Green Building Council. This amounts to the early stages of an effort to create a marketable brand of buildings, one that addresses environmental issues outside the scope of the government's Energy Star program. 
That program, administered by the Environmental Protection Agency, awards certification to voluntarily participating buildings that demonstrate energy efficiency. The Green Building Council's program offers escalating levels of certification, using a point system to measure a broader palette of green. Developers can win points by complying with more difficult, costly and unusual standards like replacing impervious surfaces with vegetative cover and treating waste water at the site.
Governmental entities are also pressing for green building. In 2001, the federal General Services Administration joined the Green Building Council. In 2000, New York State approved a tax credit for developments that comply with requirements for energy use, materials selection, indoor air quality, waste disposal and water use. It was the first state to do so, and others, including Maryland, have followed.
Still, of the 1.6 billion square feet of nonresidential construction projects started last year, only 2.3 percent applied for certification from the Green Building Council, according to an analysis by Robert K. Watson, director of the International Energy Project at the Natural Resources Defense Council. Of government buildings, 16.5 percent applied. In commercial projects, where by far the most construction was started, only 1.07 percent applied for certification. A factor contributing to the low participation rate is that the program has existed only since March 2000, and so far, most types of projects have needed to apply in the early, conceptual phases, though they do not achieve certification until much later.
"We need to make the business case," said Kenneth W. Hubbard, a partner in the Hines Company. "It has not caught on."
There are notable exceptions, mostly experienced developers who hold their properties for many years and who have seen a comparable long-term payoff from the use of distinctive, high-quality architecture. A prominent example in New York is the Durst Organization, developer of 4 Times Square.
Elsewhere in the country, the Hines Company has taken a pioneering role, with environmentally sophisticated office buildings in Boston, Seattle, Houston, Detroit and Atlanta.
Hines estimates that it has spent 45 cents to $1.30 a square foot, varying by building, above conventional construction costs to make mechanical and electrical systems in its buildings exceed building codes.
To date, Mr. Hubbard said, the financial returns are unproven.
Here in Rockville, a private developer called the Tower Companies has built a squat 10-story oval of dark reflective glass and metallic panels, split on the thin ends by angular wedges that look like supports for a lunar module. The 263,000-square-foot Tower Building cost $62 million and sits on 12 acres. It opened at the end of 2001 and is now 85 percent leased. The cost breaks down to $235 a square foot, and of that, $124 a square foot was spent on construction, $2 more than conventional construction by the developer's estimate.
The windows are made of double-paned, spectrally selective glass that reduces the transfer of heat. Carpets and ceiling tiles are made of recycled and recyclable materials. They are manufactured to reduce the emission of volatile organic compounds, the airborne chemicals familiar to most people for giving off the "new car" smell. Fiberglass is sealed behind aluminum to prevent its transformation into airborne particles. 
The closed offices of more senior managers are lined with windows that are above the sight line (unless Shaquille O'Neal is visiting) to provide them privacy while still allowing natural daylight to reach workers in their cubicles.
Tenants cannot hear cars on I-270, an eight-lane freeway that passes within 200 feet of the building; the curtain wall is prefabricated and snapped together on the facade, with window fittings sealed with sound-minimizing gaskets instead of caulking.
In a mechanical room, 210 filters, each the size of a cat litter box, are filled with potassium permanganate, a purple granular powder that kills exposed pathogenic bacteria, part of a three-stage air filtration system that cost $75,000 more than a top-quality conventional system.
The Tower Companies has by no means employed all of the principles of green building, and the most obvious example is that this building does not generate energy. Photovoltaic cells were invented by Bell Laboratories in 1954, and their cost has been declining, but even the 4 Times Square building in New York, a high-water mark in green commercial office development when it opened in 1996, uses only a limited amount of solar power. 
With this modest approach to green building, the Tower Companies says it has secured rental contracts for $30 to $40 a square foot, at a time when average annual asking rents in Rockville are $29.38, according to the real estate services firm Cushman & Wakefield. But Tower employees said that their tenants were driven by more traditional real estate concerns.
"I can tell you the reason Bank of America leased here," said Bernard Sanker, an agent of the company. "Green didn't hurt, but they've got sign rights facing that Interstate."
His boss, Jeffrey F. Abramson, a partner in the company, said that he did not expect tenants to pay a premium for green development, even though the energy cost savings were clearly demonstrable. The monthly bill comes to about $1.50 a square foot instead of the $2 of comparable nongreen buildings the company owns.
"Tenants at Tower refused to be on their own meter," Mr. Abramson said. "They wanted to be on a gross lease."
Leasing structures are a powerful obstacle to making economic sense of green building principles. Most office tenants sign gross leases, meaning that the building owner pays for energy and water, so tenants have no incentive to reduce their energy use. 
"The lease structure is clearly not set up to address this issue," said M. Arthur Gensler Jr., chairman of the design firm that bears his surname.
And the Green Building Council's certifications, created as a marketing tool for developers and building owners, have even in their infancy become less than compelling to their intended audience, corporate tenants, according to brokers and developers across the country.
"They brought me on to this thing three years ago to open the door to the corporate sector, and it's not there; it's not even close," said Edward W. Caulkins, a senior director of Cushman & Wakefield in San Francisco who is a board member of the Green Building Council. "It can be very costly, and at the end of the day, you get a plaque."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Dan Wertz, a building engineer, shows the potassium permanganate pellets in the air-purification system of the Tower Building. The windows are made of glass that reduces the transfer of heat. (Photographs by Marty Katz for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: COMMERCIAL REAL ESTATE: Regional Market -- Connecticut; 
Tribe Invests Downtown In an Old Industrial City

BYLINE:  By ROBERT A. HAMILTON 

DATELINE: NORWICH, Conn., Jan. 9 

 BODY:
An office building is rising for the first time in decades in the downtown of this old industrial city. It is a structure that local officials see as the harbinger of more investment as a result of the proximity of two large Indian casinos. 
 The Mashantucket Pequots, who operate Foxwoods casino about eight miles from Norwich, are one of the primary backers of the $19 million Mercantile Exchange building, which has about 113,000 square feet of space on five floors. The Mashantuckets have signed a 20-year lease for the building at $1.4 million a year. 
 The tribe intends to move some of its offices to occupy about 30,000 square feet of the building when it opens in November, and rent the rest, said Elizabeth G. Judd of the leasing agent, the Konover Office and Industrial Corporation, which is a unit of the Konover Investments Corporation.
"There is lots of interest in the rest of the space, primarily because it's the first new speculative office building in southeastern Connecticut for a number of years," Ms. Judd said.
"The way the economy is now, I don't think we can guarantee it will be fully leased by the time it's ready, but I think it will fill up fairly quickly with a nice mix of tenants," she added.
Rentable space in the building is estimated at 83,785 square feet, including 6,000 square feet of retail space. Asking annual rents will be $22 a foot for the office space, and $16 a foot (without utilities and insurance) for the retail space.
The project also includes 41 parking spaces under the building and 136 spaces in a lot next to it.
The city is hoping that the project will not only revitalize the downtown retail environment, once hundreds of office workers occupy the Mercantile Exchange, but also that it will attract other commercial investment.
"To some extent that's already happening -- we have six-hour planning meetings every month to deal with all the proposals," said William R. Sweeney, the city planning director. 
"While the rest of the state and most of the Eastern Seaboard is in the doldrums, we're booming," he said.
Foxwoods and the Mohegan Sun, a casino operated by the Mohegan tribe just outside Norwich, in Uncasville, together employ more than 20,000 people, which has created a housing boom in the region already.
The Mashantuckets acquired the Mercantile Exchange property in 1995, intending to build housing or a hotel to take advantage of the waterfront views of the site, just off Norwich Harbor.
Michael Van Leesten, executive assistant to Kenneth M. Reels, the tribal councilor who has been supervising the project, said that those uses were not economically feasible -- the tribe already operates 1,400 hotel rooms and suites near its casino -- but that the Mashantuckets remained committed to improving the downtown. 
So two years ago the tribe turned the property back to the city, which brought in the Norwich Community Development Corporation to look at alternatives. Peter E. Polubiatko, who managed the project for the development agency, said there had been no new office construction in the downtown for several decades, except for the state courthouse in the early 1980's.
The Hartford architectural firm of Jeter, Cook & Jepsen designed an office building that would fit in with the Victorian architecture of the downtown.
"We tried to be sensitive to the scale and design of what surrounds the building," said Scott R. Persing, vice president of Jeter, Cook & Jepsen. Because it is five or six times the size of anything in the area, for instance, Mr. Persing used glass curtain walls and punched windows to break up the building visually.
The development agency got a $6.1 million economic grant from the state and $11.8 million in loans from a consortium of six local banks for the project. The city put up $800,000, as well as the property, valued at $200,000.
"In the absence of these kinds of partnerships, without government support, you cannot make these projects happen in distressed urban areas," Mr. Van Leesten said. "This is a partnership in the truest sense of the word, and I think there are already some indications it will lead to more cooperation."
The tribe recently announced that it will build an $8 million, 35,000-square-foot laundry in Norwich in collaboration with the Mohegans, to clean linens from the casino hotels and other commercial operations.
The tribe is also in discussions with Norwich about building a mixed residential and commercial project of three buildings of six stories each, or two buildings of about 10 stories, on the harbor. The tribe owns two of the properties at the site and the city owns the rest.
"We have a lot of confidence in Norwich," Mr. Van Leesten said. "The whole point of this project is to be a good neighbor, and we're very interested in other opportunities."

HEADLINE: Deals on Cars Help Spur Rise In Retail Sales 

BYLINE:  AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 

 BODY:
Retail sales rose 1.2 percent in December as strong car sales offset lackluster holiday business, the Commerce Department reported today. Retail sales had increased 0.9 percent in November.
 Car sales increased 5 percent, the largest rise in more than a year. While low-rate and free financing deals and other incentives motivated car purchases, shoppers seemed choosy in making smaller purchases. Sales at retail outlets other than car dealerships were flat in December, compared with a 0.3 percent gain in November. 
 For all of 2002, retail sales rose 3.4 percent, down from 3.7 percent in 2001. Consumer spending accounts for the majority of economic activity in the United States. 
"Spending is erratic," said Lynn Reaser, chief economist at Banc of America Capital Management. "Consumers will need to see gains in employment and income to support sizable gains in spending." 
Recovery from recession has been slow and uneven, with a quarter of economic growth followed by a quarter of weakness. 
According to the figures released today, the 5 percent rise in car sales in December came after a 2.6 percent increase in November. 
"The reinstatement of more generous incentives, such as zero percent financing, strong cash incentives and, in some cases, delayed payments and no down payments on 2003 models, were irresistible to customers," said Paul Taylor, chief economist at the National Automobile Dealers Association. 
Elsewhere, sales at electronics and appliances stores rose 0.6 percent in December, up from a 0.1 percent increase in November. Sales at clothing stores rose 0.8 percent, balancing a 0.8 percent drop the month before.
Gasoline sales rose 0.7 percent, after a 0.9 percent increase in November. Both figures reflected the increase in world oil prices. 
Bar and restaurant business increased 1.1 percent in December for the second consecutive month. At furniture and home furnishing stores, sales were flat after posting a 1.6 percent rise in November. 
Sales of building and garden supplies fell 1.8 percent last month, after a 0.8 percent rise. Sporting goods, book, music and hobby-store revenue dropped 0.9 percent in December, a turnaround from November's 0.5 percent increase.
Sales at food and beverage stores declined 1 percent, after a 1 percent increase in November. 
And sales at department stores dipped 0.3 percent, after a 3.4 percent drop in November.

HEADLINE: Indonesian Province Enjoying First Signs of Peace 

BYLINE:  By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: LHOKSEUMAWE, Indonesia, Jan. 12 

 BODY:
Children are playing outside again, street vendors are selling soda and couples are strolling on the rutted walkways, simple pleasures that perhaps spell some return of normalcy to Aceh, the northern Indonesian province torn apart by conflict for nearly 30 years.
 The first blush of peace in this city is particularly welcome to residents who have missed using the central park, a graceful retreat of green trees, sand pits and slides that had long been too dangerous for residents to frequent for fear of ambush by soldiers or extortion by guerrillas. 
 "We have been waiting for this moment for years," said Cut Syamsurniati, the leader of the human rights organization Rehabilitation Action for Torture Victims in Aceh, as she strolled in the shade, her face wreathed in smiles.
A peace accord signed in Geneva on Dec. 9 by the Indonesian government and the separatist group in this province, the Movement for a Free Aceh, has worked better than expected, Acehnese people and Western diplomats say. 
The number of reported killings of civilians has plummeted. Twelve war-related civilian deaths were reported during the first month of the accord, compared with a monthly average of 87 in 2002, according to David Gorman, a negotiator for the Henry Dunant Center, the Swiss-based private group that mediated the peace deal. So far, armed clashes have been reduced to occasional skirmishes, he said.
Most significantly, the government has permitted foreign monitors to visit Aceh (pronounced AH-chay) for the first time. Previously the Indonesians insisted that Aceh was an internal matter, a posture that diplomats said kept the dirty war and its human rights abuses by both sides -- murders, kidnappings, torture -- hidden from the world.
Behind the scenes, the United States encouraged both sides to go to the peace table. Gen. Anthony C. Zinni, the retired former head of the Central Command, is an adviser to the Henry Dunant Center and was critical to reaching agreement on the final details in Geneva last month.
Now the United States Agency for International Development is financing a public information campaign intended to embolden civilians to call a hot line with complaints about violations of the accord.
A settlement of the conflict would mean less trouble for the large Exxon Mobil natural gas plant near here, which has been a longtime target of the guerrillas.
The Bush administration, which is considering a renewal of military ties with Indonesia, the world's most populous Muslim nation and a place where Islamic militancy has shown some signs of spreading, would welcome improved behavior from the armed forces and the police as well.
But it remains unclear whether the progress of the first month reflected the heady days of a skimpy peace or the long slog to an enduring reconciliation.
 The American ambassador to Indonesia, Ralph L. Boyce, said in Aceh on Tuesday that fulfillment of the peace deal would be a "long-term problem." 
A leader of the rebels, Isnandar Al-Pase, said in an interview that his group was relatively pleased with the specifics of the accord. Moreover, he said, "I am happy when I see our people happy."
The accord makes considerable demands on both sides, with the most difficult tasks to start early next month. The Indonesian Army is to relocate its forces to defensive positions, meaning among other things that it should take down roadblocks.
The most vicious element of the police force, commonly known as Brimob, is to be melded into the regular Indonesian police under the leadership of a newly installed police general, Bachrumsyah Kasman.
For their part, the rebels are expected to deposit their weapons at sites designated by the rebels but open to inspection without notice by the Henry Dunant Center's monitors.
Gen. Tanongsuk Tuvinun of Thailand, who arrived last month to head teams of monitors from Thailand and the Philippines, said he was upbeat so far. "In this one month we have established credibility," he said. But that credibility "will go down" quickly, he warned, unless more foreign monitors arrive and unless a couple of sticking points in carrying out the accord are resolved.
Most critical for cementing the good feelings is a quick infusion of money to rebuild schools, which were a target of the war, and to reconstruct villagers' homes that were burned by the army as it hunted suspected rebels. The World Bank has pledged money, but how fast and how much is still undecided, said Andrew Steer, the bank's representative in Indonesia.
Another early problem is how and where to set up "peace zones" that the peace accord says are to be established in "locations of conflict." 
General Tuvinun said he had been meeting privately with both sides to find agreement on at least a first peace zone. Neither side wanted to give up a supposed territorial advantage. He said he was now considering imposing a zone.
In some contested rural areas, the signs of peace have been promising enough for people to take matters into their own hands and return home from camps of the displaced.
In the village of Indrajaya in the Pidie district, about an hour's drive south of the provincial capital, Banda Aceh, Muhammad Ali and his wife, Nurlaila, were reunited in their house last week. Mr. Ali said he ran away four years ago after the army came looking for him as a suspected member of the rebel movement. They harassed his wife, so two years ago she ran away too, he said.
In the last few weeks the local soldiers have been less abusive, the villagers at Indrajaya said. They said that instead of routine intimidation during patrols, soldiers were now riding through on motorbikes, their weapons no longer so visible.
Further south, along the main dirt track into the village of Cempedak, about 10 miles south of Lhokseumawe, soldiers guarded four roadside posts. This has been one of the most violent areas in the war. A few hundred yards off the track, three workers of Ms. Syamsurniati's group were shot and killed by Indonesian soldiers in December 2000. No case has been brought against the troops.
As she traveled down the track, Ms. Syamsurniati noted that the soldiers appeared to be less threatening. Before, she had to ask permission to go to Cempedak, and soldiers would stop her at each roadside post. Now they just waved her on from the comfort of their shacks.
In the village itself, people milled around on the main center, and at the corner coffee shop the tables were crowded, even at dusk. "We can sit here until late at night," said Zakana, a rice farmer. But the owner, Lutan, said gunfire could still be heard some days, forcing customers to flee. 
Mr. Zakana said: "It's still not completely normal. If you go to the rubber fields, the soldiers come and ask for money." General Tuvinun said he considered such reports of extortion an encouraging sign. 
"Prior to the signing there were a lot more serious incidents," he said, citing killings and rapes. "All those serious cases have gone down," he said. Now people are daring to come out and talk about extortion."

HEADLINE: Microsoft to Give Governments Access to Code 

BYLINE:  By STEVE LOHR 

 BODY:
To try to slow the acceptance of the Linux operating system by governments abroad, Microsoft is announcing today that it will allow most governments to study the programming code of its Windows systems. Under the program, governments will also be allowed to plug their security features instead of Microsoft's technology into Windows.
 More than two dozen countries, including China and Germany, are encouraging agencies to use "open source" software -- developed by programmers who distribute the code without charge and donate their labor to debug and modify the software cooperatively. The best-known of the open source projects is GNU Linux, an operating system that Microsoft regards as the leading competitive threat to Windows. 
 "Microsoft is doing this to combat Linux and open source," said Ted Schadler, an analyst at Forrester Research. 
One appeal of Linux is that developers have complete access to the underlying source code, whereas Microsoft has kept some Windows technology secret. That has made many governments leery of becoming too reliant on Microsoft technology, and it has been a marketing advantage for Linux. 
The concern about Microsoft abroad has grown as the company has become more dominant and as more and more government operations, from the military to health services, rely on its software.
"The issue is how comfortable are governments depending on the technology of a United States company and Microsoft in particular," said Craig Mundie, a senior vice president at Microsoft. "As a technology platform, we want to be demonstrably neutral to national interests."
In the past, Microsoft has shared some source code -- the computer instructions rendered in a programming language that people can read, instead of binary code of 1's and 0's that machines process -- with selected governments.
But Mr. Mundie said the new initiative, called the Government Security Program, represents "a substantial step beyond our previous efforts."
Under the program, 97 percent of the code to Windows desktop, Windows server and Windows CE hand-held software will be available to governments online for inspection and testing. To view the other 3 percent -- the most sensitive technology -- government representatives must come to Microsoft headquarters in Redmond, Wash.
Governments, under the initiative, will also be allowed to choose their own cryptography software and snap that code into software "sockets" in Windows. Governments can also control their own identification and authentication technology for privacy and security, and still run on Windows.
"Microsoft will partner with and trust the governments where we do business," Mr. Mundie said.
And abroad, there have been steady reports and rumors that Microsoft kept a software "back door" in Windows that it would allow tapping by United States government agencies for national security or espionage purposes. "This should go a long, long way," Mr. Mundie said, "toward eliminating the popular speculation in many countries that has been used to attack Microsoft." 
Microsoft expects that perhaps 60 foreign governments and international agencies will eventually join its government security program. The first to join were Russia and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, and the company is negotiating with 20 other groups.

HEADLINE: Philanthropist Gives A.C.L.U. $8 Million 

BYLINE:  By STEPHANIE STROM 

 BODY:
Peter B. Lewis, the feisty philanthropist who has forced several beneficiaries of his largess to practice greater financial discipline, is giving $8 million to the American Civil Liberties Union. But Mr. Lewis said there were no strings attached to his gift. 
 The donation, the largest the organization has ever received from an individual, will support the A.C.L.U.'s efforts to fight antiterrorism measures that it deems a violation of civil liberties. 
 "This gift comes at a critical time in the A.C.L.U.'s work and the country's history," Anthony Romero, executive director of the group, said on Monday. "Even in the midst of an economic downturn, Peter recognizes that civil liberties are not a luxury item to be supported only in times of prosperity."
Mr. Lewis, a longtime member of the organization, said he made the contribution because he wanted to show support for Mr. Romero and the causes with which the A.C.L.U. deals.
"I just think that what they work on is very important," he said.
Mr. Lewis's profile as a philanthropist has skyrocketed since he declared a boycott of charities in Cleveland, his hometown, last fall and then forced the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum in New York to pare its budget in exchange for a $12 million gift.
"My gifts are not given on condition," he said. "But I have discovered that as a philanthropist, one's leverage is substantially before the check is written."
Mr. Romero expressed no concern over Mr. Lewis's penchant for driving hard bargains for his gifts. Rather, he said, he expected to be able to use the gift to encourage other philanthropists, something about which Mr. Lewis was less certain.
"I'm flattered that he thinks it will have that effect, but I think philanthropists tend to be pretty independent," said Mr. Lewis, who made his fortune in the auto insurance business.
Since the Sept. 11 attacks, the A.C.L.U. has seen record growth in membership, Mr. Romero said. In 2000, it attracted 59,607 new members, but in 2001, almost 75,000 people joined.
Last year, its ranks swelled by 90,000, bringing membership to 330,000.
"What this demonstrates is that a growing portion of the American public is concerned that government efforts to ensure national security undercuts core American values such as fairness, equality and freedom," Mr. Romero said.
The Lewis gift means that the A.C.L.U. will probably meet its goal of raising $50 million for its endowment, he said.

HEADLINE: In Public Input, a Hint Of Rebuilding Fatigue 

BYLINE:  By EDWARD WYATT 

 BODY:
Since the new designs for the World Trade Center site were unveiled to great fanfare last month, there has been no shortage of public discussion and debate about the plans, their expected impact on the downtown skyline or the future of Lower Manhattan.
 So it was surprising that a citywide series of public hearings yesterday and Monday to gauge response to the new designs and guidelines for a memorial to victims of 9/11 attracted little more than a predictable array of single-issue zealots and almost no substantive comments about details of the plans. 
 The result, including a very light turnout at satellite hearing sites outside of Manhattan, was even more puzzling in light of the fact that tens of thousands of people have toured an exhibit of the plans in the Winter Garden of the World Financial Center, and millions have visited the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation's Web site to view the nine plans from seven teams of architects. 
More than 4,000 visitors to the exhibit have submitted written comments on the plans, according to development corporation officials, and 2,400 have submitted comments over the Internet -- including about 400 people who did so Monday evening as the hearing was being broadcast online and on television. 
Only a small percentage of those comments have rejected all of the new designs, but that was the favorite position of those who spoke at the hearings this week.
What the response reflects is more likely a combination of poor execution in the latest round of public hearings and a sort of rebuilding fatigue among those who have been most active in the process.
In addition, even people who have closely followed the process remain confused about who will make the decisions about what is built at the trade center site. Still unclear is what the rebuilding effort will look like over the next five years -- before new office buildings go up but as work proceeds on a memorial, a new transportation hub and the reopening of an area of downtown that has been kept largely in limbo for well over a year. 
Certainly few officials of the rebuilding effort were happy with Monday night's meeting. 
"In the end, it didn't feel like a particularly useful meeting, and that was fairly dispiriting," said Billie Tsien, the architect who is a director of the development corporation and is on the joint agency task force reviewing the new designs. "Unfortunately the people who have paid attention to the plans and could comment seriously on them were relatively few." 
The hearings this week at Pace University in Lower Manhattan lacked the rigor of the more fruitful meeting in July at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center, where a demographically representative group was put together by the sponsor, the Civic Alliance to Rebuild Downtown New York, and asked to discuss, in small groups, specific issues and details of the plans. 
But the lack of turnout this week might also have reflected some satisfaction that the new designs are on the right track, as well as a lack of energy among too many people to continue to engage in a debate that has now lasted for more than a year. 
For the hearings specifically on the memorial yesterday, like Monday, comments often strayed from the proposed agenda. At Pace, about 300 people listened as the participants focused on calls for the memorial to take priority over buildings, something that rebuilding officials have stressed and that the architects seemed to take to heart by putting space for a memorial at the center of their designs.
Other speakers opposed some recommendations of a working group that put together preliminary guidelines for a memorial. Those comments called for separate recognition of firefighters and other rescue workers in the memorial, and for more specific references to the terrorist attack. Others endorsed the idea of a tomb of unidentified remains. 
Some architects who have examined the plans closely say they are bold in scope, but are lacking in details. Beverly Willis, the director of the Architecture Research Institute and co-chairwoman of Rebuild Downtown Our Town, said the group's members have struggled to understand each design's underground elements, their topographical layouts, even the square footage of proposed office space.
Two other civic groups have similarly tried to grasp the details of the plans. Imagine New York, a project of the Municipal Art Society, prepared a concise comparison of the nine plans, allowing for direct comparison of details like the number of skyscrapers, the amount of open space and the stages of construction in each. Titled "The People's Response," the document is available at www.imaginenewyork.org.
New York New Visions, a coalition of 21 architecture, planning and engineering organizations, released a far more detailed assessment of the plans on Monday. Its 41-page document, which will be posted online this week at nynv.aiga.org, examines how each design treats the memorial, the street network and the skyline. 
While those efforts can help to make sense of the designs, considerable uncertainty remains about who gets the final word. 
"We've talked consistently about the need for a clear public process and an explanation of what the decision-making procedure is going to be," said Marcie Kesner, an urban planner and co-chairwoman of New York New Visions.
Roland W. Betts, the development corporation director and chairman of the task force, said Alexander Garvin, the development corporation's planner, and Stanton Eckstut, the Port Authority's planner, were evaluating the plans against about 40 categories of design principles. 
Their work will then be considered by the task force, which includes development corporation board members; directors of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which owns the trade center site; and representatives from the offices of Gov. George E. Pataki and Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg.
Mr. Betts disputed the notion that Mr. Garvin and Mr. Eckstut are designing their own plans, a sort of amalgam of the latest designs. 
"They have not been asked to come up with plan No. 10 or a composite plan," Mr. Betts said. "As we come down to one or two or three plans to work with, I think maybe the public will be more involved."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
$70 Million in Fines Paid In Illegal Stock Trading
Seven former traders and executives of Datek Online, once heralded as a pioneer in online stock trading, agreed to pay $70 million in fines for what regulators called illegal trading and fraudulent bookkeeping during the market boom of the 1990's. The Securities and Exchange Commission called it one of the largest securities fraud settlements in history.
 Regulators said the group of former traders and executives made tens of millions of dollars by engaging in stock fraud that went on for nearly a decade and involved taking advantage of a Nasdaq trading system that was intended to help smaller investors. Page A1. 

Charges Raise China Questions
In three separate cases since October, natives of China have been accused of obtaining technology from Silicon Valley companies with the intent of exporting it to China. C11.

Little Detail From WorldCom Chief
In his first extensive public comments since taking over at WorldCom, Michael D. Capellas, left, said his executive team would help cut costs and maintain high ethical standards at the company. But he offered few specifics about how many jobs he intends to cut or other steps the company will take as it tries to emerge from bankruptcy protection. C3.

Financially troubled Kmart will lay off as many as 35,000 workers and close 326 stores over the next three months. C4.

Regulators Halt Gene Therapy Trials
Federal regulators suspended 27 gene therapy trials involving several hundred patients after learning that a second child treated had developed a condition resembling leukemia. A1.

Industry Won't Seek Help on Piracy
The major recording companies said they would not seek government intervention to prevent digital piracy. C3.

Microsoft Offers Access to Code
To try to slow the acceptance of the Linux operating system by governments abroad, Microsoft is announcing today that it will allow most governments to study the programming code of its Windows systems. Under the program, governments will also be allowed to plug their security features instead of Microsoft's technology into Windows. C10.

Airbus Is on Course to Lead Market
Airbus said that it was raising its prices by an average of 2.5 percent and forecast that it would deliver about 300 planes this year, setting it on course to be the market leader over Boeing. World Business, Section W.

Car Deals Spur Rise in Retail Sales
Retail sales rose 1.2 percent in December as strong car sales offset lackluster holiday business, the Commerce Department said. C4.

Strike at G.E. Over Health Costs
Angry about General Electric's decision to force employees to pay more for their health coverage, 17,000 workers at 48 locations in 23 states began a two-day strike. A13.

Going Green a Matter of Economics
The tools for building environmentally sensitive, energy efficient offices have existed for decades. But such buildings are just now drawing interest. Commercial Real Estate. C5.

HEADLINE: Handful of Indictments Over Technology 

BYLINE:  By MATT RICHTEL 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 14 

 BODY:
In three separate cases since October, natives of China have been accused of obtaining technology from Silicon Valley companies with the intent of exporting it to China.
 While China policy experts say there does not appear to be any direct connection among the cases, they say they underscore a continuing effort to procure high technology from the United States, particularly in Silicon Valley, and to serve a fertile market for the sale of trade secrets. 
 In the most recent indictment, handed up on Friday, Qing Chang Jiang, the president of EHI Group USA Inc./Araj Electronics in Cupertino, Calif., was accused of illegally exporting technology with military applications. He is the fourth Chinese native to be indicted in the last four months. In the two other cases, the technology appears principally to have commercial, not military uses. 
With government officials scrutinizing technology procurement by Iraq and North Korea, the indictments have raised an issue that came to the fore during the Clinton administration: China's procuring of technology, both for its military and for its growing technology industries.
"There is very aggressive economic espionage and reverse engineering by Chinese commercial enterprises exploiting the diaspora of Chinese," said James Mulvenon, a political scientist at Rand, who has closely studied technology procurement by business and the military in China.
China experts say the issue was intensified by the indictment of Mr. Jiang, 51, also known as Frank Jiang. According to court documents, Mr. Jiang is accused of exporting microwave amplifiers, which have commercial applications but can also be used for military purposes like tracking missiles.
In the spring of last year, according to the documents, Mr. Jiang bought nine microwave amplifiers and sought to export them to a company known as the Hebei Far-East Harris Company. According to an affidavit, that company has the same address as the 54th Research Institute.
According to the affidavit, the secretary of commerce has deemed that "end users" at the 54th Research Institute -- known as the Ministry of Communication, Telemetry and Telecontrol -- "present an unacceptable risk of diversion to developing weapons of mass destruction or the missiles used to deliver those weapons."
The indictment comes a little more than a month after the United States attorney for the Northern District of California indicted Fei Ye, who is a United States citizen, and Ming Zhong, a permanent resident. The two men were arrested at San Francisco airport and, according to the indictment, were in possession of trade secrets stolen from four Silicon Valley companies: Sun Microsystems, the Transmeta Corporation, NEC Electronics and Trident Microsystems.
The indictment contends the trade secrets were obtained in connection with an effort to promote a Chinese venture called Supervision Inc. that sought to produce and sell microprocessors in China. According to the indictment, the defendants in the case told others they sought to recruit, including engineers, that Supervision was being financed by the city of Hangzhou. The defendants also told potential recruits that they were working with a professor from Zhejiang University, a major university in China, according to court papers.
Ross W. Nadel, an assistant United States attorney in the Northern District of California, who oversees the computer hacking and intellectual property unit, said, however, that the indictment did not contend any direct involvement by the Chinese government.
In October, the United States attorney indicted Shan Yan Ming, 32, a citizen of China, who is accused of having obtained unauthorized access to the computers of 3DGeo Development Inc., a company in Mountain View, Calif., that makes software for the oil industry. According to the government, Mr. Shan is an employee of the DaQing Oil Field, a division of a major Chinese company called PetroChina. F.B.I. agents arrested Mr. Shan at San Francisco International Airport as he was trying to board a flight to China, according to prosecutors.
China policy experts said that in general it was difficult to know whether the people accused of procuring or possessing technology might be working at the behest of corporate or government entities. Rather, the experts said the individuals might be working alone, hoping to obtain, or steal, intellectual property in the United States and then find a market for it in China.
Nicholas Lardy, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution, said that in the case of semiconductor technology -- like that in the Supervision case -- Chinese entities might have less incentive to mount an operation to procure it illegally because China already imports nearly $2 billion in microprocessors a year. Complicating the analysis further, Mr. Lardy said, there is a "thick interconnection" between Silicon Valley and China's booming high-technology industry -- China is a major maker of consumer electronics.
"When it comes to procurement of commercial technology, what's imponderable is whether you're looking at a guiding hand, or a whole bunch of entrepreneurs," said William Triplett, former chief Republican counsel to the Senate Foreign Relations Committee. "What is not imponderable is that the situation got way out of hand in the 90's."

HEADLINE: Think Rich, Vote Rich, Get Rich 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Re "The Triumph of Hope Over Self-Interest," by David Brooks (Op-Ed, Jan. 12): 
 Traditionally, increasing income inequality has been associated with decreasing economic fairness. 
What Mr. Brooks is really saying is that in recent years a "disconnect" took place in the inequality-fairness relationship. And he's right; look at the facts.
Despite the widening income gap, the poverty rate in this country is about the same as it was 30 years ago; the yearly income range of the middle class now extends up toward $150,000; and the wealthy (despite the bursting of the bubble) are flourishing as in no other time in history.
Ordinary Americans saw this happening and have come to realize that there is nothing wrong with being rich and getting richer -- as long as it's done fairly. The Republicans got the message. The Democrats didn't.

PAUL RYSCAVAGE
Bluffton, S.C., Jan. 13, 2003

The writer is a former Census Bureau economist.

HEADLINE: THREATS AND RESPONSES: BEIJING; 
China Offers to Be Host of Direct U.S.-North Korea Talks

BYLINE:  By ERIK ECKHOLM 

DATELINE: BEIJING, Jan. 14 

 BODY:
China stepped up an effort today to defuse the North Korea nuclear crisis, offering to act as host to direct talks between the United States and North Korea should both sides agree.
 The offer reflected the high importance China attaches to resolving a problem that could potentially destabilize its northeast border or damage its emerging friendship with the United States. 
 In Washington, the White House said it welcomed China's involvement and appeared receptive to talks with Pyongyang, though officials insisted that an end to North Korea's nuclear plans was not negotiable. There was no immediate response to the offer from the Pyongyang government. 
Although China is a longtime ally of North Korea, it strongly opposes North Korean development of nuclear weapons and long-range missiles, which it fears could set off an arms race or conflict in East Asia.
At the same time, China does not want social chaos or war on its borders and hopes to head off harsh international economic sanctions against the North that would produce hordes of refugees or even cause the Pyongyang government to collapse, bringing pro-Western military forces to its border.
"North Korea provides China with a big security buffer," said Shen Dingli, a defense expert at Fudan University in Shanghai. "We can't risk losing this."
China made the offer to act as a host the same day an American diplomat, Assistant Secretary of State James A. Kelly, arrived in Beijing for talks on the impasse over North Korea's nuclear weapons plans. Mr. Kelly, who conferred with South Korean officials on Sunday and Monday, has tried to convey the message that the United States has no desire for war with North Korea and that it might consider economic assistance to North Korea if it backed off its recent nuclear threats.
"The key at present is for the parties concerned to resume dialogue," said Zhang Qiyue, a Foreign Ministry spokeswoman, at a regularly scheduled briefing today.. "We've had frequent contact with all the parties concerned."
In response to a question, Ms. Zhang said, "If the relevant sides are willing to hold dialogue in Beijing, I think we would have no difficulties with that."
China is formally an ally of North Korea and provides essential trade and aid, but officials here often express frustration with the unpredictability of the government in Pyongyang and say their leverage is limited. 
The nuclear impasse is an enormous headache for China, which hopes for regional stability and closer ties with the United States as it pursues economic development.
Because it is one of the few countries with regular access to North Korean leaders, though, China has in recent years played what American officials have often called a "constructive role" in easing tensions in the Koreas. If China can help resolve the current crisis, it may gain favor with the Bush administration.
President Jiang Zemin discussed the Korean issue with President Bush in a telephone call on Friday. The North Koreans had just announced that they would withdraw from the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty, prompting an unusual if mild rebuke from Beijing.
Today, Ms. Zhang repeated China's concern. "We are clearly not in favor of the D.P.R.K.'s withdrawal from the nonproliferation treaty, " she said, using the initials for North Korea's formal name, Democratic People's Republic of Korea.
In Beijing on Saturday, in a statement that must have displeased Chinese leaders, North Korea's ambassador ratcheted tensions still higher by repudiating Pyongyang's promise in 1999 not to test long-range ballistic missiles. Such a test in 1998, in which a North Korean missile flew over Japan, sent shivers through Asia and upset Beijing because it increased Japanese support for the American military alliance and for development of missile defenses. 
Today, Ms. Zhang declined to say whether the Chinese Government had been surprised by North Korea's provocative statement on Saturday, but said, "No party should take moves that would further escalate the situation." 

GRAPHIC: Photo: Assistant Secretary of State James A. Kelly talked to reporters today at a Beijing hotel. Mr. Kelly arrived in Beijing last night as China offered to act as host to talks between the United States and North Korea. China is an ally of North Korea, but opposes its development of nuclear weapons. (Reuters)
