HEADLINE: Strike's Effects Tear at Social Fabric in Venezuela 

BYLINE:  By GINGER THOMPSON 

DATELINE: CARACAS, Venezuela, Jan. 15 

 BODY:
The sign on the door says "closed." The lights are dim. The staff is not in uniform. Customers are only allowed in through the out door. But in the seventh week of a national strike aimed at shutting down the economy and toppling President Hugo Chavez, Blockbuster Video began covert operations in at least two popular stores in the capital.
 The staff and managers refused to fully identify themselves, or to even respond to simple queries about store hours and movie releases coming soon. However, in one brief outburst, a store manager who identified herself only as Eugenia, strived to make clear that her decision to open for business weighed heavily on her conscience. 
 "It is hard to work," she said. "But it is harder not to work." 
The strike that once left most commercial areas of the city dark and abandoned -- at an economic cost of more than $50 million a day -- is now a collage of contrasts: abandoned shopping malls and bustling street markets; long lines outside gas stations and traffic jams; shuttered McDonald's outlets and packed gourmet restaurants. Venezuelan beer has been replaced by Mexican and German brands. Movie theaters are closed, but neighborhoods are setting up screens in parks and plazas.
Since it began on Dec. 2, the strike has become the fault line that divides this society into rival camps, wreaking havoc on neighborhoods and families alike. It was organized by a coalition of business executives, union leaders and civic organizations to force Mr. Chavez to call new elections.
So far, the strike leaders have failed to accomplish that goal. In the lingering war of attrition between President Chavez and his opponents, Venezuelan society has begun to take stock of the consequences. The economy is in ruins. A country that already endures one of the highest violent crime rates in the hemisphere -- dozens of people are killed on an average weekend in this metropolitan area -- has now been pushed to the brink of civil conflict. Mr. Chavez shows no sign of leaving.
In some places the strike holds firm, particularly in the state-owned oil company, which pumps the black blood of Venezuela's economy and is a chief supplier to the United States. Thirty-thousand workers walked off the job soon after the strike started. The government has been unable to lure them back in significant numbers, causing oil shortages around the world.
Marches by flag-waving Chavez opponents, rolling through the city like red, blue and yellow tidal waves, continue almost every other day; the most vibrant display, some analysts say, of the politicization of a once comfortable middle class that considered politics a frivolous pursuit. In a nightly ritual called the "cacerolazo," or pot-banging, a cacophonous clatter echoes through the skyscrapers and condominium complexes across this valley city at 8 p.m. as opponents of Mr. Chavez -- housewives and professionals, rich and working class -- emerge from their homes and offices to blow whistles and bang on cooking pots.
In a local newspaper interview, the poet Rafael Arraiz Lucca described the atmosphere: "Venezuelans are living a collective hypnosis very close to hysteria."
Still, in the day-to-day life of the city, the strike comes more in fits and starts. Some private and public schools have not reopened. Others have opened with the help of neighborhood volunteers. Banks and supermarkets are open for limited hours. Subway and bus service continues as normal.
"This is not a strike that will be lifted," said Ibsen Martinez, a newspaper columnist. "This is a strike that will slowly languish."
The opposition's base of support among the Venezuelan middle class -- especially the owners of small and medium-sized businesses -- consider President Chavez a dictator in a democrat's clothes. They point to his control over the Congress and the justice system as signs of a grand plan to install a Cuba-style government. But their dwindling financial resources have them grappling over how much longer they can hold out.
Gonzalo Garcia, owner of a Subway sandwich shop, has lost more than $30,000 since the strike began. He added that if the Chavez government survives the strike, he and his family would leave their homeland.
"I would love to recover my store and even open others," he said, but "I cannot let my children grow up in an atmosphere of violence."
Lawlessness is not limited to Caracas. Local news media reported that three people were shot and wounded today as looters ransacked the town of Guiria, 310 miles east of the capital. Looting also was reported in Ciudad Bolivar, 280 miles southeast of Caracas. 
Supporters of President Chavez seem simply fed up. Behind the marches and cacerolazos, they see a plot orchestrated by a group of the wealthy elite who are determined to impose their will on a democratically elected president.
Nicolasa Veita, a nurse the Centro Medico de Caracas, said the privately owned hospital had closed all but its emergency services. Last Friday, supervisors notified the nursing staff that they would not be paid this month. But she and the 130 other nurses refused to walk off the job.
"The first right that all people have, no matter what their political views, is the right to life," she said. "The doctors are looking for an excuse to close the hospitals and blame it on the government. The nurses are not going to let that happen."
On Tuesday the political storm that has battered this country came crashing down on the Mater Salvatori girls' school. Two-thousand parents -- almost all of them mothers -- packed into the small assembly hall to vote on whether to break the strike by opening the sprawling, affluent campus for classes.
The meeting turned into a rally, with parents roused from their seats, chanting "Not one step back." By the end of the morning, there was no need to take a vote.
One daring father stood briefly against the furious female outpouring against Mr. Chavez to ask how long parents were willing to keep their children out of school, and how teachers planned to make up the classes that would be lost.
The assembly hall filled with hissing. Then another father spoke up.
"This is not about losing some classes, or even the whole semester if that is what is necessary," he said, his bespectacled face turning red with emotion. "This is about losing our country."
School meetings like that one have become flashpoints for the strike against Mr. Chavez. After a vote at a private elementary school in a neighborhood called California Norte, Elenitza Guevara, a lawyer and mother of two, left fed up. The parents, she said, were not interested in a real debate about closing the school, she said. People like her, who were opposed to closing, were shunned. "I told them, what kind of tolerance are we going to be able to teach our children if we cannot let everyone express their views?" she said, still riled from the meeting. "The truth is, there was no room for negotiation."
What made her even more angry, she said, was that the cost of the decision had been passed on to the parents. While school administrators encouraged parents not to reopen the school, they advised the parents that they would be expected to make this month's tuition payments.
"If some parents do not want to send their children to school, they should have that right," she said. "But why should they take away my right to send my child to school? Why should they take away my child's right to an education?"

U.S. to Join Mediation Group
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (Agence France-Presse) -- The United States said today that it would take part in a new group to assist regional mediation efforts to end the political crisis in Venezuela, whether President Hugo Chavez likes it or not.
"We would expect to be part of it and others would expect us to be part of it," said Richard Boucher, a State Department spokesman. After initial opposition, the United States now supports the creation of a "Friends of Venezuela" group to help mediation by the secretary general of the Organization of American States, Cesar Gaviria. 
Otto J. Reich, the United States special envoy to Latin America, discussed the plans on Tuesday with Mr. Gaviria in Quito, where they were attending the inauguration of the new Ecuadorean president, Lucio Gutierrez. 
Earlier, Mr. Chavez, who also attended Mr. Gutierrez's inauguration, had signaled that he did not want Washington to take part in meetings to set up the group.

CORRECTION-DATE: January 18, 2003

 CORRECTION:
A nurse quoted in an article on Thursday about the impact of a national strike on day-to-day life in Venezuela says the article misstated the context of her comments. The nurse, Nicolasa Veita, who works at the Centro Medico Caracas, said, "The doctors are looking for an excuse to close the hospitals and blame it on the government." Later, in the presence of Centro Medico administrators, Ms. Veita said her comments had referred to Vargas Hospital, a public facility, where she also works, not to the Centro Medico.

HEADLINE: Yahoo Plans Big Expansion Of Broadband 

BYLINE:  By SAUL HANSELL 

 BODY:
Buoyed by its growing sales and profits, Yahoo is planning to take its high-speed Internet access service nationwide.
 Yesterday, the big Internet portal announced better-than-expected financial results for the fourth quarter of 2002. It was able to expand its sales of online advertising, even as it added new services that generate monthly fees from users. 
 One of the fastest-growing of those services is high-speed, or broadband, Internet access, which Yahoo now offers as a co-branded service with SBC Communications, the phone company that serves about one-third of the nation. 
"Sometime this year, if you are a Yahoo user, you will have the ability to be part of Yahoo broadband all over the country," Terry S. Semel, Yahoo's chief executive, said in an interview yesterday.
In particular, he said that cable companies, which until now have tried to promote their own broadband services, are now preparing to open their networks to a variety of offerings. Yahoo, he said, will compete with America Online, Microsoft and EarthLink in providing broadband services over cable. Mr. Semel said Yahoo would explain its broadband strategy at a meeting with investors next month.
Safa Rashtchy, an analyst with U.S. Bancorp Piper Jaffray, said that such deals had the potential to be significant for Yahoo. "SBC hasn't produced a lot of revenue for Yahoo yet, but we estimate it will be $100 million this year," he said. "If they get the other two-thirds of the country, that could be $300 million a year."
Over all, Yahoo earned $46.2 million for the quarter, in contrast to a loss of $8.7 million a year ago. Last year, however, Yahoo had to write off some acquisition-related costs that are no longer required. If current accounting rules prevailed, it would have had a profit of $6.8 million in the fourth quarter of 2001. Yahoo's profit comes to 8 cents a share, better than the 6 cents analysts expected. The company posted sales of $285.8 million, up 51 percent from a year earlier. Excluding HotJobs, an employment site that Yahoo acquired early last year, its sales would have risen 31 percent.
Fee-based services were the fastest-growing area for Yahoo. It said it had a combined total of 2.2 million subscribers for its broadband service; a dial-up Internet service, also offered with SBC; its rapidly growing online personals service; and a range of other, smaller offerings. That is up from 375,000 subscribers a year ago. Revenue from those services, which also includes the HotJobs site it acquired in January 2002, was $9.4 million. Excluding HotJobs, that represented a 65 percent increase.
But online advertising, which is plummeting at rivals like America Online, also performed well for Yahoo. Its advertising sales rose 31 percent to $177.5 million, largely as a result of sales of text advertising on its search pages and other advertising products for small businesses. 
Yahoo also boasted that it had been able to create big animated ad formats that big national advertisers find increasingly appealing. In a conference call with investors, Mr. Semel said that Yahoo had recently expanded its sales to Gap and General Motors, among others.
A big priority for this year, he said, is advertising related to Web searches, Yahoo's original service. Largely as a result of its deal to incorporate paid listings from Overture Services, its revenue from search advertising was $120 million last year, about 20 percent of its total. Yahoo is hoping to increase this by putting search-related advertising on other areas of its site. And last month, it agreed to buy Intkomi, a maker of search software, to help its search service win back users who have defected to Google.
Mr. Semel said the company expected its overall advertising sales to grow at least 20 percent this year.
Yahoo's advertising sales rose in each quarter of last year, but the company has yet to reach the heights of its business in the dot-com boom. For all of last year, Yahoo's sales were $953 million -- up from $717 million in 2001, but below the $1.1 billion level of 2000.
But Yahoo yesterday increased its guidance for financial results this year. It now expects to post revenue of $1.14 to $1.21 billion for the year, beating its record. 
Mr. Semel said that the company was confident of this sales increase of 20 percent to 27 percent, even if the economy and the advertising environment did not improve. 
Moreover, he said, the company can grow while keeping a tight lid on costs. As a result, it expects its earnings before income tax, depreciation and amortization, a measure of cash flow popular with media companies, to increase 43 percent to 60 percent this year. Those earnings last year were $206 million.
Yahoo reported that its user base continued to grow briskly. Its audience worldwide, excluding Japan, was 213 million people in December, up from 188 million a year earlier. 
Mr. Semel said that this user base, most of whom buy Internet access from America Online, Microsoft's MSN and others, creates the best opportunity for Yahoo's expanding broadband offering.
"Every time a Yahoo user comes in contact with Yahoo, we can talk about our own broadband service," he said.

HEADLINE: Bush Aide Sees Deficit in 2003 Of $200 Billion 

BYLINE:  By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM and EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 

 BODY:
The White House said today that the federal deficit was likely to exceed $200 billion this fiscal year and probably hit $300 billion next year. 
 The ballooning deficits -- the largest ever in dollar terms but smaller relative to the economy than deficits in the 1980's and early 1990's -- could put President Bush's tax plan in peril. 
 This afternoon, 11 moderate senators -- five Republicans and six Democrats -- met to discuss their qualms about the president's proposals and made plans to draft alternative tax legislation. 
The group's consensus, a participant said, was that the tax plan was too costly and that its centerpiece, the elimination of individual income taxes on most stock dividends, would not help the economy enough.
Senator Charles E. Grassley, Republican of Iowa, the most influential senator on tax legislation, said in an interview that the president's tax package would probably have to be changed to get it through the Senate. 
The deficit forecasts were made by Mitchell E. Daniels Jr., the president's budget director, in answer to questions after a speech at the United States Chamber of Commerce here. The estimates assume enactment of the tax plan but do not take account of the potential cost of a war with Iraq, which officials have said could be $50 billion or more.
The forecasts are in line with those of many private economists, but this was the first time the administration had acknowledged the magnitude of the expected deficits.
Mr. Daniels did not spell out his exact deficit projections, which will be published in early February as part of the administration's budget for the 2004 fiscal year, which begins on Oct. 1. 
But he said the deficit would equal 2 percent or 3 percent of the nation's gross domestic product in the next year or two. With an annual economy of roughly $10 trillion, that would translate to deficits of $200 billion to $300 billion.
Providing additional detail, Mr. Daniels said the president's tax plan would add several "scores of billions" to the deficit in 2003 and about $100 billion to the deficit in 2004. 
Coming on top of last year's budget deficit, which was $159 billion, that means the president's tax plan alone could increase the shortfall to $250 billion by 2004 and new spending for domestic security and other priorities could raise the total above $300 billion. The budget Mr. Bush submitted to Congress a year ago forecast a deficit of $80 billion for fiscal year 2003, which ends on Sept. 30, $14 billion for 2004 and surpluses thereafter.
Mr. Daniels suggested today that the budget was not likely to be in surplus in the next 10 years. But he and other administration officials emphasized that the anticipated shortfalls of 2 percent to 3 percent of the nation's gross domestic product were modest in relation to the size of the entire economy.
"We ought not to hyperventilate about this," he told reporters. "By any historical measure, these are manageable deficits."
The deficit reached 6 percent of the economy in the mid-1980's under President Ronald Reagan and was more than 4.5 percent in the last two years of the administration of President Bush's father.
When Bill Clinton became president in 1993, he raised taxes, the economy boomed and the deficit shrank steadily. From 1998 through 2001 the government ran a surplus. 
Then the economy turned sour, taxes were cut and security spending was increased after the terrorist attacks. In the fiscal year 2002, which ended last September, the deficit was $159 billion.
Mr. Daniels's remarks provided new grist for Democrats critical of the administration's economic agenda. Senator Kent Conrad of North Dakota, the top Democrat on the Budget Committee, called the administration's policy reckless and asserted, "It's amazing how these guys have gone from being conservative to radical with respect to economic views."
The deficit was also on the minds of the moderate senators at the meeting on taxes this afternoon.
"I am concerned about the size of the president's package at a time when we have pressing needs and are possibly on the verge of a second war with Iraq," one participant, Senator Susan Collins, Republican of Maine, said.
The other Republicans at the meeting were Senators Olympia J. Snowe of Maine, Lincoln Chafee of Rhode Island, George V. Voinovich of Ohio and Norm Coleman of Minnesota. The Democrats were John B. Breaux of Louisiana, Blanche Lincoln and Mark Pryor, both of Arkansas, Dianne Feinstein of California, Max Baucus of Montana and Thomas R. Carper of Delaware. 
They agreed that their staffs would immediately begin meeting to develop an alternative tax plan to the president's. Some senators expressed doubt about whether any tax cut was wise, but they were in the minority, one of those present said. But nearly all the senators had concerns about the proposed elimination of taxes on most dividends.
"I question whether this is truly stimulative," Senator Collins said.
With the Senate so closely divided -- 51 Republicans, 48 Democrats and an independent who votes with the Democrats -- and almost all Democrats opposed to Mr. Bush's tax proposal, any Republican defections put the plan in jeopardy.
Senator Grassley, who is chairman of the Finance Committee, attended the meeting with the moderates to take soundings. He said that the president's plan was basically sound and that "I agree with most of it."
But he added, "I have to be realistic, and I want the president to be realistic that I've got to have some flexibility to work a bipartisan majority."
For his part, Mr. Grassley suggested that scrapping the tax on dividends, which accounts for $364 billion of the $674 billion 10-year revenue loss from the tax proposals, would not have been his top priority. 
He said he wished the president had "put more emphasis" on lowering tax rates. He said he also would prefer a tax cut directed more at small businesses and less at dividend-paying corporations. Those steps, Mr. Grassley said, would create more jobs and help the economy more than the president's package.
Mr. Daniels conceded that the dividend proposal had generated opposition, and his tone and body language suggested that the administration would not be rigid.
"It's clearly going to be the focal point of dispute," he said. "There's going to be a lot of give and take, absolutely."
Some private economists predict a significantly higher shortfall than that projected by Mr. Daniels. For example, Edward McKelvey, a senior economist at Goldman Sachs, said today that the deficit could reach $300 billion this year and $375 billion in 2004.
Asked about impending deficits at a breakfast meeting with reporters, R. Glenn Hubbard, chairman of the president's Council of Economic Advisers, replied, "What matters is what you're doing with the money."
Using it for a party is unacceptable, Mr. Hubbard said, but using it to invest in future growth is good policy.
Asked whether cutting taxes at the same time a war was being fought was tantamount to a party, he said: "We're not throwing a party. We're encouraging business investment."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Supreme Court Upholds Extension of Copyright
The Supreme Court upheld the 20-year extension that Congress granted in 1998 to existing copyrights, declaring that while the extension might have been bad policy, it fell clearly within the authority of Congress.
 The decision came in the court's most closely watched intellectual property case in years, one with financial implications in the billions of dollars. A victory for the Hollywood studios and other big copyright holders, the ruling will keep the original Mickey Mouse as well as other icons of mid-century American culture from slipping into the public domain. Page A24. 

Deficit Expected to Top $200 Billion
The White House said the federal deficit would exceed $200 billion in this fiscal year and probably go over $300 billion next year, with deficits continuing for the next decade. A1.

Unwanted Attention for Hedge Fund
The disclosure that a stock trader at SAC Capital Advisors, the company owned by Steven A. Cohen, is being investigated by securities regulators for possible insider trading may put Mr. Cohen and SAC under a spotlight that by all accounts he would rather avoid. C2.

Tougher Accounting Rules Offered
The nation's accounting rulemakers took steps intended to make it harder for companies to hide debts and assets from their shareholders. At the same time, the Securities and Exchange Commission adopted rules aimed at changing other practices that were thrown into a harsh light by recent financial scandals. C4.

Goldman Sachs Invests in Japan
Goldman Sachs placed a major bet on a revival in Japanese asset values, agreeing to buy several hotels from a troubled retailer and $1.3 billion in preferred shares from a major bank. World Business, Section W.

Parsons Is Likely Successor at AOL
As the directors of AOL Time Warner prepare to meet today, Richard D. Parsons, the chief executive, is emerging as the most likely successor to chairman Stephen M. Case. C4.

Investor Takes Control of Globalstar
Globalstar, the bankrupt satellite phone company, agreed to sell control of itself to New Valley, an investment firm run by Bennett S. LeBow, for $55 million. C9.

Apple Reports a Loss for Quarter
Apple Computer reported that it lost money in its first quarter on revenues that were slightly weaker than expectations. Apple's lost $8 million, or 2 cents a share. That compares with a profit of $38 million in the year-earlier quarter. Its quarterly revenues were $1.47 billion. The results were hurt by a $17 million charge for discontinued operations. C6.

Share Prices Fall Sharply
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 119.44 points, to 8,723.18. The Nasdaq dropped 22.19 points, to 1,438.80. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock fell 13.44 points, to 918.22. C10.

Oil prices rose to $33.21 a barrel after an Energy Department agency reported that inventories of crude oil declined to near their lowest levels in more than two decades. C10.

The economy's current "soft patch" extended into early January, the Federal Reserve said in its beige book, as consumers were cautious about spending over the holidays. C6.

Tax-Free Dividends and the Market
Examining the long-term implications of President Bush's plan to eliminate taxes on stock dividends while putting aside the short-run politics and macroeconomic stimulus. Economic Scene: Hal R. Varian C2.

HEADLINE: BUSH AND AFFIRMATIVE ACTION: THE CONTEXT; 
With His Eye on Two Political Prizes, the President Picks His Words Carefully

BYLINE:  By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 

 BODY:
In announcing today that his administration would urge the Supreme Court to declare the University of Michigan's admissions program unconstitutional, President Bush was careful to present a hard-line decision to intervene in the case with soft language, as he has with great effectiveness throughout his public career. 
 He denounced "the wrong of racial prejudice" and emphasized the value to society of racial diversity. In a sign of the careful political calibration of his words, the president repeatedly used the term "quotas," to describe Michigan's admissions policy, a word that inevitably draws strong opposition in polls. 
 The president's firmly worded decision will no doubt bolster his standing with the crucial conservative wing of the Republican Party, whose leaders expressed delight and relief as they learned of his position. Once again, Mr. Bush seems to be drawing a lesson from the missteps of his father, whose failure as president to tend to those on the right contributed to his defeat in 1992. 
Mr. Bush took his stand on the Michigan case nearly two years before Election Day, perhaps allowing time for him to try to repair any damage his decision may deal to efforts to widen the Republican Party's appeal to blacks, Hispanics and moderate voters.
During his 2000 campaign, Mr. Bush tried to cast himself as an inclusive "big tent" Republican. His political advisers have told him he must do better in 2004, because minority populations are expanding in so many closely divided states.
And it is no small matter that Mr. Bush took this stand less than a month after his White House helped push Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the former Senate Republican leader, out of his leadership post for remarks that were criticized as racially insensitive.
For all that, Mr. Bush's decision today would seem to be highly risky, coming at a moment of turmoil for the Republican Party, and at the very moment when the Democratic presidential competition has begun. While Mr. Bush and his party have been trying, with success, to distance themselves from Mr. Lott, today's decision by the president offered Democrats another opportunity to present the party as hostile to civil rights -- and thus to mobilize minority voters. 
They wasted no time in doing so. Democratic critics of today's announcement included presidential candidates, like Senators John Edwards and John Kerry and Representative Richard A. Gephardt, as well as figures like Senator Tom Daschle, the minority leader, and the Rev. Jesse Jackson.
"Frankly, I don't understand it," said David Bositis, senior political analyst at the Joint Center for Political and Economic Studies, a liberal-leaning research organization as he considered the political implications of the stand for the White House. "Hispanics support affirmative action as much as blacks do. Even in terms of suburban whites, they have to worry -- this makes it much more difficult for them to keep up their political appearance of being 'compassionate conservatives.' "
Conservatives hailed Mr. Bush's decision as correct, brave and reassuring -- especially given that it happened so soon after Mr. Lott's ouster -- as well as in keeping with his past positions.
"There's been a battle for his heart and mind on the issue since the Trent Lott business," said William J. Bennett, a prominent conservative who had urged Mr. Bush to intervene in the case.
"A number of people feared that people would take the Trent Lott episode and misinterpret that, and think this would require that the Republicans and the president to pander and go supine before the civil rights establishment," Mr. Bennett said.
Ralph Reed, the Georgia Republican chairman, said Mr. Bush's statement "was consistent with his view that we need to maximize opportunities for all Americans without discriminating against anyone -- which I think is good public policy."
Some conservatives described themselves as not only delighted but also a bit surprised that Mr. Bush had come down where he had. A few staunch opponents of affirmative action also fretted that the administration's legal brief, to be filed on Thursday, might be more narrowly drawn.
A review of Mr. Bush's public record -- from his time as governor of Texas to these busy weeks since the turn of the year -- would suggest there should be no surprise in what he did, or how he did it.
Even Mr. Bush's detractors said today that they believed his decision to oppose the program, no matter how much it heartened his conservative supporters, reflected genuine feelings. When he was governor, Mr. Bush applauded a decision by a federal appeals court overturning a similar admissions program used by the University of Texas. 
More tellingly, though, was the way Mr. Bush presented his position. In Washington as in Texas, he took a stand praised for its ideological clarity by conservatives, but with language that seemed designed for broad political appeal.
"The modus operandi is to speak centrally and act from the right," Bruce Buchanan, a professor of government at the University of Texas, said tonight. "The conservative constituencies won, because they got exactly what they want. And the minority constituency, who is exactly what the Republican Party is courting, get the soft words."
Mr. Buchanan noted that in Texas, Mr. Bush had proclaimed his support for "affirmative access" even as he rigorously opposed programs that many Democrats said would accomplish that result. And, he noted, Mr. Bush enjoyed a huge and unwavering support from Latino voters in Texas.
That effective use of language, and the ability to present conservative positions while still appealing to a broad political spectrum, is without doubt a hallmark of Mr. Bush's political skill. Several Democrats, reviewing Mr. Bush's speech today, compared it to the way he had framed his call to eliminate the tax on stock dividends last week, and the way he endorsed strict limits on stem-cell research last year.
Mr. Bush may have wider latitude to make the kind of moves now that might prove more difficult a year hence. His announcement came after he has pursued the appointment of conservative judges to the federal bench, and after he released a second plan of tax cuts. 
Aides to some of the Democrats, while not disputing his ideological commitment to conservative causes, suggested that Mr. Bush was dealing with the right side of the agenda today, precisely so that he would have flexibility when he finds himself in the middle of a re-election campaign. While some Democrats described what Mr. Bush was doing as calculating and even a bit cynical, there was also a bit of admiration for what the White House was doing.
"There's no question I understand his calculation," said Steve Elmendorf, a senior adviser to Mr. Gephardt, who filed a brief today with the court urging it to uphold the program. "They are feeling pretty good about where they are so they can take a few of these. It's not like they are in a precarious position."
"But this is not a 'compassionate conservative' move," Mr. Elmendorf said. 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times; 
They're All Amateurs. Go Figure.

BYLINE:  By SELENA ROBERTS 

DATELINE: DALLAS 

 BODY:
THERE is a teenage phenom with the vertical leap of an astronaut on a moonscape who possesses the flair of a Vegas act and enough potential to rock a sport. LeBron James? No, Sasha Cohen. 
 There is a high school senior with a life story that has unfolded on TV who doesn't have an agent, but has companies panting like groupies wanting to turn the hot teenager's head. This could be King James, but it's Sarah Hughes. 
 There is an S.U.V.-driving athlete who has graced magazine covers since age 16, a captivating star who cannot gaze into the future without a camera lens there to project the thought to a national audience. If this wasn't Michelle Kwan, it could be Gloria James's son.
But amateur status isn't one size fits all. All of these young stars have been exploited by their sports. Pick your poison: little girls skating in plunging necklines, or a peek at LeBron's hoop skills on pay-per-view.
All unsavoriness being equal, the Olympic skaters are the ones given a quid pro quo, allowed to take from the takers. After rolling into Texas this week, Hughes, Cohen and Kwan will compete for the national title even though they all have spent the off-season stuffing ice-show money into their cookie jars.
Why not? The life span of an Olympic skater ends before 20. Or does it? At age 22, Kwan has raked in an average of $5 million a year for nearly seven years. No gold, no problem. 
"It's clear that she is past the point to where the gold medal is the be-all, end-all to her popularity," said Kwan's agent, Shep Goldberg. "It was true after Nagano, and it has proven true after Salt Lake. She's at a level of public awareness and acceptance that supersedes the Olympics."
If so, why not turn pro? Just the illusion of another chance at Olympic redemption for Kwan is more lucrative than becoming another lounge act on the slumping pro exhibition scene. 
"What is life without competition?" Kwan said after her practice today. "It's hard, but it's something I love. I'm nervous right now, because I'm human. But I feel that as long as I can keep up the drive, why not? 
"You'd think that after six nationals, I'd be, 'O.K., that's enough,' " Kwan added, referring to her six United States titles. "But I was on the phone with a few skaters on tour, and I said, 'I'd either be on the tour bus with you, doing exhibitions, or I'd be competing.' I've chosen this road."
Kwan's car on this journey? A Chevy Tahoe. No investigation into its purchase necessary. Her amateur status is safe. 
If James could only muster a quadruple axel, he could steer his 2003 pewter-colored Hummer H2 down the streets of Akron, Ohio, without rousing the eligibility police. 
As it is, the Ohio High School Athletic Association is investigating the increasingly murky waters of amateurism. Officials are looking into whether James's unemployed mother financed the car legitimately (perhaps using her son's name as collateral), or if the 18th birthday present was a gift from an outsider that violates the state's amateur bylaws. 
The inquiry must be made. There is something of a double standard here, but it's necessary when applied to James's situation.
Given that he doesn't intend to play in college, and is expected to be the N.B.A.'s top draft pick, some believe James has just as much right to the dough he generates as the vendors who hawk his jerseys. But there is no more room for pro treatment at the high-school level. One Sonny Vaccaro on the loose is enough. Unaccountable gift-giving only fans the seediness spreading through prep-age athletics. Shoe wars? How about car wars?
What may seem fair for one special player is not in the best interest of the majority. If an investigation leads to a violation, James can move on, punching the pedal, with millions just months away. His St. Vincent-St. Mary teammates, however, could have their wonder season crushed.
And to think, James probably alerted officials with his own horn. If anything, that is the more unfair issue here. If his mom had given him a Ford Bronco, would the outcry be the same? Somehow, poor kids in fantasy cars trigger disdain in the mainstream. Pimp-mobiles, some mumble in stereotype.
Olympians? They're all so pure, aren't they? An ice darling can drive a Zamboni or a Mercedes, and no one blinks at all. In the world of skating, the amateurs have purchase power.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Michelle Kwan (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Czech Deputies Fail to Pick Successor to Havel 

BYLINE:  By PETER S. GREEN 

DATELINE: PRAGUE, Jan. 15 

 BODY:
The Czech Parliament failed today to elect a successor to the departing President Vaclav Havel. A second balloting is expected after Mr. Havel steps down on Feb. 2.
 A divided Parliament, led by an equally fractured center-left coalition government, could not agree on a successor to Mr. Havel, the playwright and rights activist who led his countrymen to overthrow Communist rule in the 1989 velvet revolution. 
 The election is widely seen as a vote by parliamentarians on the legacy of Mr. Havel's 13 years as president. Despite a commanding early lead, Mr. Havel's longtime political nemesis, the rightist former prime minister Vaclav Klaus, was unable to win the required majority in a contest against the Senate president, Petr Pithart, a long-time Havel ally backed by the government's minority Christian Democrats.
The next president needs an outright majority in both the 200-seat Chamber of Deputies and the 81-seat Senate. In the last round today, Mr. Klaus secured 80 votes in the lower house, and 33 votes in the Senate. Mr. Pithart won the backing of 44 deputies and 40 senators.
News reports said that in the next round of voting, expected in mid-February, the governing Social Democrats would probably nominate their former leader, Milos Zeman, who was prime minister from 1998 until last year. Supporters of Mr. Pithart said it was not clear whether he would run again.
Analysts say a victory by either Mr. Zeman or Mr. Klaus would probably bring down the government, led by the Social Democrat prime minister, Vladimir Spidla, a bitter enemy of Mr. Zeman, and could jeopardize the outcome of a vital referendum expected this spring on joining the European Union.
In a farewell speech that prompted a standing ovation in the ornate Spanish Hall of Prague Castle before Parliament began a long day of horse-trading and back-room politicking over his successor, Mr. Havel urged members to work for freedom and dignity for all Czech citizens.
Mr. Havel said he was confident they would elect a "good" leader and urged them to follow their consciences.
"We were elected," he said, "in the hope that we would do what, according to our knowledge and convictions, is in the long-term interests of human society as a whole; what is in the interest of freedom, security and dignity for all of us; what is in the interest of our life in peace and prosperity." 
Mr. Klaus, who openly detests Mr. Havel, earlier told journalists, "I think that Vaclav Havel has only been interested in himself for the past 13 years."
Mr. Havel said that as a citizen who has never been able "to keep silent" on public affairs, he would not withdraw from public life, but that he would for the time being withdraw and reflect before jumping back into the fray.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Vaclav Havel, the Czech president, left the Spanish Hall of Prague Castle yesterday after his farewell address. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES; 
Why Your Waitron Can Serve Brunch but Not Linner

BYLINE:  By MICHIKO KAKUTANI

 BODY:
PREDICTING NEW WORDS
The Secrets of Their Success
By Allan Metcalf
Illustrated. 206 pages. Houghton Mifflin Company. $22.
 Why do some new words become staples of our everyday language while others fade away? Why have words and phrases like "moonlighting," "politically correct" and "yuppie" entered the mainstream, while other recently minted ones like "velcroid" (a person who sticks by the president, "especially for photo opportunities"), "prosultant" (emphasizing the positive in the consulting business) and "shuicide bomber" ("terrorist with bomb in shoes") have failed to catch on? 
 Why did "server" as a gender-neutral term for waiter or waitress prevail over "waitron"? Why do restaurants serve "brunch" but not "linner"? Why did "Lilliputian" catch on, but not "Brobdingnagian"?
In tackling such questions, Allan Metcalf, executive secretary of the American Dialect Society, has come up with an intriguing idea for a book. But while "Predicting New Words" is filled with interesting tidbits and asides, the book as a whole is full of holes and flawed by a dogmatic and not always logical thesis.
It is Mr. Metcalf's contention that you can tell what words are likely to survive by applying a simple formula involving what he calls the FUDGE factors: the Frequency with which a new word is used; the Unobtrusiveness of the new word, meaning its ability to slip unnoticed into daily usage without calling attention to itself; Diversity of users and situations in which the new word is employed; Generation of other forms and meanings (i.e., "Watergate" giving birth to "Travelgate" and "Whitewatergate"); and Endurance of the concept, meaning that the idea to which the new word refers proves durable over time (unlike, say, Y2K).
Other factors, Mr. Metcalf argues, do not matter much. It doesn't matter whether a word is new: chad, for instance, had been around for ages before achieving celebrity with the messy 2000 election standoff in Florida; in contrast, a phrase like Saddam Hussein's "mother of all" locution was a new formulation that quickly caught on.
While new creations or phenomena sometimes get a new name -- like "software" or "affirmative action" -- gaps in the language are not always filled: a compelling and widely embraced name for the first decade of the 21st century has yet to be found, though many suggestions like "the aughts," "the naughts," "the zeros" and "the oh-ohs" have been floated. Nor does an existing term for an idea or concept rule out the adoption of trendy new phrases: running amok and going berserk, for instance, did not preclude the introduction of "going postal" in the 1990's.
Intriguing as some of Mr. Metcalf's observations are, his overarching thesis about predicting the staying power of new words remains unconvincing. In the first place, he doesn't back up his theory with enough examples to make it feel fully grounded. "Predicting New Words" seems highly cursory in the extreme. It pays little attention to the role that popular culture has played in promoting new words and phrases: no discussion of words from movies like "neuralizer" (from "Men in Black") or "hurl" (given a popular new meaning by "Wayne's World") and scant discussion of computer slang and teenage talk as well.
In addition, some of the examples Mr. Metcalf cites in support of his thesis are decidedly dubious. His citation of "Frankenfood" ("a scary word for genetically modified foods") as "a fairly successful new word" is debatable at best, as is his contention that the phrase "sex kitten" is obsolete.
Of the five FUDGE factors, he says, "Unobtrusiveness seems especially important." He argues that people use words to make jokes but don't want the words themselves to be jokes: "The more general principle is that a word shouldn't call attention to itself, by humor or by any other means -- its looks or origin, for example. If it does attract notice, chances are it will be rejected." 
This principle, however, seems to be contradicted by some of the examples Mr. Metcalf cites. "Couch potato," for one, was a term based around the comical image of a fat, dumpy creature perched on a sofa, all eyes on the television, and wordplay stemming from a term for television aficionados: "tubers." As for "gerrymander," it has roots in a 19th-century joke about Eldridge Gerry, a Massachusetts governor who rearranged the election districts in the state to the advantage of the Democratic party. Although Mr. Metcalf argues that these words succeeded only when their jokey beginnings were forgotten, the fact remains that they began life as humorous constructions.
Words like "googol" and "scofflaw" challenge Mr. Metcalf's belief that successful new words tend not to be conspicuous or bizarre. And his assertion in one chapter that "relatively few foreign words are directly imported into our language with success" because "they look too foreign" is contradicted by his observation, in another chapter, that "English is famous for swallowing words whole from other languages."
One additional oddity of this book is the amount of space it devotes to examples of ungrammatical language and plain old-fashioned gaffes, most notably those made by President George W. Bush. Among the famous Bushisms cited in this book are: his use of terms like "mential" ("This is still a dangerous world. It's a world of madmen and uncertainty and potential mential losses") and "misunderestimate" ("They misunderestimated me"), and his substitution of "hostile" for "hostage" ("We cannot let terrorists and rogue nations hold this nation hostile or hold our allies hostile") and "anecdote" for "antidote" ("A tax cut is really one of the anecdotes to coming out of an economic illness").
The problem is that in citing such examples, Mr. Metcalf is himself confusing grammatical mistakes with innovation: just one of the stumbles in this book that makes it a lot less persuasive than it might have been.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Allan Metcalf (MacMurray College)

HEADLINE: ART REVIEW; 
Pedigreed Feast of Winter Is Back at the Armory

BYLINE:  By GRACE GLUECK

 BODY:
The Winter Antiques Show, an enticing consumerama whose goods range from massive pedigreed furniture to petite pocket tchotchkes, is back in its element at the Seventh Regiment Armory after last year's switch to the Hilton Hotel. And its officials and organizers seem much, much happier.
 The switch was engendered by 9/11 and the National Guard's need for more of an operational base at the Armory in case of another attack. But dealers and buyers apparently did not feel that the Midtown hotel site was right for the prestigious show. 
 "It's an East Side institution," one dealer said, "and the Hilton location on Sixth Avenue confused people. They weren't used to going out of their ZIP code. The disaster itself and the change it occasioned were a double whammy." 
This year, despite the downturn in the economy, dealers seem optimistic that buyers will not sit on their pocketbooks. Some objects scheduled to appear in the show, in fact, have already been sold. "A catalog I sent out recently got one of the best responses ever," said Donald Ellis, a Canadian dealer whose gallery specializes in American Indian artifacts.
Helen Fioratti of L'Antiquaire & the Connoisseur, a New York gallery, said: "Although the market is not doing well, people are looking for alternatives for their money. They're investing in art so at least they can make their surroundings enjoyable."
The show, now in its 49th year, was established in 1955 as a benefit for the East Side Settlement House, a Bronx-based social services agency more than a century old. The show is regarded as the most established and esteemed of the increasing number of stylish big-ticket antiques bazaars in cities across the country. Although it includes fine and decorative art objects from Europe and Asia, its strength lies in Americana, with more than one-third of its objects from the United States.
Its opening gala, which traditionally kicks off the winter social season, was last night. And the event is expected to draw an attendance of 25,000 during its 10-day run. "It's a very buyable show," said Arie L. Kopelman, chairman of the event and president of Chanel U.S.A. "People come here expecting to find not only museum pieces, but a nice little something they can tuck under an arm and go home with."
Its 70 dealers make a highly eclectic mix, specializing in items like rare books and manuscripts, carpets and tapestries, jewelry, ceramics, furniture, folk art, paintings, textiles, military items, nautical artifacts, garden antiques, prints, silver and portrait miniatures.
Most are regulars at the show, but one, the Richard Green Gallery of London, has dropped out on short notice this year. The show's officials would not comment on the matter. But other dealers pointed out that the gallery was one of several that sold art to L. Dennis Kozlowski, the former chairman and chief executive of Tyco International, who last June was charged with evading New York City sales tax on his purchases. They speculated that a New York appearance for the London gallery could result in a subpoena.
Reached in London on Wednesday, a spokesman said the gallery had no comment. When the Kozlowski story broke in June, however, the gallery denied any violation of New York law and said it was cooperating fully with the investigation into the Kozlowski transactions.
Furniture, naturally, is one of the hottest categories. At the top of the line are major pieces like the early 19th-century Sheraton-style Regency sideboard at Philip Colleck Ltd., a mahogany bow-front fitted out with lead-lined, mahogany-covered hot-water urns. There is also a very proper Queen Anne bonnet-top highboy at G. K. S. Bush, made in Boston in the mid-18th century for the merchant John Rowe. Its $325,000 price is justified by the fact that it retains its original finish.
At Hirschl & Adler, the prize is a recently discovered center table, a stately statement in rosewood and mahogany with a round marble top, produced in New York around 1815 to 1819 by the French-born cabinet maker Charles-Honore Lannuier, a rival of Duncan Phyfe.
Phyfe, too has a handsome presence here in the form of several furniture pieces attributed to him at Carswell Rush Berlin. One is a rare, drop-dead mahogany sofa in Grecian style, with five intricately carved panels, circa 1815, and there are also six Federal carved Phyfe-attributed mahogany side chairs with similar carving.
A more recent counterpart to these early exquisites is an elegant low-slung sofa as wide as a daybed at Barry Friedman Ltd. Of palisander wood with ivory insets, it was made around 1920-22 by the distinguished French designer Jacques-Emile Ruhlmann. Among furniture items might also be included a smashing grille of gilt bronze and opalescent glass at Geoffrey Diner of Washington that ranks among the show's top 10. Designed by Louis Comfort Tiffany, it was part of a running balustrade in the now-demolished Havemeyer town house in New York.
This is not the show to seek out art of an avant-garde persuasion, but older treasures in the field are not in short supply. At Joan B. Mirviss Ltd., specializing in Japanese fine art, one standout is the naturalistic "Three Cranes by the Shore," a painting on silk with sprinkled gold leaf done around 1820 by the master Keibun, noted for bird and flower painting.
The London-based Fine Arts Society is showing a touching Pre-Raphaelite-style painting by John Roddam Spencer-Stanhope (1829-1908), depicting Ulysses's wife, Penelope, at her loom, with head in hand as she mourns for her long-departed husband. At the Connecticut dealer Peter Tillou's booth, a large and gorgeous image of a floral wreath meant to surround a mirror is attributed to the 17th-century Italian painter Giovanni Stanchi.
Elle Shushan, who deals in portrait miniatures, is offering, among other lively examples of this long-neglected art, a tiny likeness on ivory of Louis XVI, his crown floating above his head as cherubic angels dance around it. It is an apotheosis done in 1798, five years after the ruler's execution, by his miniaturist Pierre-Noel Violet, and presented to the king's only surviving daughter, the Duchesse d'Angouleme.
A knockout sculptural work is a splendid 14th-century Neapolitan tomb effigy at the English dealer Peter Finer. A life-size knightly figure in full regalia faithfully carved in marble, it is thought to depict a member of the Ferretti family of Ancona, vassals of the French court of Anjou, which ruled the area at the time.
Folk art, from painted furniture to children's toys, is a vital part of the show, and what's here doesn't disappoint. One appealing piece is a wool merchant's trade sign, at the London dealer Robert Young. Carved in flat pine and painted, with a stick-out horn of real bone and a glass eye, the sign depicts a fat, cuddly sheep plentifully garbed in carved wool.
Olde Hope Antiques of New Hope, Pa., has fine examples of painted furniture, namely a blanket chest by Moses Eaton (circa 1825 to 1835), one of two chests extant by this well-known wall stenciler. It is adorned with a variety of wall stencil patterns, along with flower and leaf motifs. Well worth inspecting, too, is a blue two-section farmhouse cupboard, author unknown, dated around 1810 to 1820. It is stroked all over in a light, whimsical style known as feather painting, in an unusual combination of light and dark blues.
Eagles abound, as might be expected. One magnificent pair, massive in scale, carved in wood and painted gold, date from 1840. Among the largest carved eagles known, they are roosting temporarily at Hyland Granby of Hyannisport, having once graced a farmhouse in Essex, Mass.
What else? Why, the place is a veritable cornucopia. There are fabulous carpets at Keshishian, among them an imposing Arts and Crafts number in a red and green floral design by the English architect C. F. A. Voysey, circa 1900, and an intricate, splendidly worked 17th-century Caucasian known as the "Gohar Carpet" at Peter Pap Oriental Rugs of Dublin, N.H.
At S. J. Shrubsole, there is silver no well-appointed home should be without, including a coffeepot by Paul Revere, circa 1760, once owned by the merchant David Sears of Boston. At Aronson of Amsterdam, there are brilliant examples of Dutch delftware, among them a very rare 18th-century black basin charmingly adorned with floral motifs. (If you thought delft was all blue and white, you're wrong.)
At Barbara Israel, there is awesome garden furniture, like the large rendition in marble of Diana the Huntress by the French sculptor Maximilien-Henri Hiolle, a 19th-century version of a 17th-century original by Antoine Coyzevox. (It turns out to be a portrait of the Duchess of Burgundy swanning as the goddess Diana, attended by a hunting dog.)
By now, you must have the picture. It also includes, not by the way, a splendid not-for-sale loan display of art, Americana and artifacts from the famous Shelburne Museum in Shelburne, Vt., that is the Winter Antiques Show's bonus.

The Winter Antiques Show is at the Seventh Regiment Armory, 643 Park Avenue, at 66th Street, through Jan. 26. Hours: daily, noon to 8:30 p.m., except Sunday and Thursday, noon to 6 p.m. Admission, $16, includes catalog. Information: (212) 628-0417.

GRAPHIC: Photo: A 1900's grille designed by Louis Comfort Tiffany is at Geoffrey Diner's booth at the Winter Antiques Show. (Geoffrey Diner Gallery)

HEADLINE: JOURNEYS; 
36 Hours Fort Myers, Fla.

BYLINE:  By LINDA SALISBURY

 BODY:
 WITHIN 24 hours of arriving in Fort Myers in March 1885, Thomas Edison bought 13 acres on the Caloosahatchee River, and before long he was planting palm trees along the dirt road between downtown and his spread. The road is now McGregor Boulevard, lined with thousands of royal palms (not all courtesy of Edison) and congested in tourist season, and Fort Myers is still seducing Northerners. Now a mally, sprawly city of 48,000, spawning suburban housing developments, it offers not only warmth and sunshine, but boating, beaches, spring-training Minnesota Twins and Boston Red Sox games, and a pedestrian-friendly downtown historic district with restored buildings and diet-busting restaurants. There are frequent downtown festivals, where retirees can impress their visiting families with their new outdoor lifestyle and rub shoulders with tourists and longtime Floridians. The largest is the Festival of Light, celebrating Edison's bulb, which began last week and runs through Feb. 15. For its big parade (Feb. 15 this year), people reserve viewing spots a week in advance along Cleveland Avenue by positioning their folding chairs, which no one disturbs. LINDA SALISBURY

Friday

5 p.m.
1) Slip Into Sandals
Shed heavy coats to stroll the winding walkways of Centennial Park on the Caloosahatchee River and sit for a moment by "Uncommon Friends," a fountain with statues of Edison, Henry Ford and Harvey Firestone. Wander out on the docks to look at sightseeing and dinner-cruise boats (J. C. Cruises, 239-334-7474), the yacht-filled city marina, and the new high-speed ferry that runs daily round trips between Fort Myers and Key West (Fast Cats, 239-332-7777). Take in the scene: teenagers huddled under a shelter, slapping bongos; a bicyclist pausing to toss chips to sea gulls; dozing fishermen along the seawall. Take a picture of the sherbet-hued sunset fringed with mangroves and coconut palms.

6:30 p.m.
2) Conch Sushi at Shannon
Head for Shannon (1406 Hendry Street, 239-689-2675), where brick walls, a fireplace, overstuffed chairs and the yellow pine bar offer the ideal setting for unwinding and imbibing. Have an appetizer of conch sushi ($4) or mussel tapas ($8) and a chocolate martini ($8).

8 p.m.
3) Music of the Night
Feast on good things for the palate and the ear at Ellington's Jazz Bar and Restaurant (2278 First Street, 239-337-5299; live jazz at 8 p.m. Fridays and Saturdays and 7 p.m. on weeknights). Try the smoked duck with sweet potato risotto and glazed turnips ($26) or the grilled New York strip steak ($26). Save room for the cocoa-flavored bread pudding with hazelnut ice cream and raspberry puree ($7). A gray-haired woman at a table one recent night confided that the man leading the combo and alternately playing sax, clarinet and jazz pennywhistle was her husband and had been with Tommy Dorsey's band.

Saturday

9 a.m.
4) On Broadway
Sit by the front door at Bara Bread Bistro (1520 Broadway, 239-334-8216) to visit with its Breton baker, Jean Pierre Cadiou, while you have coffee and a white omelet with spinach and tomato ($5.95) or a French pastry breakfast ($4.95). You may catch Mr. Cadiou mixing almond cream for king cakes, traditional in early winter. After breakfast, walk to the end of the block and check out Flowers to Fifties (2133 Main Street, 239-334-2443), which sells relics of the 1930's to the 1970's. Reminisce among polyester leisure suits, pointy bras and chrome toasters.

10:30 a.m.
5) An Electrifying Experience
Join other tourists at the winter homes (2350 McGregor Boulevard, 239-334-3614) of Edison and Ford, his neighbor after 1916, who, according to the tour guides, rolled up the rug here almost every day for a square dance with his guests. (Shown above in 1931, from left, are Ford, Edison and Firestone.) Tour the laboratory where the three experimented with goldenrod to make a rubber for tires, achieving some success. There are more than a thousand plants from around the world in Edison's botanical garden (9 a.m. to 5:30 p.m. Monday through Saturday; noon to 5:30 p.m. Sundays. Admission is $14 for adults, $7.50 for children).

Noon
6) Food Trumps Decor
Don't let the unimpressive ambience of Ida's Bon Appiteatery (2208 First Street, 239-332-8151), with its peachy paint and scuffed wooden booths, deter you from having homemade tomato bisque soup ($2.50) and a Reuben ($6.95) in this friendly neighborhood spot where thirtysomething locals mingle with out-of-towners.

1 p.m.
7) Do Downtown
Wander in the downtown historic district, making sure to look up at the ornate, colorful facades of commercial buildings dating to the late 19th and early 20th centuries. You will find outdoor restaurants, courtyards and fountains, a browsable independent bookstore called Shakespeare Beethoven & Company (1520 Broadway, 239-332-8300), and scattered antiques and gift shops. On the first Saturday of the month there is a walking tour here ($5 for adults and $3 for children, 239-332-5955) and streets close for an antiques and collectibles fair. The Arcade Theater, built in 1908, houses the Florida Repertory Theater (2267 First Street, 239-332-4488). The eclectic Southwest Florida Museum of History (2300 Peck Street, 9 a.m. to 4 p.m. Tuesday through Saturday, 239-332-5955; $6 for adults and $3 for children) offers a self-guided tour that starts with prehistoric animals and ends in a 1929 private Pullman railway car.

2:30 p.m.
8) Times Square, Beach Style
Pack your towels for a 16-mile drive (starting southwest on McGregor Boulevard for 10 miles, then turning left onto San Carlos Boulevard) to the town of Fort Myers Beach, a 30-minute trip if traffic is light. Once you cross the 65-foot-high Matanzas Pass bridge, turn right to find public parking; the wide, white sandy beach on the Gulf of Mexico; a fishing pier; and, yes, Times Square. Follow the brick path to the town clock hub, where Birdie McClarine, a street performer, recently juggled rubber chickens and flaming torches and spray-painted a picture of outer space. Snack on conch fritters ($7.95) and locally harvested steamed clams ($9.95) at the Beach Pierside Grill and Blowfish Bar (1000 Estero Boulevard, 239-765-7800), where you can watch parasailers, boaters, fishermen and the sunset over Sanibel Island. The restaurant offers free plastic sand pails and shovels to children who eat there.

7:30 p.m.
9) Polished Grits
For an elegant meal in an old-Florida setting, make reservations at Veranda (2122 Second Street, 239-332-2065). It is housed in two 100-year-old homes, above, that were joined by Peter Pulitzer, the publishing heir, in the 1970's. A garden courtyard is used for outdoor dining. Try artichoke fritters stuffed with blue crab ($7.95) or savor grit cakes with pepper cheese ($6.95). Then dine on local grouper with blue crab hash and a caper vinaigrette ($27.95) or rack of lamb ($27.95).

Sunday

9:30 a.m.
10) Under the Live Oak Tree
As you sit at an umbrella table on the tiled patio at the McGregor Cafe (4305 McGregor Boulevard, 239-936-1771), look up into the branches of the large live oak tree covered with fuzzy air plants called ball moss. Order eggs and grits ($5.50) or homemade biscuits and sausage gravy ($5.50) and maybe a frothy latte ($3.25). The cafe opened as a burger joint in 1937, according to Cristof Danzi, the owner and chef, who frequently leaves the grill, which he refers to as his office, to visit with customers.

11:30
11) She Sees Sea Cows
From downtown, drive 10 minutes east on State Route 80. At the Florida Power and Light power plant turn right into Lee County Manatee Park (239-694-3537). During the winter, as many as 100 manatees, some with calves, are visible from an overlook; many of these endangered mammals are scarred by encounters with boat propellers. They flock to the warm water of the power plant's discharge canal. You will see ripples in the dark water, then a large flat back surfacing, and perhaps a small whiskery face. Amble along trails to the Orange River to see how Florida looked before developers arrived. (The park is open from 8 a.m. to 5 p.m. through March, then until 8 p.m.)

THE BASICS
Visiting Fort Myers
Downtown Fort Myers is about 20 minutes from the Southwest Florida International Airport. By car, Fort Myers is about three hours from Tampa, four from Orlando and two and a half from Miami. The city is 15 miles inland from the Gulf of Mexico; good beaches are on Sanibel Island and at Fort Myers Beach, a separate city nearby. You will need a car to get around.
The Holiday Inn Riverwalk and Marina (2220 West First Street, 800-664-7775) has 147 rooms and suites, many overlooking the Caloosahatchee River. Weekend winter rates are $79 to $159.
About half of the 420 rooms and suites at the 25-story Ramada Inn at Amtel Marina (2500 Edwards Drive, 800-833-1620), have river views. Weekend winter rates are $69 to $139.
The Black Tie is a floating bed-and-breakfast (239-826-2457) in a wooden motor yacht built in 1936 and now based in the City of Fort Myers Yacht Basin. There are two staterooms, $120 and $140 a night.

HEADLINE: DRIVING: BELLS & WHISTLES; 
Your Wishes At a Fingertip

BYLINE:  By DAN McCOSH

 BODY:
Audi's new A8 sedan responds to a light touch -- literally. The console on certain models of this aluminum-bodied luxury car incorporates a device that recognizes the driver's fingerprints. 
It then responds with an individual adjustment of several controls, like radio presets or the position of the seat, steering column and mirror. It can even adjust the automatic transmission -- to stay in low gears longer for high performance driving, for example, or to shift faster for fuel economy.
 The fingerprint sensor, seemingly worthy of the front door of an F.B.I. office, is a postage-stamp-size pad located on the starter button. Using 24 fingerprint characteristics stored in its digital memory, it compares the fingerprint of the person pressing the button with the owner's, also stored in its digital memory. If the driver passes the test, the stored presets come into play. 
 The sensor can also unlock a personal address book with up to 100 entries and even engages a personal program on the car's satellite navigation system. It is capable of remembering and recognizing up to 60 fingerprints, allowing the owner to let other drivers use the features.
So far, the system is available only on some European models of the A8, but the company hopes to add it soon to models sold in the United States.
In the meantime, American buyers will have to make do with the similar, though more limited, device that some automakers add to the key fob. It expands the function of the familiar key-based system that unlocks cars from a few feet away so that it also activates a few presets, like the seat position. DAN McCOSH

GRAPHIC: Photo: PRESS HERE -- A fingerprint reader, to the right of the gearshift, on an Audi A8.
