HEADLINE: PRACTICAL TRAVELER; 
Europe Slowly, On a Barge

BYLINE:  By MARTHA STEVENSON OLSON; MARTHA STEVENSON OLSON is a freelance writer.

 BODY:
IN these often dismal times, I've taken comfort in a fantasy of slowed-down civility: cruising through centuries-old locks and waterways, past peaceful fields and villages, bicycling to a bakery for fresh bread or buying dewy produce from the lock-keeper's wife. In my daydream I can't decide whether the boat will be a hotel barge, with meals, service and day trips included, or a rented boat piloted by me and my husband, with our two children as crew.
 Once busy avenues of commerce, the canals and waterways that interlace Europe, punctuated by locks, docks and towpaths, date from Roman times into the last century, when railways and roads took over as conduits of goods. Now those waterways play host to scores of recreational craft, including refurbished barges and modern cruisers. 
 For the adventurous sort who likes being in control and wants to keep costs to a minimum, a self-hire boat may be the right choice, requiring more work but also offering more freedom. Those who prefer being pampered, and can afford it, may opt for a cruise. Boats range from small craft with up to eight guests, to floating hotels accommodating up to 120. Barges have become increasingly popular with groups, like families on a reunion, or travelers on an incentive trip offered as an award by their companies. Once aboard, passengers need to make few decisions other than which wine to drink or whether to take the next day's excursion.
 There are several agencies in the United States that can ease passage into both kinds of trip with advice and information. One is Le Boat, 45 Whitney Road, Suite C5, Mahwah, N.J. 07430; (800) 992-0291; www .leboat.com. Its owner, Debbie Petermann, will provide brochures ranging from do-it-yourself narrowboats in the British countryside to luxury cruises that include Jacuzzi baths, hot-air balloon rides and golf. On the West Coast, John Kroontje and Roger Van Dyken operate a company called Barging in Europe, 115 Front Street, Lynden, Wash. 98264; (360) 354-6727, www.barging ineurope.com, which arranges luxury barge trips, self-drive boats, or "hosted charters" (with a skipper as host, beginning at $3,900 a week). 
 The barge season lasts primarily from March to November, with the peak months in late spring and early fall, according to Ms. Petermann. Because of the slowed American economy, she said, prices have stayed pretty much the same as last year's. Self-catered barges have a steady market of European renters, she added, and so are not as dependent on dollars.

Escorted Cruises
 Here are some of the companies offering escorted barge cruises: In England and Wales, a classic route is along the upper Thames, from London to beyond Oxford. European Waterways books two boats along the route, one of them the 1907 Dutch Klipper Actief, which holds up to 11 passengers and a crew of 4. Other luxury cruises in the British Isles, France and Germany include one through Scotland's Caledonian Canal, two along the Shannon River in Ireland, and one through the Berlin canals and Mecklenburg lake region of Germany. European Waterways, 35 Wharf Road, Wraysbury, Staines, Middlesex, TW19 5JQ, England; (800) 394-8630, fax (44-1784) 483 072; www.gobarging.com.
 France pioneered and remains a leader in luxury barge trips; the food is a big attraction. Popular excursions are along the Seine and through the upper Loire and Burgundy region, with other possibilities through many other regions. Continental Waterways specializes in French barge and river cruises; as an example, a six-night cruise through Burgundy aboard its 24-passenger Escargot begins at $1,790 a person during the main summer season. Continental Waterways, 53 East 34th Street, New York, N.Y. 10016; (800) 546-4777; www.continentalwaterways.com. 
 In the Netherlands, where canal barging is a way of life, 4Winds Specialty Tours offers 15 itineraries, including a 10-night cruise through flower fields in peak season ($1,395, based on double occupancy). A trip in Belgium focuses on breweries and beer tasting (seven nights, $805, double occupancy). Most routes offer cyclists a chance to pedal up to 35 miles a day on bikes provided. The company also rents barges for groups, with a minimum crew of 2. 4Winds Specialty Tours, 4500 Victoria Court, West Richland, Wash. 99353; (509) 967-3448; www .4windstours.com.

Doing It Yourself
Self-hire boats are rented out by large and small companies, families and individuals along seemingly every navigable waterway in Europe, usually by the week. Companies usually provide information about routes, restaurants, places of interest and useful telephone numbers, as well as training on how to handle the boat and a temporary boat license, if necessary. Bedding and galley equipment is usually supplied, along with refrigerator, gas stove, heat and a plug-in for cell phones (bring your own). Bikes can often be rented.
 The smallest boats start at about $1,500 a week in peak summer months, with larger boats sleeping up to 12 people costing $4,000 a week or more. One of the larger rental agencies, Crown Blue Line, has self-hire boats in the Netherlands, Germany, Ireland, Scotland and Italy (for the area around Venice); Crown Blue Line, Annapolis Landing Marina, 980 Awald Road, Suite 302, Annapolis, Md. 21403; (888) 355-9491; www.crownblueline.com.
 Connoisseur, in its 50th year of operation, is a self-hire company with several offices in Europe. It has boats in France, Belgium, Germany, Italy, Scotland, England and Ireland (it recently joined forces with Emerald Star, a specialist in boat rentals along the Shannon River in Ireland, as well as with Houseboat Holidays in Italia, with routes around Venice). Connoisseur's boats are for sale new or used. Connoisseur Wroxham, Norwich, Norfolk NR12 8RX, England; (44-1603) 782 472; fax (44-1603) 783 089; www.connoisseurafloat.com.
 Locaboat Holidays tries to reduce environmental impact with old-fashioned bargelike lines, quiet-running engines, solar panels, and waste-water holding and recycling. Bookings are available throughout France, and in the Netherlands, Germany and Ireland. Locaboat Holidays, Boite Postal 150, 89303 Joigny Cedex, France; (33-3) 86.91.72.72, fax (33-3) 86.62.42.41; www.locaboat.com.
 France Passion Plaisance has many departure points in France and also offers routes inland around Venice, and in Spain and Portugal. Boite Postal 63, 71160 Digoin, France (33-3) 85.53.76.70, fax (33-3) 85.53.75. 71, www.france-passion-plaisance.fr. H2olidays S.A.R.L., Port de Plaisance, 21170, St.- Jean de Losne, France, (33-3) 80.29.13.81, fax (33-3) 80.29.04.67, has many links on its Web site, www.barginginfrance.com.
 In Britain, the choice of waterways increases markedly with self-hire boats called narrowboats. Routes include the Severn and Avon Rivers and canals through the Midlands, Norfolk and northern Wales. A major renter is Black Prince Narrowboat Holidays, Stoke Prior, Bromsgrove, Worcestershire B60 4LA (44-1527) 575 115; fax (44-1527) 575 116; www.black-prince.com.

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY: CORRESPONDENT'S REPORT; 
Mideast Haven Prepares For Tourists, Not War

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH B. TREASTER

DATELINE: DUBAI, United Arab Emirates 

 BODY:
IT is early evening in the vast marble and glass lobby cafe of the new Emirates Towers Hotel here and it is hard to find an empty couch or armchair. Guests from Europe and the nearby Gulf states and an American or two are sipping tea and chilled wine. In the more modest Towers Rotana Hotel farther along Sheik Zayed Road, a crowd of foreign businessmen and women -- many of them British construction supervisors -- gathers at the long bar.
 While the drumbeat of war in Iraq -- just up the Persian Gulf -- seems to be ever more insistent, this desert city of spectacular modern architecture goes right on playing its self-appointed role as safe haven in a troubled region, a place where business and pleasure persistently trump politics. 
 "People aren't walking around here talking about war," said Rashid Taqui, the editor of a new magazine here, Architecture+. "It seems very distant. We're very developed here. We feel protected."
 Indeed, tourism officials say occupancy in the major hotels is running close to 100 percent and bookings for early 2003 are strong.
 War -- if it comes -- will surely hurt tourism and trade in Dubai, the commercial center of the United Arab Emirates, a slice of desert just across the Persian Gulf from Iran and a short flight north from Yemen, the ancestral home of Osama Bin Laden. But Dubai and the other emirates have made neutrality pay off in the past.
 "We end up supplying both sides," Mohammed al-Fahim, chairman of Makarem General Trading and Real Estate, told the Middle East Economic Digest recently.
 So far, Dubai, with its alluring white beaches and steel-and-glass towers, has more than held its own as travel worldwide has declined. Despite a severe dip following the Sept. 11 attacks, Dubai, a major air hub between Asia and Europe, ended 2001 with a 6.5 percent increase in visitors, to 3.6 million. For 2002, tourism officials are estimating a 10 percent rise, to more than four million. They are aiming for 15 million in 2010, as oil reserves diminish. 
 Malaysia Airlines flies nonstop, about 13 hours, between Newark and Dubai three times a week, and Emirates Airlines is considering nonstop service from New York this year. (Through March, Malaysia is offering a round-trip economy ticket for $499, down from about $750.) 
 American visitors have been gradually increasing over the last decade, government officials say, but they are far outnumbered by Europeans, Asians and people from neighboring countries who say that particularly since the Sept. 11 attacks, they find Dubai more hospitable than the United States and Europe. The government estimates that more than 80,000 Americans visited Dubai last year, compared with nearly 1 million people from nearby countries, more than 800,000 from Europe -- where Dubai is campaigning hard for more business -- and more than 660,000 from Asia.
 Dubai has lots of fine restaurants -- featuring food from Iran and India, Italy and France -- glittering malls with designer fashions, ancient souks with gold jewelry, and opportunities to explore the desert. The atmosphere is more liberal than in much of the Arab world; hotel clubs are set up for drinking and dancing, and women are not required to be covered. Prices are similar to those in London and New York.
 Dozens of business conferences and other events are planned this year, beginning with Dubai's annual monthlong Shopping Festival, which was to open last Wednesday. This nonstop bazaar celebrates the city's duty-free status with carpets, jewels and sleek fashions from 50 countries at discounted prices. 
 In February, Jennifer Capriati and the Williams sisters are expected for the Dubai Tennis Championship. In March, Tiger Woods plans to play in the Dubai Desert Classic; the Dubai World Cup, a horse racing event with a $6 million purse, is March 29.
 The event of the year is to be the September meeting of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank, an annual gathering of 25,000 bankers and business executives held in a different country each year. To handle the crowd, Dubai will be opening several big new hotels, including the 200-room Ibis and the 400-room Novotel as part of a sprawling new convention center. A 675-room Grand Hyatt and the 300-room Shangri-La are expected to open this spring. 
 Noting that Dubai was running out of beach front, the emirates' ruling family decided to build two huge islands in the shape of palm trees. Over the next several years, hotels, villas and marinas are to be built along the 72 miles of beaches they will create, many on the arching "fronds." 
 The first of the islands is rising in sight of the beach-front Burj Al Arab hotel, the celebrated 1,053-foot Teflon, stainless-steel and glass confection built in 1999 in the shape of a billowing spinnaker. The hotel has all two-story suites with crystal chandeliers and gold-plated toilet fixtures, and the best go for $7,500 a night. But some units are available in packages for about $500 a night.
 Adjacent to it is Wild Wadi, a 12-acre water park where youngsters in little blue and white rafts shoot past craggy images from Arabian folklore. 
 "Dubai is trying to develop hotels and other structures that are, let's say, attention getting," said Peter R. Voll, a travel consultant in Redwood City, Calif., who takes university and museum groups to the Middle East. "They're a little sensational, if not bizarre. But this is a signal that something historic is going on in this part of the world."

LENGTH: 1000 words

HEADLINE: ART REVIEWS; 
An Overstuffed Bear of an Exhibition

BYLINE:  By Helen A. Harrison

 BODY:
'The World of Theodore Roosevelt'
Nassau County Museum of Art, One Museum Drive, Roslyn Harbor, (516) 484-9337. Through Feb. 16.
 Theodore Roosevelt was a pampered city boy who became a rugged outdoorsman, a warrior who won the Nobel Peace Prize, and a big game hunter who championed wildlife conservation, among other seemingly contradictory roles. As he once remarked, "I have enjoyed as much of life as any nine men I know." 
 This exhibition -- which includes paintings, sculpture, drawings, prints, furniture, political cartoons, photographs, documents, clothing and assorted memorabilia -- ranges far and wide in trying to encompass Roosevelt's outsized personality, as well as his social, political, economic and domestic milieu. The curators could not decide whether to focus on the man or to examine his times, so they did both. In an unintentional case of art mirroring life, they came up with a display that serves as a metaphor for Roosevelt himself: enough material for nine exhibitions, stuffed into one.
Chronological organization brings some order to the presentation, but the cumulative effect overwhelms. The viewer is constantly seesawed between Roosevelt's public and private personas and shuttled among his various worlds, among them Sagamore Hill, his beloved retreat in Oyster Bay.
Many of the art works, extensively interpreted in wall labels, illustrate his career, including his stint as New York City's police commissioner, his military service in the Spanish-American War and his two terms as President. Others depict the places he frequented and the people he met, whether in the gilded corridors of power or around a campfire in the wilderness. Some of his personal possessions, reflecting his own taste and the aesthetics of the period, are also on display. 
Roosevelt was apparently such a dominant figure, that when he was in the room, everything else took second place. That's what happens in these galleries. 

'Sammy Dent: Organic Abstraction'
Port Washington Public Library, One Library Drive, Port Washington, (516) 883-4400. Through Jan. 30.
Ms. Dent's large, vibrant canvases carry on the tradition of Abstract Expressionism, with its reliance on spontaneous gesture and its avoidance of representational imagery. The paintings recall those of Helen Frankenthaler, who, like Ms. Dent, contrasts translucent areas of stained pigment with thick calligraphic strokes and linear elements to create forms that float in pictorial space.
Although Ms. Dent describes her aim as achieving a balance between the figurative and the abstract, references to specific subject matter are minimized to the point of dissolution. Her primary subject is color itself, which may or may not coalesce into recognizable objects.
Sometimes the titles offer likely interpretations, as in "Egg," with its suggestion of an embryonic cell dividing within an encircling white enclosure, or in "Life's a Peach," with its fruit-like shape, or in "Jealousy II," in which an aggressive green blob spews its bile at an equally explosive red-orange antagonist.
But more often the titles seem to indicate a place, time or state of mind rather than a subject. "Bangkok," for example, might be an amalgam of impressions created by multicolored cloth banners tossed by a breeze, perhaps something the British-born artist glimpsed during her travels. In "Buddha's Birthday," a floating mass of pink, red and orange, trailing purple tendrils tipped with orange and turquoise, conjures the advent of a brilliant jellyfish rather than the birth of an Asian philosopher.
Whether their titles explain or obscure their meanings, Ms. Dent's paintings can be enjoyed without the benefit of such intimations. Their appeal lies in their gestural verve and the artist's love of chromatic interplay, resulting in imagery that alludes to nature while seldom picturing it.

'Winter Selections'
Alpan Gallery, 2 West Carver Street, Huntington, (631) 423-4433. Through Feb. 15.
Many of the artists in this group show share Ms. Dent's interest in painterly abstraction, but with different results. Several use color both as imagery in its own right and as a concealing device.
Eleanor Schimmel's untitled encaustic paintings -- one luminously pearly, the other a glowing red over equally intense blue -- use thick crusts of pigment to create multilayered surfaces into which she carves linear swirls and circles. In Anne Raymond's "Now," the canvas seems to emit a shimmering cloud of warmth that envelops cooler undertones.
Sylvia Harnick's "Re/Bounded Memories" allows the viewer to peek beneath the surface by peeling away successive layers of paint, the way a weathered wall documents its own history. Frank Wimberley blocks access to an imaginary vista beyond the picture plane in "Tarred Skylight, Interior View," which cleverly confounds the notion of a painting as a window on the outside world.
Carla Beyers creates a three-dimensional surface by building up a pattern of shadowy strokes embedded in what appears to be layered acrylic polymer; the effect is like the aftermath of a pillow fight in the dark. In "Black Thorn" and "Red Ryder," David Geiser wraps references to plant life in blankets of translucent color that refer to the earth, water and sun that nurture the spiky growths.
Two of the artists make imaginative use of recycled materials. Janet Nolan's "Twister No. 9" is a construction of old umbrella frames, stripped of their fabric and crunched together as if by the force of a powerful wind. Their sad carcasses are revitalized by wrappings of colorful, cloth-covered wire, which transform them from useless relics into a whimsical, Judy Pfaff-inspired sculpture.
Used tea bags provide Gulsen Calik with an unlikely but effective basis for a visual diary, drawn on the bags themselves, which are arranged on the wall like pages from a travel sketchbook. The result, "Voyage to Cai," is a mosaic of ink and watercolor vignettes chronicling encounters on a journey of discovery that is more spiritual than actual.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Janet Nolan's "Twister No. 9," far left, is on view at the Alpan Gallery in Huntington; "Return of the Conquerors" (1899), left, is part of the Teddy Roosevelt show at the Nassau County Museum of Art; and Sammy Dent's "Bangkok" is on display at the Port Washington Public Library.

HEADLINE: The View/From Stratford; 
Aiming to Ground a Plan To Expand a Runway

BYLINE:  By RICHARD WEIZEL

 BODY:
FOR almost 30 years, officials at Igor I. Sikorsky Memorial Airport in Stratford have wanted to make runway safety improvements that would have involved expanding the airport. The issue became particularly heated in 1994 after a crash on a foggy April night resulted in the deaths of eight people aboard a chartered flight from Atlantic City.
 While the crash was deemed largely the fault of the pilot, the National Transportation Safety Board ruled that the flawed runway design left little room for pilot error and had contributed to the deaths aboard the chartered Piper Navajo Chieftain plane. 
 For years, there had been talks about obtaining more land for runway improvements. But residents, a local environmental group and the town feared that any runway changes would result in a larger, nosier airport that would, among other things, hurt the town's plans for economic development on a mile-long stretch of Main Street. 
Last month, the old debate was revived after the Federal Aviation Administration announced a proposal to obtain a portion of Main Street near the runway through eminent domain.
"While the F.A.A. has hinted in the past that it might pursue the avenue of condemnation, to make this announcement without warning and further exploration of compromise solutions is indeed disturbing," Mike Feeney, the town manager, said last month.
"Furthermore, for the F.A.A. to disguise these expansion actions as safety improvements while ignoring the many safety concerns raised by Stratford with respect to added emergency response times and the unsafe configuration of Main Street appears disingenuous."
Residents have long opposed expanding the runway, which is bound on one end by Long Island Sound and on the other side by the highway, where the plane rammed into a steel fence that shields passing cars from the blast of planes taking off.
In 1994, the safety board recommended moving Main Street, a two-lane state highway, away from the airport to allow room for a safety zone beyond one runway to protect planes that overrun a crash fence, and installing new landing lights for the runway.
None of the proposals moved forward, despite repeated efforts by the city of Bridgeport, which owns the airport.
Then, when all commercial flights at the airport came to an end in 1999 after US Airways became the last commercial airliner to pull out, residents and town leaders saw that as a sign that Sikorsky would remain a small airport for private and charter flights.
The recent talk of rerouting Main Street has outraged some residents and town officials.
F.A.A. officials insist, however, that eminent domain will be used only as a last resort. Officials for the F.A.A. and the airport, which was built in 1928, contend that runway improvements are long overdue.
"There has been a history of crashes associated with a particular runway at that airport and our plans would include an approach lighting system and expanded safety areas beyond the existing runway," said Gail Lattrell, an F.A.A. airport planner who is based in Burlington, Mass.
Kurt Sendlein, the superintendent of operations for Sikorsky, said the runway safety improvements were vital to preventing accidents.
"In 1994 there was a crash that killed eight people, and while the accident was caused by pilot error, death resulted from the plane hitting the blast fence at the end of the runway," Mr. Sendlein said. "If the fence had not been there the people would have survived."
Airport officials said they had wanted to make changes to the runway even before the accident, including having 1,000 feet of grass at each end of the runway, compared with the current 150 feet on one end and 15 feet on the end that includes the blast fence.
Two corporate jets and 80 small private airplanes currently fly out of Sikorsky, Mr. Sendlein said, compared with more than 30-based corporate jets and 220 small private airplanes at Tweed Airport in New Haven.
"By putting in these safety areas you won't suddenly have big jets flying in here; that's not going to happen," Mr. Sendlein said. "The only thing we're trying for now are safety improvements."
Town officials and residents are skeptical, however.
"It's very upsetting that the F.A.A. is even considering taking the property through eminent domain to carry out a reconfiguration plan that we believe would jeopardize motorists' safety," said Jennifer Hillgen, the Republican Town Council minority leader, who represents the district that includes the airport. "The relocation plans include extremely sharp curves and would sacrifice the safety of thousands of people on the ground."
Ms. Lattrell, the F.A.A. planner, said: "We will attempt to negotiate for as long as we can, but at some point if continued negotiations are not fruitful and it is determined these plans need to move forward, we would have to consider other options such as eminent domain."
As for the state Department of Transportation, Arthur Gruhn, the chief engineer, said: "We have taken a position against the relocation of the road. We have concerns with the geometric re-alignment of the road that are in the plans, as well as with the local community's opposition."
Mr. Gruhn said if the F.A.A. carried out its plan to proceed with eminent domain, the department "would not be willing to accept the relocated road into the state highway system. It would become a road that the federal government would be responsible for."
At a meeting last month on the reconfiguration of Main Street, the F.A.A. told town officials that new studies had to be conducted before a decision was made. The study is expected to be completed in May.
"This is all just another ploy, yet another tactic they are using to get that road moved, this time through eminent domain," said Walter Rimkunas, 72, who has lived in his home on Second Avenue near the airport for more than 50 years and can see the one of the runways from his backyard.
"The F.A.A. has been doing studies for years, so I don't know why they have to do another one now."
Mr. Rimkunas is also on the board of directors of Protect Your Environment, a town group that has been fighting airport expansion for decades to protect local marshes and wildlife.
The group believes a larger airport would result in booming jets that would make living in the area intolerable.
"This is the federal government trying to take a state highway from a local municipality and use it for their own purposes, and we cannot let them do this," he said.

GRAPHIC: Photos: At Igor I. Sikorsky Memorial Airport, F.A.A. officials are considering using eminent domain to obtain land along Main Street to make safety improvements on a runway. Below, Jennifer Hillgen, who thinks the reconfiguration plan would jeopardize motorists' safety. (Photographs by Thomas McDonald for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: POSTINGS: Estimating Construction Spending in City; 
For 2003 and '04, It's 2002 Redux

 BODY:
Construction spending in New York City is expected to remain essentially the same this year and next as it was in 2002, at slightly more than $15 billion annually, according to a report by the New York Building Congress, a private coalition of contractors, subcontractors, developers, architects, engineers and skilled workers. The figure, though, is considerably higher than the $10 billion a year in the mid- to late 1990's. 
 Construction spending totaled $15.3 billion in 2002, down $600 million from the record-setting pace of 2001, according to the report, "Construction Outlook 2002-2005." Spending is estimated at $15.5 billion this year and $15.3 billion in 2004, and is estimated to rise to $17.8 billion in 2005. But Building Congress officials cautioned that the estimates, based on an analysis of capital budgets, development plans and other indicators, face considerable uncertainty because of the unsettled economy and public-sector budget gaps. "The big question regarding public and private sector work," said Marilyn Jordan Taylor, chairwoman of the group -- and chairwoman of Skidmore, Owings & Merrill -- "is the availability of financing necessary to move projects from planning to construction." 
 Spending for residential construction totaled $1.7 billion in 2002, producing 12,300 housing units. That level is expected to continue through 2005, the report said, producing about 12,000 housing units a year.

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/New Jersey; 
Office Vacancy Rates Continued to Rise in 2002

BYLINE:  By ANTOINETTE MARTIN 

 BODY:
RECENT reports about New Jersey's office market all sound pretty much the same sour note: the situation is dismal, and not getting better fast.
 Of course, the market will eventually improve, according to reports by several real estate firms, including Cushman & Wakefield, Insignia/ESG, GVA Williams, Trammell Crow, Newmark and Julien J. Studley. But given the slow pace of the general economy's recovery and the fact that commercial real estate market conditions usually lag behind by about a year, there was solid agreement that a rebound is unlikely until the end of 2003. 
 Still, the optimistic impulses of real estate people are legendary, and a few weeks into the new year, there already seems to be competition over who will be first to spot the dim beacon of recovery.
Studley's branch manager in New Jersey, Thomas V. Giannone, said in a statement on Jan. 3 that his company was seeing larger crowds at showings of vacant offices and pronounced this to be a glimmer of hope. "After an extended period of softness, tenants have begun examining available inventory," Mr. Giannone said. "While this has not yet affected statistics -- leasing volume fell again in the fourth quarter -- it is an indication that the market may have reached bottom and that it may soon begin a slow advance." 
Paul E. Giannone, managing principal of Newmark New Jersey -- and no relation to Mr. Giannone of Studley -- announced the same day that more clients had signed leases in the last month of 2002 than had done so in 11 previous months and called this is a sign that the market is "beginning to move." Newmark New Jersey, based in Woodbridge, recently negotiated a lease with the United States government for office space in the firm's hometown. Newmark was also involved last month in leasing two medical offices and a new space for a marketing company in Middlesex County; extending a sublease for a financial services firm, also in Middlesex County; extending a Princeton software company's lease agreement; and expanding the amount of space that a Bergen County law firm had leased. 
Meanwhile, at the Trammell Crow Company, the team of Bob Sklow, managing director, and Mitchell Katz, vice president, reported in the first week of the 2003 that there had been a slight increase in leasing transactions; the pair represented tenants in some transactions and owners in others. Their recent deals included Fujitsu IT Holdings' lease for office space at Continental Plaza III in Hackensack, New World Restaurant Group's sublease for space at Horizon Center in Hamilton Township to serve as headquarters for its Einstein Bros. Bagels division, and Euco Aromatics' lease of industrial space at 1026 West Elizabeth Avenue, Linden.
During 2002, according to Cushman & Wakefield's final quarterly report, the vacancy rate within north and central New Jersey's 168.6-million-square-foot office market rose "at a steady pace." At the end of the year, it was 17.1 percent in the northern part of the state and 21.7 percent in central New Jersey. For Class A space, the most desirable offices, in northern New Jersey, a market closely linked to conditions in Manhattan, the vacancy rate was 19.3 percent, Cushman said.
Christopher Kinum, a managing director at Cushman, noted, "Even the Hudson waterfront, which two years ago had virtually no available space, saw its vacancy rate nearly triple in 2002." The rate at year-end was 13.7 percent, although all but 3.9 percent was sublease space. 
The fourth quarter figures produced by other companies' research arms varied by only fractions of a point. GVA Williams's figures, for example, showed an overall vacancy rate at the end of 2002 of 16.9 percent, which the firm said was 25 percent higher than a year before. On the other hand, GVA said, the overall rate decreased a bit in the fourth quarter compared with the third quarter, when it was 17.6 percent.
FOR northern New Jersey Class A space, GVA calculated the vacancy rate at 18.9 percent at year-end, up 40 percent from a year before. 
"In order for the New Jersey real estate market to progress," Mr. Kinum said, "we must have an economy that is moving in a positive direction." In commentary attached to Cushman's year-end statistics, he said, "As we lead into 2003, no major change has occurred in our economy that suggests this trend will come quickly."
Mr. Giannone of Newmark acknowledged that quick recovery is out of the question. But he speedily pointed to a few negative trends that might be reversing themselves.
"We had negative absorption of 2.5 million square feet last year," he said, meaning that much more space was available at the end of 2002 than was available at the end of the previous year. "But in the last quarter, we had 750,000 square feet positive absorption over the previous quarter."
That still leaves a great deal of space to be absorbed before the market achieves equilibrium, Mr. Giannone said -- roughly 1.5 million square feet to get the vacancy rate down to 10 percent. "It's a start," he said.
He and others also pointed to a small spike in the number of jobs being created in New Jersey in the last quarter after many months of job shrinkage, caused by cutbacks and downsizing by companies of all sizes and types. "The commercial office market is tied so strongly to job growth," said Mr. Giannone of Newmark. "In October, there were 3,300 new jobs and in November, 7,700 new jobs. That's not dramatic, but it shows we hit bottom -- and barring bad news on the international front -- we're on a path to recover."
Studley's Mr. Giannone pointed to a halt by another negative trend as a positive sign. "In the fourth quarter reports, the amount of sublease space did not increase as a percentage of the overall space available," he said. A total of about 1.1 million square feet of leased office space was put on the market for sublease last year. In the first three quarters of the year, Mr. Giannone said, the amount of sublease space kept increasing in proportion to direct lease space. In the final quarter, proportions remained steady, with sublease space representing about 36 percent of all space on the market.
But that could quickly change again, the GVA Williams report noted. "Upward of 2 million square feet of additional sublease space is expected in 2003," it said, "which represents a 20 percent increase of the current sublet inventory in northern and central New Jersey."
Sublease space generally rents for less and is more difficult to market, brokers agree. On the other hand, the fact that many long-term leases have not yet expired and landlords still get rent even when space is vacant has helped stabilize the market, Mr. Kinum of Cushman noted. But as numerous primary leases signed during boom times a decade ago expire in the next year or two, more pressure will be put on property owners to lower rents, he predicted.
GVA WILLIAMS reported that average asking rents were $23.55 per square foot annually at the end of 2002, 37 cents higher than in the third quarter. That number may be a bit low, however, GVA's report said, because companies offering many large blocks of space on the Jersey City waterfront do not disclose asking rents for survey purposes.
Several year-end reports mentioned that growth in the pharmaceutical industry, which was so extensive in the past decade in New Jersey that the state's real estate market was able to withstand ill winds in the telecommunications and financial services industries, had slacked off. "Pharmaceutical activity," Mr. Kinum said, "has been stable, at best."
He and others discerned a glint of hope, though, in recent growth of law firms, public accounting offices and other financial services companies.

HEADLINE: L.I. @ WORK; 
Helping a Company to Renew and Redefine Itself

BYLINE:  By WARREN STRUGATCH

 BODY:
HARVEY ELECTRONICS, the chain of television and stereo stores, was pulling itself out of Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in 1997 when Harrison Leifer DiMarco, an advertising agency in Rockville Centre, came in to make a sales pitch. Two decades earlier, Herb Leifer, one of the agency's founders, had worked for Harvey's president, Franklin Karp, as the stores' advertising director, and he had known Mr. Karp from an even earlier job at the Stereo Warehouse chain. 
 What Mr. Leifer and a creative team from his agency were proposing was not a traditional ad campaign but a makeover of the chain's image, known in the ad trade as rebranding. 
"My thinking was at that point they really had no identity," Mr. Leifer said. "One day they presented themselves as specialists; another day they were mass merchandisers. I said, 'You can't be all things to all people.' They seemed ready to go along with that."
Mr. Karp agreed with the need for repositioning. "We've been around for 76 years, and our success has largely been as a value-added retailer," he said. "We ran into problems when, among other things, we tried to compete on price rather than service."
After spending several months conducting consumer focus groups, researching market trends and studying how other retailers had successfully reinvented themselves, the Harrison Leifer team put forward its recommendations. "Essentially, we saw there was a niche for a retailer who would cater to the middle- and high-end home theater market, selling products like plasma TV's and installing them in the customer's home," Mr. Leifer said.
The agency suggested a new slogan, "Not your ordinary electronics store," which Mr. Karp liked. (Last October, the slogan was revised again, to "Extraordinary in every way.") The agency also helped Harvey redesign the interiors of two existing stores, in Manhattan and Paramus, N.J., and five new stores, one of them in Greenvale. 
"We helped them carve the sales space into a series of small homelike environments where customers could sit down on couches and watch the systems in comfort," said Joe Benty, Harrison Leifer's vice president for brand strategy.
The agency shifted ad spending to upscale magazines from daily newspapers. The color ads emphasized comfortable living rather than prices.
The efforts apparently worked, and by 1998, the chain had completed a successful public offering. In its last fiscal year, which ended Oct. 31, Harvey said it made a profit on revenues of $41.5 million but would not release any other figures. 
Not every rebranding effort results in such a clear turnaround. Yet because of its potential to change a company's fortunes, branding has become a business buzzword. 
Beginning in the mid-90s, advertising and marketing agencies on Long Island began adding branding to their roster of services. More recently, companies like Acclaim Entertainment, the video game maker in Glen Cove, have begun hiring brand specialists.
The emphasis on branding has largely been a boon to ad agencies and has translated into increased spending on services like market research and logo development. Sometimes it has allowed agencies to offer new services like interior design and custom training. 
For decades, the makers of consumer goods have done just this sort of thing with clothes, cars, perfumes and shampoos. In recent years, the practice has spread to companies like Computer Associates, the Islandia software company, which began a global branding effort in 2001, and Farrell Fritz, the Uniondale law firm, which plans to start a rebranding campaign next month.
In some cases branding campaigns are little more than logo redesigns. In other cases they represent a major repositioning in reaction to a market shift and an awareness of customer perceptions.
"Branding is essentially a quick statement about why you should spend money," said Faith Popcorn, the president of Brain Reserve, a marketing and trend-tracking consulting concern in Manhattan. "The brand says, 'Here's what I stand for.' People are so overloaded with information that if you're not a brand, you can't get anyone's attention."
"You should be able to explain a brand in three words," said Ms. Popcorn, who has a house in Wainscott. "A paragraph is too long."
Most branding experts come out of advertising or marketing backgrounds, and in fact their methods, tools and jargon usually reflect those disciplines. What's different is the emphasis. Where traditional advertising people focus on the client's product or service, branding people focus on the client's customers -- and their perceptions.
"Branding is about connecting with the individual," said Mr. Benty, the Harrison Leifer vice president. "When the consumer decides to buy your product, instead of the other guy's, it's because you were perceived as different. It isn't just about product benefits. It's about what you stand for."
Companies that sell mainly to other companies, as opposed to consumers, are now jumping on the branding bandwagon, and their campaigns resemble consumer ads more than traditional business pitches. Once limited to specialized trade and business publications, these ads now appear on television and in print. 
A good example is Computer Associates' "Hello Tomorrow" rebranding campaign that began in January 2001.
"We used to run product ads that had lots of product screen shots, huge amounts of text and plenty of details about product functionality," said Nancy Baghat, the company's senior vice president for global marketing. "We've made a huge shift in terms of focusing on the consumer perspective. We're talking about the benefits that technology brings, rather than getting hung up on feature functionality.
"It's all about the benefits of working with Computer Associates, and positioning Computer Associates as a company whose core values are innovation, approachability and being customer-focused."
Last year, Rich D'Amico, an advertising research specialist in Northport, believed that the time was right to start his own business offering branding services to ad agencies. He said that he had found plenty of work, even in a difficult economy.
"The business-to-business companies are beginning to realize what the big consumer-goods companies have known for years," he said, "namely that it doesn't matter how they perceive their products, it's how the market perceives their products that matters. That means going out and asking customers questions like, 'What do I represent to you?' "
With its emphasis on making the most of every opportunity to deliver a company's message, branding can also open the door to unforeseen problems. "By painting your logo and tag line on every vehicle in your fleet, you get your message out to every driver on the road that day," Mr. Benty said. "Your truck becomes a brand extension. But if your truck cuts someone off or the driver gets into a big collision that ends up on TV, you better be prepared to handle the image problems."

HEADLINE: In the Region/Connecticut; 
Fairfield Office Park Plan Progresses

BYLINE:  By ELEANOR CHARLES 

 BODY:
FOR nearly seven years, a massive mixed-use project proposed for a 35-acre brownfield site in the Black Rock section of the town of Fairfield has been punted back and forth by three critical parties: the developers, Kurt Wittek and Arnold D. Stauber; the town; and the Connecticut Department of Transportation. The estimated cost of the project is now about $200 million. 
 Last year, town zoning regulations were amended, designating the site as a "transportation commercial park" in addition to its existing industrial zone. The new designation would allow for up to a million square feet of offices, a hotel, a day care center and health club, and a Metro-North train station. 
 The developers and three successive town administrations negotiated modifications in the plans, reducing its size, but all agreed that for the project to work the Connecticut Department of Transportation had to be convinced of the necessity for a third Fairfield train station on the site. Its northern border abuts the Metro-North tracks, and Exit 24 of Interstate 95 is within easy access. 
The state finally approved the station late last month, and a letter of intent was signed by the first selectman, Kenneth A. Flatto; the developers; and Harry Harris, chief of public transportation at the state Transportation Department.
The letter sets forth plans for a development of five clustered office buildings with a total of 750,000 square feet, each with underground parking. The plan also envisions a station house with a waiting room, a retail component and restaurant; three parking garages; a 200-room hotel; a 42,000-square-foot day care center and health club; a 1,500-car commuter parking lot; and a greenbelt walkway along Ash Creek, separating Fairfield from Bridgeport.
"It makes sense to locate an office park with immediate access to mass transit," said Mark Barnhart, Fairfield's economic development director. Without a station, the offices could not attract tenants; with a station, parking and traffic problems in Fairfield's downtown generated by two existing stations would be eased. Currently, there is a waiting list of 1,500 residents seeking commuter parking permits, in addition to the 1,900 people who already have them. In Fairfield County, only Stamford, with 2,500 daily peak-hour commuters, exceeds Fairfield, with 2,200.
Next month the agreement, which is binding only on the signatories, is to be voted on officially by the entire Boards of Selectmen, Finance, and Planning and Zoning and by the Representative Town Meeting. A series of approvals of conservation and site plan details must be obtained from various government agencies before demolition of a derelict foundry on the site can proceed. The property would then be decontaminated, and after a year of design work, construction could begin, Mr. Stauber said. 
The hotel may be the first component to be built. "The I-95 corridor is not well served with hotels," Mr. Stauber said. According to Mr. Wittek, "We have been in discussions with every major hotel company and they are interested. We would build the hotel and retail attached to the station house first, simultaneously with the town's construction of the parking lot." Office construction would not start until tenants had committed to lease at least 75,000 square feet in one 150,000-square-foot building. 
Over the years, public attention to the development has not been intense, but residents have expressed worry about possible costs to the public that have not been well defined, about losing town control of commercial development that could take 10 to 15 years and about the threat to Fairfield's quiet, upscale, country ambience.
"People don't know a lot about the town's fiscal commitment to this project," said Meg Francis, a member of the Board of Finance. "They are concerned about the possibility of the commercial development not working out and wonder what benefit accrues to the town if it does."
Mr. Flatto expects annual tax receipts generated by the project to grow to $4 million or $5 million by 2012, plus revenues from parking. "That could help pay back a good portion of bonding for new schools," he said. A comprehensive school construction program has been approved after an influx of families swelled Fairfield's population by more than 4,000, to 57,340, in 2000 to 2002. Approximately $163 million worth of bonds are to be floated for two new elementary schools, a second middle school and the reopening and renovation of a second high school, closed since 1988. 
THE prospect of higher payments for schools is causing many residents to focus on Black Rock Park, as the development is tentatively called, to help the public treasury. To begin with, 90 percent of the town's 33.1 square miles are zoned residential, and according to Paul Hiller, Fairfield's director of finance, 82.7 percent of property taxes are paid by 10,280 households, and only 9.4 percent are paid by commercial property owners. "During the past two revaluations, four and eight years ago, residential values went up by 68 percent," he said, "while commercial values went up by 37 percent. Taxes on my house went up 19 percent last July." 
Residential real estate has been pushed upward in the past decade by sales prices far above the norm for Fairfield, including a current asking price of $13 million for the home of General Electric's former chief executive, Jack Welch. Martha Stewart's house was sold in 2000 for $10 million, and other homes have sold for up to $24 million, Mr. Hiller said. Fairfield is or has been home to the chairmen of I.B.M. and Xerox and the chief executive of Lehman Brothers, as well as Mike Nichols and Diane Sawyer, the family of Leonard Bernstein and the actor Jason Robards.
In some cases the revaluations actually reduced commercial property taxes. The town's largest taxpayer, General Electric, whose corporate headquarters are in Fairfield, paid $1.5 million last year, but this year it will pay $1.3 million.
Only 1.6 million square feet of offices exist in Fairfield, said Joseph Devonshuk, the town planner, and aside from Black Rock Park there are no applications for more. The town's commercial real estate consists mainly of automobile dealerships, small office buildings and some stores on Commerce Drive; shops on Route 1; and the 10-year-old 120,000-square-foot BJ's Warehouse Club, a discount emporium at a site called Bullard Square, named for the Bullard Company foundry, which it renovated and occupies opposite the Black Rock Park site. Next to BJ's are two multiplex cinemas with 21 screens. 
Last April, the town's largest office building, 140,000 square feet, opened at 501 Kings Highway (Route 1). It is on the fringe of the business district but close to the Black Rock project. The Board of Education purchased 24,000 square feet as an office condominium, and a few tenants have taken spaces of 3,000 and 4,000 square feet. The structure's builder, Harold Fischel, said 48 percent is vacant raw space, but local brokers who have been showing it estimate the vacancy rate is much higher, around 100,000 square feet, but they say the building could benefit from its location when the new train station is built. Other attractions at the site are tenant parking for 540 cars and relatively low rents, which brokers say are around $28 a square foot per year.
Marshall Madow, a commercial broker at Coldwell Banker's Fairfield office and a longtime town resident, said: "From a resident's point of view, taxes are skyrocketing here, and Black Rock will have a great effect on taxes, but I'm bothered by the lack of obligation for the developer to build out the project. Speaking as a commercial realtor, Black Rock will be a much bigger area to play in. This is basically a bedroom community; you can't bring in a major tenant now."
UNDER the terms of the three-party letter of intent, the town would be responsible for buying 10 acres of the property from the developers, cleaning it up and building the commuter lot at a cost of $6 million. A $4 million federal grant would pay for road and traffic improvements in the area. The state would invest $25 million in building the station platforms and a four-lane bridge over the tracks to provide access to northbound trains. Black Rock Realty would finance the commercial elements, a roadway through the development and the Ash Creek greenbelt.
There are those who believe that Black Rock could come to fruition at the wrong economic time, to which David Gorbach, president of Colonial Realty in Fairfield, a residential and commercial firm, replies, "By the time Wittek gets all his permits, the market has a good chance of improving." He added: "At the moment it's just backfilling a lot of sublease space. Large users don't even look here, but now any broker worth his salt is going to put Wittek's project on his plate."

HEADLINE: Executive Life; 
No, I Insist: You Pick Up the Check

BYLINE:  By LISA NAPOLI 

 BODY:
EVERYBODY knows that companies have cut their employees' expense accounts in this sputtering economy. But it took a lunch with four other business travelers during a trade show last fall in Los Angeles for Hal Bringman, a public relations executive, to witness close up the new tightfistedness of his fellow executives.
 At a table at the Brasserie Vert in Hollywood, Mr. Bringman, along with an employee, a venture capitalist, the chief executive of a start-up and a senior strategist at a Fortune 100 company, dined on inexpensive bowls of pasta. Then the check arrived. At less than $80, the price was a far cry from those of lavish meals Mr. Bringman had enjoyed during the dot-com boom, when he helped mold the public image of the music-sharing services MP3.com and Napster. Even so, his table companions -- one of whom had tried to steer the group to a cheaper eatery -- froze momentarily in their seats. 
 "Everyone was sort of looking at it, as if it was bathed in anthrax," said Mr. Bringman, the founder of Hal Bringman Public Relations, a boutique firm in Los Angeles. "Not too long ago, there would have a duel to pick up the tab. Instead, everyone just plunked down a 20 and hoped they got change back."
To hear some corporate executives tell it, the new stinginess cuts across the spectrum of American business. Many of those who described their employers' parsimony requested anonymity, for obvious reasons. But the anecdotes they told were revealing.
One Wall Street broker said expenses were now taken out of his gross production figures. A producer at a video production company in New York described how a client rescinded her offer to pay for dinner at an expensive restaurant once she saw the bill. The president of an e-commerce business tied to an established brick-and-mortar industry said he had eliminated the first-class flying privileges and the use of a limousine service that he had demanded in contract negotiations.
And a manager at a wireless company in Europe said that the weekly delivery of fruit baskets to the office had been eliminated and that the use of taxis for company business and of mobile phones for personal calls had been forbidden. "Everyone must fly coach," even on trips to Asia, she said. "Even a new mobile phone must be authorized by the V.P. of our unit, so no one wants to go to him for approval. It's embarrassing. Expense accounts are gone."
Corporations tighten spending whenever the economy is wobbly, of course, but this time the cutbacks have been especially conspicuous because they contrast so sharply with the excesses of the 1990's. Back then, internal controls over employees' expense accounts were sometimes considered a joke, even by the people who were supposed to enforce them, according to the chairman of an audit committee at an aluminum and plastics company.
When the executive took on the oversight responsibility five years ago as one of the company's directors, he said, "It was little more than a wonderful idea to make shareholders believe we were paying attention."
All that has changed. "If the officers are not playing ball and not counting the pennies, how can you stand in good conscience before shareholders and eliminate dividends?" he asked. "There are real questions about who's paying the bill."
Two years ago, when he became chief executive of an ailing Australian Internet company, he said, he engineered a similar shift in attitude there: he first eliminated the twice-a-week visits to the staff of a massage therapist. "The culture of the time was, 'Gosh, we're not employees, we're a team, we're a family, we'll work 24/7, we'll bring our dogs to work, our kids to work,' " he said.
That mind-set had begun to creep into the corporate mainstream when the bubble burst. Bill Margeson, president of CBL Data Recovery Technologies, a provider of computer data recovery services in Armonk, N.Y., recalled that one of the first things he and his staff would do on business trips in the free-spending days was to scout around for a good restaurant.
Now, Mr. Margeson said, the trips are shorter and decidedly focused on, well, getting work done. "We call it a blitz," he said. "People get right down to business now. The fluff has evaporated. We find it easier to survive and accomplish. I was a little tired of those steak dinners and the Chateau neuf-du-Pape. You do start to waddle if that's all you've got."
His company has eliminated first-class flying and the other trappings of what he calls the "utopia feeling" that dominated business dealings in recent years. "It was the Hilton; now it's the Motel 6," he said.
Brendan McGovern, who has worked in New York's Silicon Alley for seven years, has witnessed a similar swing back to basics. When he was controller for North America at Agency.com, an Internet consulting company that was acquired by Seneca Investments in 2001, he marveled at all the free food -- sandwiches at lunchtime and plates of "cookies sprinkled with M&M's" in the afternoon -- lavished on employees.
In contrast, at Meetup.com, the eight-month-old business in New York where he is now vice president for finance and administration, the bootstrap mentality is at full tilt. For an office move, Mr. McGovern said, the six-member staff just packed up a U-Haul.
Does he prefer the boom years to today's climate? "One was not real, and one is real," he said. "We've all been rudely awakened to the realization that P.& L. is what it is," he said, referring to profit and loss. "Your expenses have to be less than your revenues. You're going to cut the things that are easy to cut."
THAT doesn't mean, of course, that expense accounts have disappeared. Thomas Morling, who has worked in sales for 20 years and is building a consulting practice for a technology company in the New York area, still takes clients to lunch on the company dime the way he always has. But he is more cautious about how many people he invites, and about where he goes.
"The days of $2,100 dinners are history," Mr. Morling said. "It's not financially acceptable, nor socially acceptable. It's a time when people are enjoying being frugal."

HEADLINE: MONEY & MEDICINE; 
Risky Turn on Madison Avenue

BYLINE:  By MICHELLE ANDREWS; Michelle Andrews is a freelance writer in Manhattan specializing in health care. Her column on its economics appears the third Sunday of each month. E-mail: moneymeds@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
THE printed advertisement showed water gushing through an opening in a dam. "It could feel like this again," the accompanying text said. Puzzled? You probably wouldn't be if you knew where the ad appeared: in the men's restrooms of 100 or so restaurants in Minneapolis and St. Paul last year. The ads, sponsored by Medtronic, the medical device manufacturer, promoted a minimally invasive procedure that can be administered by a urologist to help relieve urinary discomfort from an enlarged prostate.
 The company, based in Minneapolis, also ran ads in the women's restrooms at the same restaurants, promoting an implantable device to relieve incontinence. These ads had an empowerment theme: "Bladder control problems shouldn't control your life. You should." 
 Talk about advertising with a target. People who suffer from incontinence or an enlarged prostate may use the restroom dozens of times a day. "We have the attention of the individual," said Scott R. Ward, president of Medtronic's diabetes and neurological division, which includes its urology business.
Medtronic isn't the only medical device manufacturer to increase its advertising to consumers, though its ad placements may be the most creative. Consumers, however, need to be cautious when it comes to ads for medical devices, a broadly defined category that covers everything from tongue depressors to pacemakers to hemodialysis machines.
Unlike drugs, which can often be discontinued with little ill effect, undoing the effects of problems with some medical devices can be difficult or sometimes impossible.
"In the last 10 years, medical device manufacturers have seen the extreme success that pharmaceutical manufacturers have had with direct-to-consumer advertising," said Charles Whelan, an industry analyst at Frost & Sullivan, a marketing consulting and training firm in San Jose, Calif. "And they said, 'We should get a piece of this, too.' "
A recent report by the General Accounting Office estimates that at least 8.5 million Americans a year request and receive specific prescriptions after seeing or hearing ads for particular drugs.
Mr. Ward said weekly inquiries from consumers to Medtronic for the two therapies tripled after the campaign, which ran from August to October. The company plans a nationwide rollout of similar ads in major metropolitan areas this year. 
Sharon Guess, 47, saw plenty of ads for Lasik eye surgery before deciding to have the procedure last March. She probably wishes she didn't. Ms. Guess, a quality-control representative for an automotive component manufacturer in Rochester, said she had done her research carefully to find a doctor who was qualified to perform the surgery. But, she said, only about a minute after beginning the procedure, the doctor stopped and said he couldn't continue. The problem: the surgical blade he was using came apart in her eye, cutting her cornea, she said. Ms. Guess said she was left with permanently blurred vision in her right eye and may need a corneal transplant. In December, she filed a $40 million lawsuit in state Supreme Court in New York against Bausch & Lomb, which manufactures the blade. 
Margaret Graham, a spokeswoman for Bausch & Lomb, based in Rochester, declined to comment on the suit, but said the type of blade in question had never before been the subject of a lawsuit.
Medical devices are different from drugs in another important way. Consumers, accustomed to the Food and Drug Administration's rigorous approval process for drugs, may assume that the same applies to medical devices. It doesn't. Only about 50 devices -- including pacemakers and heart valves -- must go through a clinical data collection process, similar to what a drug would go through to prove safety and effectiveness, before being introduced to the market.
Some 3,200 devices, or more than 98 percent of the total, go through a much more abbreviated process that usually does not require clinical trials. Devices in this group include hip implants, apnea monitors for infants, blood glucose meters for diabetics and pregnancy tests.
In these cases, the manufacturer may decide on its own that the new device is "substantially equivalent" to one already on the market and go through a simpler approval process.
What can that mean in practice?
If, for example, a product that's already on the market is safe but not very effective, "as long as you can match the product on the market, you can be just as crummy as they are, as long as you're just as safe and just as crummy," said Harold A. Pellerite, assistant to the director for the compliance office at the F.D.A.'s Center for Devices and Radiological Health. 
You can advertise your product as being just as good as the next one, too. In the absence of clinical trials data, "people don't have the information they need to evaluate whether one product is better than others," said Dr. Sidney Wolfe, director of Public Citizen's Health Research Group, based in Washington. "It's easier for companies to make extravagant claims," he added.
Perhaps Medtronic's prostate therapy does work wonders. But when I look at that ad, and I think about the prospect of being deluged with even more medical ads that I don't understand and don't know how to evaluate, I want to put my finger in the dike (or in this case, dam) and say, "No more!"

Nicole Spitz, Nicholas Miller

HEADLINE: Footlights 

BYLINE:  By ROBERTA HERSHENSON; E-mail address: westarts@nytimes.com

 BODY:
Jazz for Everyone
Jazz has moved squarely into the mainstream since the Jazz Studies program at the Purchase College Conservatory of Music began in 1992 -- thanks to programs like Jazz at Lincoln Center and Ken Burns's series on public television. Even television commercials are using jazz. As Todd Coolman, director of the Purchase program, said, "Someone on Madison Avenue has decided that jazz is cool." 
 Jazz used to be passed on informally in jam sessions from mentors to talented newcomers, but learning takes place now in classrooms as well as in smoky clubs. 
 But jazz in advertising, jazz in elevators, jazz in the classroom and jazz when you're on hold on the telephone does not necessarily translate into great profits for jazz, especially in an age of unregulated and often illegal downloading of music from the Internet. Mr. Coolman regards the economic "disasters in the jazz recording industry" as the darker side of the jazz world. He says that when teachers perform they are also doing "field research" for their students on the pitfalls of the business world. "We try to bring our expertise to them," he said. 
To celebrate the program's 10th anniversary, the school is issuing a CD called "Jazz Faculty @ Purchase College 10th Anniversary Celebration." Besides Mr. Coolman, a bass player who has won a Grammy award, the players include the trumpeter Jon Faddis; Grammy winners Jim Pugh on trombone and Hal Galper on piano; and the guitarist Doug Munro, the first full-time jazz faculty member, who is credited with building up the program. 
The CD will be available in the spring for $15 at all Purchase jazz events. Information: (914) 251-5908.

Two Loves
Lawrence Del Casale does not know which he loves more: playing classical guitar or teaching music to third and fourth graders. Luckily he does not have to choose. His day job is teaching at the Woodside School in Peekskill, where he often gives mini guitar recitals for students. 
He also performs at places like Weill Recital Hall at Carnegie Hall, where he will appear with the classical guitarist Carlos Barbosa-Lima on March 14. Closer to home (he lives in Cortlandt Manor), he will give a free recital at the Katonah Public Library next Sunday at 3:30 p.m., playing music by Ernesto Cordero, Villa-Lobos, Bach and others. Information: (914) 232-3508.
Mr. Del Casale, who has recorded a CD of the music of Mr. Cordero, a Puerto Rican composer, takes his love of Spanish music and poetry to the classroom. At their spring concert, his students will sing one of the composer's pieces in Spanish.
It is called "Callate Silencio Mio," which Mr. Del Casale translates as "Quiet, I'm in such grief and pain that if you speak, I'll die." 

When Movies Go Dancing
 Tango dancing in the streets, the Daedalus and Icarus legend set in Africa and a portrait of the "Queen of the Gypsies" are all part of the "Dance on Camera" film series at the Jacob Burns Film Center in Pleasantville from Jan. 31 through Feb. 4. Comic dance, modern dance and ballet will also be included in this look at dance through the camera's lens. The series, a collaboration with the Film Society of Lincoln Center, will focus on dance from South America, Spain, Africa and the United States.
On Feb. 2, Elliot Caplan, an award-winning director/producer, will introduce and discuss "Utango," his short film about tango on the streets of Buenos Aires; a scene from the film is pictured at left. Information: (914) 747-5555.

Totem to Tooth Fairy
The Westchester Arts Council announced Friday that 42 arts organizations and 3 artists would share $58,000 in Arts Alive grants for the coming year. Arts Alive Grants, which are financed by the Decentralization Program of the New York State Council on the Arts, provide grassroots financial and technical support for emerging cultural groups and ethnically based cultural activities, according to the arts council.
Some examples of projects include "cosmic totem" sculptures that will be produced at the Mount Vernon Public Library; the premiere of an original play, "The Substitute Tooth Fairy," to be performed free at 20 public libraries by the Yorktown Community Players; the Westchester Chordsmen's annual spring concert; and a full production by the New Rochelle Opera of "The Merry Widow" by Franz Lehar. The grants range from $1,000 to $4,200. ROBERTA HERSHENSON

HEADLINE: STRATEGIES; 
It's O.K. toReach for Unreachable Star Managers

BYLINE:  By MARK HULBERT; Mark Hulbert is editor of The Hulbert Financial Digest, a service of CBS MarketWatch. His column on investment strategies appears every other week. E-mail: strategy@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
INVESTORS are behaving rationally when they engage in apparently pointless searches for mutual fund managers who can beat the market over the long run, according to a new study.
 That conclusion may seem puzzling when viewed next to extensive previous research showing that only a handful of portfolio managers can beat the overall stock market for extended periods. Most researchers have assumed that investors who persist in spending time and money on a quest for star managers are acting out of some sort of irrational compulsion. 
 But Jonathan B. Berk, a finance professor at the University of California at Berkeley, and Richard C. Green, a financial economist at Carnegie Mellon University, have concluded that this behavior is sensible, even if largely fruitless. They say that the market for portfolio managers is just as efficient as the stock market itself. (Their research is available online at papers.ssrn.com/sol3 /papers.cfm?abstract-id=338881). 
In developing their model of how the market for money managers operates, the professors drew together findings, previously considered unrelated, from other researchers' studies. The first is the strong correlation between past performance and the flow of money among funds. In other words, investors systematically move cash into funds that have had the best performance.
The second finding involves managers' increasing difficulty in beating the market as they have more cash to invest. That is largely attributable to the poorer prices they receive when buying and selling larger blocks of stock. A manager can buy almost any stock without affecting its price when his total portfolio is worth $10 million, but not when he is managing $10 billion.
Of course, managers who avoid that problem by expanding the number of stocks in their portfolios face another quandary: it is harder to analyze every stock on a "buy list" of several hundred stocks as carefully as every stock on a list of just 20.
Professors Berk and Green contend that these features combine to create a Catch-22. Some managers are talented enough to outperform the market if their portfolios remain small, the professors said. But when investors become aware of the managers' talents, they pour money into the portfolios, and their performance deteriorates.
Consider a basketball player whose field-goal percentage is much higher than that of his teammates. It is entirely rational for them to pass the ball to him and let him take the shots. That will cause his field goal percentage to fall, as he is double-teamed. But his teammates still have reason to keep passing to him so long as his percentage remains higher than theirs.
The analogy is not perfect, of course. But it helps us understand that declining performance by a portfolio manager who gets large inflows of cash does not necessarily mean that he's an inferior stock picker. Just as it's not irrational for the star shooter's teammates to keep passing him the ball, it is not irrational for investors to invest new money with a star manager. It does mean, though, that both strategies, over time, are likely to end in disappointment.
A few managers have been able to continue beating the market even after attracting large amounts of investors' money. Consider Bill Miller, manager of Legg Mason Value Trust. His fund has beaten the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index in the last 12 years, and its assets under management have grown tenfold. The professors nevertheless predict that his fund will eventually attract so much cash that he will be unable to continue his remarkable streak.
If the stock market and the market for portfolio managers are equally efficient, as the professors conclude, how should investors react? Put simply, their search for money managers should be much like their search for stocks. In each case, it is reasonable for investors to seek those rare opportunities that have not yet been widely discovered. But if they cannot find them, they should choose an index fund.

HEADLINE: PRELUDES; 
So, Let the Rat Races Begin!

BYLINE:  By ABBY ELLIN; Abby Ellin is a Manhattan writer. Her column on starting out in the world of money appears the third Sunday of each month. E-mail: preludes@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
I HAVE developed a craving for the corporate cafeteria, the corporate desk, the water cooler and the copy machine. I want to wake up each day, deck myself in Armani and join the throngs of workers with a defined purpose, or at least have a place to go in the mornings besides Starbucks.
 I had always been antiestablishment, shunning the corporate life. I never wanted to deal with office politics or to have someone tell me when I could take a vacation and for how long, or make me show up at work the same time each day. 
 So why do I suddenly want to stop freelancing after 13 years and join the so-called corporate rat race?
It's not about money, although I'm a big fan of the steady paycheck. It's more about belonging and the desire for responsibility and community. It's also about identity.
Sure, many free agents have come up with strategies for dealing with the loneliness and isolation of working independently. In recent years, makeshift office spaces have sprung up for such workers, like the kind offered by HQ Global Workplaces of Addison, Tex.: the worker pays for a desk, phone line and computer and sits side by side with other free agents or those running fledgling businesses. There are also plenty of organized support groups, both online and off.
That works for some people, but I'm not interested in being part of a group of disembodied voices or a band of outsiders. Rather, I want to be part of something greater than myself.
Dr. Debra Condren, a business psychologist and president of the career-consulting firm HumanInvestment.com in New York, says my new attitude is more the norm. "Unless you're that rare entrepreneurial maverick person, after a while the isolation begins to wear away on you," she said. "When you're around other people you have the periodic spontaneous think-tank environment and the rapid-fire meetings across the table. Just being around other people, you get a kind of synergy that you can't get from the U.P.S. guy or doorman."
Of course, Dr. Condren said, there's no guarantee that this will happen every day, even in the proverbial 9-to-5 job. But working with others still means greater opportunities than sitting around your house waiting for the sushi delivery man. 
Some people think I'm crazy, that freelancing is where it's at. "I love it," said John Walters, a sportswriter who was laid off from Sports Illustrated in 2000. Since then, Mr. Walters, 36, says he has covered sporting events he would never have had the chance to cover, traveled and self-published a book about the University of Connecticut's 2000-01 women's basketball team. But this way of life is new to him -- he hasn't been doing it since he was 21, as I have.
Indeed, both age and time have influenced my decision, and other independent young professionals seem to be feeling the same, especially with the economy so uncertain.
Victor Marsh, 36, a freelance theater set designer in Manhattan, notes that finding freelance work can be stressful. "It's extremely difficult to keep the momentum up to look for another job; it's a full-time job in and of itself," he said. "I'm ready for a change."
Ellen Catsikeas, 35, a freelance filmmaker who often works as an assistant director on films and commercials in Greece, has never had a steady job but says she is re-evaluating her situation. "You start to feel, 'Am I too old for this?' My friends envy me; they think it's the most wonderful thing to be free. But they don't understand that I work 15- , 16-hour days sometimes. I'm not as free as they think."
Most freelancers I know work practically around the clock, which translates into blurred lines between their work and personal lives. (I'm terribly nocturnal, so I'm often at my desk while the rest of the world sleeps.) That might have been O.K. in the dot-com heyday, when people were tethered to their computers at all hours. But now I'm thinking it might be healthier to have a defined workday and work space. 
Of course, I'm still a rebel; I would take a full-time job only if it offered the right mix of flexibility, money and freedom. But an editor friend put it in perspective when he said: "Look at it as an adventure. You've had freedom, so now do something else. You can always quit."
Sometimes I wonder if I have done myself a disservice by refusing to play by conventional rules. Maybe there's something to being part of the masses, at least temporarily.
As Dr. Condren said, "Isolating oneself workwise can become a bad habit, a false comfort zone that protects you from further professional rejection. It's important to debunk the myth that isolation provides real security, and to help people see professional isolation for what it is: an excuse to avoid exposing oneself in the open market."
In some ways, the idea of making a change seems somewhat moot right now. We're still in the midst of what feels like a recession and jobs are scarce. But the wheels have started turning. I'm just not sure if this is growing up, or giving up.
