PERSON: Ed Fire 

HEADLINE: Private Sector; 
Stirring Words, Realist Tactics

BYLINE:  By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: EAST CLEVELAND, Ohio 

 BODY:
IT was 19 degrees and the wind was whipping off Lake Erie as Ed Fire climbed onto the back of a pickup last Tuesday to address 150 workers who were on strike against General Electric.
 "The greed of General Electric must stop," thundered Mr. Fire, president of G.E.'s largest union, as he denounced the company for increasing employee health care co-payments this month. 
 Then, in his booming baritone voice, Mr. Fire quoted the Mexican revolutionary Emiliano Zapata, telling the shivering strikers why their two-day walkout was noble. "I would rather die on my feet as a man than live on my knees as a dog," he said. "Let's show G.E. that we're not going to live on our knees." 
The workers applauded through thick gloves, and Mr. Fire responded with a huge smile. He was doing what he loves: standing up for workers and preaching that labor unions are the best way for American workers to secure and defend middle-class wages and benefits.
Mr. Fire is president of the International Union of Electronic Workers-Communications Workers of America, which represents 14,000 G.E. workers. That is a sharp drop from 45,000 in 1979, a result of automation, downsizing and operations moved abroad. The I.U.E., one of the unions hurt most by globalization, has shrunk to 100,000 members from 242,000 in 1979.
"Its power has fallen dramatically," said John Russo, director of the labor studies program at Youngstown State University in Ohio.
Mr. Fire said he pushed for last week's walkout to show G.E. that the workers are a force that cannot be trampled upon. It was the biggest recent strike over health care, the No. 1 issue of dispute in labor negotiations, and companies and unions across the land are closely watching how the G.E. dispute plays out. In calling the two-day strike, Mr. Fire had one eye on negotiations in June, when the union's three-year contract with G.E. expires.
"We see this strike as a deterrent," Mr. Fire, 66, said in an interview. "We want to show that if they plan to come at us with a club in the nationwide bargaining and if they think they're going to beat us into submission in terms of shifting other serious health costs onto the workers, they're just plain wrong."
Despite such skewering, even some G.E. officials voice respect for Mr. Fire. "He finds a way to communicate in a very folksy way to the membership," said Bill Conaty, G.E.'s senior vice president for human resources. "He can energize a crowd. He's basically a very decent, hard-working guy."
Mr. Fire was not always such an avid advocate of unions, even though his father, a blacksmith at a foundry, was financial secretary of a machinists' union local in Youngstown. Mr. Fire cared little about unions until he took a factory job at the age of 22 in Warren, Ohio, with Packard Electric, a General Motors division.
"When I was 16, I was a lot more interested in girls than in unions or the salvation of mankind," said Mr. Fire, a short, stocky man who says he works out every day. He became interested in unions only after a friend suggested that he attend a union meeting and only after he was inspired by a philosophy professor at Youngstown State, where he studied for several years.
"This professor really opened my eyes up to see we have a duty and calling beyond just making money," Mr. Fire said.
Mr. Fire was born in Lowellville, Ohio, the son of immigrants from Italy. After finishing high school, he joined the Navy at 17, serving in the Mediterranean as a radio operator until he turned 21. 
Returning to Ohio, he took the job with Packard Electric. "When you went into a factory in those days, you had to turn your brain off because the work was not challenging," he said. "I didn't feel stimulated until I got involved in union work."
In 1965, he was elected president of a 13,000-member I.U.E. local. When the union's chief negotiator with G.M. died in 1977, Mr. Fire took his place. In 1980, he became the union's district director for six states.
In 1982, when the union's president died, the board selected Bill Bywater as president and Mr. Fire as secretary-treasurer. They were elected as a team in 1984, 1988 and 1992, but in 1996 Mr. Fire challenged Mr. Bywater, then 76, for the presidency. Mr. Fire won.
"The was deterioriting," he said. "Bill was just not dealing with what we has to do to save the union."
With his union losing 6,000 workers a year, Mr. Fire wanted to link with a larger union. He arranged a merger in 2000 with the Communications Workers of America. 
Morton Bahr, the C.W.A.'s president, welcomed the partnership with Mr. Fire, saying, "Philosophically, we were on the same plane, meaning progressive in lots of areas, militant but responsible."
Mr. Fire, who has three grown children and five grandchildren, is twice divorced, acknowledging that his dedication to union matters hurt his marriages.
While Mr. Fire seems confrontational against G.E., he can take a cooperative tack. "Under him, the I.U.E. has partnered with corporations to help the union and various factories survive," said Sandra Kennedy of the Center for Labor-Management Cooperation at Wright State University in Dayton, Ohio.
As an example of such cooperation, Mr. Fire said he negotiated a contract, in which new workers earned less than old ones did, to persuade G.M. not to close a factory in Rochester. But some union critics said such two-tier agreements showed that Mr. Fire was too accommodating to management.
"A union leader has to be realistic and pragmatic," Mr. Fire said. "You have to bargain on the basis of the economic facts of life."
BUT he asserted that with G.E. turning a profit of $14 billion, or $45,000 a worker, last year, the economic facts don't justify raising health co-payments an estimated $200 to $400 a year a worker.
"How can a company say they're having a problem with higher health costs when they're enjoying record profits?" Mr. Fire said. He said G.E. forced him to take a more combative approach than did G.M., Visteon and Delphi, where his union represents thousands of workers.
"You can't take anything away from G.E.; they're an extremely well-managed company," Mr. Fire said. "In terms of their relationship with us, G.E. tolerates the union. They have never accepted us."
Mr. Conaty says G.E. is in more businesses, and often in more competitive businesses, than are the auto companies and thus needed to work harder to stay competitive.
"We get this talk about greed and profits, but there's one important fact -- our earnings went up 7 percent last year, but our health care costs went up 14 percent," Mr. Conaty said. "With healthcare, something has to give."
But Mr. Fire, who is threatening a strike in June, isn't buying that argument. "You're not going to convince G.E. to do anything on the basis of what's fair, what's simple justice," he said. "What influences this company is the persuasion of power, not the power of persuasion."

HEADLINE: Investing; 
Are Small Caps a Size Too Big?

BYLINE:  By VIRGINIA MUNGER KAHN 

 BODY:
IN 2001, when small-capitalization stocks outperformed large caps, investors poured $28 billion into small-cap mutual funds. 
 The deluge caused a problem for many small-cap fund managers. As their funds swelled in size, managers found it more difficult to invest profitably in a market of relatively modest size. Many of the most popular funds closed their doors to new investors. 
 Last year, though, small-cap stocks performed almost as poorly as the overall market, and since June, investors have generally been pulling money out of the sector. Partly as a result, several of the shuttered small-cap funds have reopened. Those include Fidelity Low-Priced Stock, Buffalo Small Cap, T. Rowe Price New Horizons and Wasatch Core Growth, which has reopened only to existing shareholders.
Even so, moving money into these reopened funds may not be the best approach for investors who believe that the small-cap sector is ready for a rally, some fund analysts say.
"I would worry that if the market takes off, these funds' asset size will make them sluggish," said Philip Edwards, managing director in charge of global fund research at Standard & Poor's. 
Buffalo Small Cap has $721.6 million in assets, while Wasatch Core Growth has $1.04 billion, T. Rowe Price New Horizons has $3.36 billion, and Fidelity Low-Priced Stock has $15.54 billion. Mr. Edwards suggested that investors look for smaller funds.
Jeremy DeGroot, director of mutual fund research at Litman/Gregory Asset Management in Orinda, Calif., said: "The fundamental rule is, past performance is not predictive of future performance. You have to look at the characteristics of the fund now and base your investment decision on that."
Other analysts, including those at Morningstar, continue to recommend Fidelity Low-Priced Stock, Buffalo Small Cap and Wasatch Core Growth. "These are very impressive offerings," said Emily Hall, senior mutual fund analyst at Morningstar. "Most of these firms have shown their willingness to close funds before assets get out of control."
Ms. Hall noted that many small-cap funds closed when their assets approached $1 billion. But Fidelity Low-Priced Stock has defied the conventional wisdom about asset size by posting returns that rank among the top 8 percent of small-cap blend funds for the last one, three and five years.
While funds with large asset bases should be approached with caution, there is no science to picking the maximum asset size of a small-cap fund, Mr. Edwards said.
In many ways, the returns of the funds will depend on how well small stocks perform in general, and there is no consensus on that outlook. Historically, small caps have performed well coming out of recessions because small companies are more likely to be affected by economic cycles. In the 12 months after the eight recessions tracked by the Leuthold Group from 1954 through 1991, small-cap stocks averaged gains of 39 percent, versus 21 percent for large-cap stocks. 
JIM COLLINS, the chairman and chief executive of Insight Capital Research and Management in Walnut Creek, Calif., said he expected small-cap stocks to perform much as they did in the early 1990's, when the United States was emerging from a mild recession and faced the prospect of war in the Persian Gulf. 
From 1991 through 1993, small caps gained 115.8 percent, more than double the 54.6 percent for large caps, Mr. Collins said.
"I would suggest investors take a hard look at small caps now," he said. 
The Russell 2000 stock index, a proxy for small caps, declined by 18.6 percent for the 12 months through Thursday, compared with a 20.2 percent decline for the S.& P. 500 index.
The market has discounted small-cap stocks out of concern that the economy will tip back into a recession, said Tim Hayes, global equity strategist at Ned Davis Research in Venice, Fla. But he disagrees.
"Our work shows we are not going into a double-dip recession," he said. "Where we are in the stock market and economic cycle tends to favor small-cap stocks."
Earnings of small caps over all have not yet picked up, largely because many technology and biotechnology companies are still losing money, said Jack Laporte, president and portfolio manager at T. Rowe Price New Horizons. He said the sector would rebound when earnings improved. "I think that will happen," he said. "It has historically."
Some analysts and portfolio managers say investors should make a finer distinction by focusing on small-cap growth funds as opposed to value funds. After three years of outperformance by small-cap value stocks, Mr. Collins said, it is time for the cycle to shift back to growth. Growth and value cycles, he added, tend to reverse about every three years.
From the Nasdaq's peak in March 2000 through the third quarter of 2002, for example, the Russell 2000 Growth index fell 61.9 percent, while the Russell 2000 Value index rose 12.6 percent. The underperformance of small-cap growth stocks, compared with small-cap value stocks, has never been greater or lasted longer, Mr. Laporte said.
Mr. Edwards said that in mutual funds, "investors tend to go with what's working, but this is a great opportunity to be contrarian and get in at a good price."
He said he favored Baron Growth, which has $941 million in assets under management. "We're confident the fund's manager is cognizant of asset size and will not let it hinder performance," he said. The fund has lost 0.04 percent a year, annualized, in the three years through Thursday, placing it among the top 9 percent of small growth funds, according to Morningstar. 
He and Mr. DeGroot also recommend AXA Rosenberg U.S. Small Capitalization, which invests in growth and value stocks and has returned 3.9 percent a year, on average, during the three years through Thursday. That puts it in the top 34 percent of small blend funds. It has $133.3 million in assets under management.
Mr. DeGroot also puts Harbor Small-Cap Growth on his list. The fund lost 14.7 percent in the 12 months through Thursday, placing it in the top 17 percent of small-cap growth funds. It has $103.9 million in assets. While the fund is just two years old, he said, its manager, William A. Muggia, has a good long-term record managing institutional accounts.
Mr. Edwards said that much attention "has been focused on the funds that have reopened, but among funds that have stayed open, there are some real gems."

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH; 
Is VerizonFlying Too High Above Its Valuation?

BYLINE:  By GRETCHEN MORGENSON 

 BODY:
WITH its alluring 4 percent dividend and aura of stability, Verizon Communications has been a stock market star in recent months. Shares in this telecommunications giant, formed two and a half years ago when GTE merged with Bell Atlantic, have jumped 40 percent since the end of September. The stock closed on Friday at $38.50.
 To which Susan Kalla, an analyst at Friedman Billings Ramsey in New York, says pshaw. Ms. Kalla, perhaps the sharpest person covering telecommunications at a brokerage firm today, says Verizon is, at best, a $28 stock. It is showing no revenue growth, almost no profit growth; in short, its business is eroding, she said. 
 Verizon is in a vise. Its local service, which provides the highest profit margins, is in decline. Meanwhile, the company's new dominance in the long-distance market, which it had battled to enter in recent years, could not come at a worse time. "It's an example of be careful what you wish for," Ms. Kalla said. "They are getting into long distance just as it is crashing and burning."
A comparison of the Baby Bells' long-distance revenue with their costs reveals the problem. While revenue comes in around 4.5 cents a minute right now, costs of billing and customer service, upgraded switching software, access charges and other expenses add up to 5.5 cents. And with six major competitors battling for market share, prices of long-distance service could fall even more.
As a result, long-distance will be a money loser for Verizon for at least two years, Ms. Kalla said. With more than 10 million customers in 47 states, Verizon passed Sprint earlier this month to become the third-largest long-distance provider.
The company's local-phone business, which generates 62 percent of its revenue and carries 40 percent margins, could fall 3 percent this year, Ms. Kalla said. The company's wireless operations, which account for one-third of its revenue, make only a minor contribution to earnings. Profit margins are falling in that business because of heavy discounting.
Verizon's D.S.L. business is not likely to add to profits, either, she said.
Looking ahead, Ms. Kalla expects weakness in the economy and rising layoffs to translate into a slowdown in volume at Verizon. The Bell companies, as a group, could lose a million business lines in 2003 because of the economy and joblessness, she estimated. The companies could also lose two million residential lines this year as consumers switch to cellphones and cut back on use of second phone lines. 
Which brings us to Verizon's valuation, which Ms. Kalla figures is rich by about 20 percent. The stock carries a price-to-earnings ratio of almost 13, double the company's long-term earnings growth rate. Measured another way, Verizon is trading at 5.7 times its estimated earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization. A more reasonable multiple, given Verizon's business, would be 4.5, she said.
Investors may have bid up Verizon shares recently in the hope that regulators will eliminate the requirement that Bell companies lease parts of their networks to competitors. Verizon and other Bell companies say that the leases lose them buckets of money.
But in testimony before Congress last week, Michael K. Powell, the chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, backed away from changing the rules governing local phone service.
To be sure, Verizon's 4 percent dividend is compelling. And if taxes on dividends are eliminated, it will become even more so. But if Ms. Kalla is right about its value, and she has been right about a lot in telecom land recently, the stock could yield 5.5 percent in the not-too-distant future. Might be worth the wait.

HEADLINE: A Sinking Feeling At the Register 

BYLINE:  By DAVID LEONHARDT 

 BODY:
ONE year ago, a 50-inch Hitachi television cost $1,400 at Circuit City. It costs $1,000 today.
 Five years ago, automakers charged $25,500 for the average new vehicle. They charge about $24,500 today. 
 A decade ago, a round trip on Delta Air Lines between New York and San Francisco cost $388 -- and it was part of a sale. Delta now sells the same advance-purchase ticket for $317. 
Most stunning is the price path of Burger King's Whopper sandwich, which cost about $1.40 some 20 years ago, when the Dow Jones industrial average hovered around 1,000 and hourly wages were about one-half their current level. This weekend, a Whopper sells for 99 cents.
Deflation, a sustained decline in prices across the economy, remains merely a threat, with overall prices still rising mildly. For some of the nation's largest industries, though, falling prices are a reality. The costs of cars, clothing, electronics, furniture, jewelry, kitchen equipment and toys -- indeed, of most manufactured goods -- have been dropping for more than a year, causing turmoil for companies and their workers. Although airlines and fast food are among the only industries in the service sector to be suffering through declines, overall service prices are rising more slowly than they were two years ago, according to figures released last week.
"More goods are chasing less money," said Arthur J. Rolnick, research director at the Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis, "instead of more money chasing fewer goods."
Worried about falling prices, the Fed lowered its benchmark interest rate again late last year. Officials say deflation remains unlikely but, because it is so hard to stop once it starts, they are taking preventive measures.
The lack of pricing power has been forcing executives to cut costs even as they increase production, and it has helped to make the current economic recovery a jobless one. Almost 200,000 jobs were eliminated across the country in November and December. 
The squeeze has also cost some chief executives their jobs, like Jack M. Greenberg of McDonald's, who resigned last month, shortly before the company announced its first quarterly loss since going public 38 years ago. Other companies, including airlines, automotive suppliers and, last week, FAO, the toy retailer, have filed for bankruptcy protection.
The biggest culprit is the 1990's bubble that left many industries with more goods than they could profitably sell and more capacity than they could use. But the surge of imports from low-cost countries like China, the rise in American productivity and the continuing trend toward deregulation and market-determined prices are all playing roles. 
FACED with stagnant revenue, many companies are aggravating their industries' troubles by further reducing prices to grab pieces of a shrinking pie. 
The weak economic growth of the last year has caused poultry prices, for example, to drop about 1 percent. Tyson Foods, the world's biggest seller of chicken, has responded by offering more promotions to supermarkets, said John Tyson, the chief executive. 
General Motors, the first automaker to offer zero percent financing after Sept. 11, 2001, expanded its incentives last month to match the deals offered by Ford Motor, after G.M. had cut them back in November.
"We go to zero percent, 36 months, then the guys who were griping about incentives go to 60 months," Rick Wagoner, G.M.'s chief executive, said in an interview, referring to competitors. "And guess what? They get big market share, and we don't."
Now "they're going to have to fight toe to toe," Mr. Wagoner said.
Even some products in great demand have become less expensive, as retailers use them to woo customers. Although Chicken Dance Elmo, a doll based on a "Sesame Street" character, is dancing its way off shelves, Wal-Mart and Target still cut its price to $15, from the list price of $20, said Jim Silver, the publisher of The Toy Book, which covers the industry. Other sellers followed quickly, contributing to a 30 percent decline in overall toy prices since 1996.
Across the economy, inflation is running at an annual rate of about 1 percent or 2 percent, depending on the government measure. With the economy still weak, however, economists and policy makers worry that a deflationary trap similar to Japan's is now possible, if unlikely. 
"There are some well-founded reasons to presume that deflation is more of a threat to economic growth than is inflation," Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, said recently. But, he added, "the United States is nowhere close to sliding into a pernicious deflation." 
So long as an economy's demand for goods remains much below its capacity to produce them, inflation tends to decline, and the continuing job cuts suggest that the American economy is still operating well below capacity. If low inflation turns into deflation, unemployment can spike, debts can become unmanageable and, in the most extreme cases, consumers may hold onto their money, waiting for prices to fall further. 
The Fed, by lowering interest rates and making dollars effectively less valuable, can typically cause inflation to rise -- unless banks, consumers and businesses hoard their cash. Even if Fed officials cut their benchmark rate to zero, they can still print more money to keep prices stable or rising at a slow clip, they say. "We can always prevent deflation," Mr. Rolnick said. "There are enough people in central banks around the world who think it's a bad thing that they just aren't going to let it happen."
In recent weeks, a few economists have started wondering if 2003 will be the year inflation reasserts itself. Many of the Fed's interest-rate cuts the last two years are still washing over the economy, giving people reasons to spend, while a war with Iraq could bring both a spike in government spending and a climb in oil prices. The dollar has also lost some of its value recently, and import prices will probably rise as a result.
"I don't know if we've reached the inflection point," said Peter L. Bernstein, an author and economic consultant, "but my impression is that this phase is coming to an end."
There are still worrisome trends, however, that suggest the 1990's spending binge by consumers and executives has left a bigger hangover than a typical expansion does. In most recent downturns, prices in the service sector continued to rise as fast as they had been, largely because demand for services like education, medical care and haircuts does not drop during recessions. Since late 2000, by contrast, inflation in services has fallen to 1.8 percent annually, from 3 percent -- a sign of weak demand, said Stephen Roach, the chief economist at Morgan Stanley and probably the most vocal deflation worrier.
"The good news is that policy is responding," Mr. Roach said. "The bad news is that there's no guarantee it will work."
In many industries, the issue is far more than academic. The battle against runaway inflation in the late 1970's and early 80's was won, but the victory has created its own troubles.
Encouraged by the stability and prosperity of the 90's, American companies spent billions on new factories, equipment and software, vastly increasing their ability to make products. Some service companies helped inflate the bubble, too.
Combined, McDonald's, Burger King and Wendy's opened 6,100 restaurants from 1994 to 2001, expanding by about a third, according to Technomic, a research company in Chicago. Many now compete with one another, as well as with thousands of new outlets of Starbucks, Subway and other chains that have lured customers more successfully than the burger chains.
In response, McDonald's and Burger King have waged price wars, of which the current 99-cent Whopper sale is a part. Wendy's rarely offers discounts, but its president, Thomas J. Mueller, said, "We pride ourselves on not increasing our prices." 
Manufacturers also face new competition from overseas because many foreign companies are attracted to the American market, which they consider the world's healthiest. Since 1995, in fact, the United States has accounted for almost two-thirds of global economic growth, Morgan Stanley says.
In the auto industry, Honda and Toyota began making hundreds of thousands of sport utility vehicles every year. Hyundai captured parts of the low end of the vehicle market. Volkswagen increased its sales here. 
To keep factories running and high fixed costs covered, American companies fought back by offering incentives and markdowns. Today, those discounts are equal to $3,100 a vehicle, twice the level of two years ago, according to Autodata, a research company. A family making the median income now must use about 20 weeks of pay for a new vehicle, compared with 29 weeks in 1996, according to Comerica Bank.
"The competition has basically turned the industry into an unprofitable one," said David E. Cole, president of the Center for Automotive Research, a consulting firm in Ann Arbor, Mich. "The business model is broken." 
The shakeout is beginning. Fiat, the Italian car company, is struggling to stay in business. Ford is planning to cut billions of dollars in expenses this year.
"It's not a very pretty process," Mr. Cole said. "And it's not over."
But globalization's contribution to price pressure can also come wrapped in an American company's label. Since the double-digit inflation of 25 years ago, Mexico, China and other low-wage countries have greatly increased their manufacturing bases. The strong dollar of recent years -- another reflection of the American economy's primacy, even in a slowdown -- has made imports even less expensive. 
Imports have helped prices fall 12 percent for men's pants since 1999 and 10 percent for women's suits, the Labor Department calculates. Furniture prices are down 4 percent.
Ethan Allen, a chain of 315 furniture stores, made nearly all its products in the United States in the early 1990's; now the portion has fallen to 80 percent. Some of its most expensive products, like a $3,000 bed, are made in factories in China and the Philippines that have become much more efficient in recent years, said M. Farooq Kathwari, Ethan Allen's chief executive.
"That has put a tremendous amount of pressure on prices," said Mr. Kathwari, who announced some price cuts late last year. "In the next year or couple of years, I don't see much chance of increasing prices."
Since 2000, Ethan Allen, based in Danbury, Conn., has also cut its work force about 5 percent, to 10,000, while its sales have risen slightly. It operates 17 factories, compared with 27 a decade ago.
Elsewhere, a slow unwinding of government regulation has laid the groundwork for price declines. The federal government stopped setting airline fares in 1978, for instance, but low-fare airlines have only recently established their presence in almost every region of the country. Their success has kept fares flat since 1990, and it played a crucial role in the bankruptcy filings last year by United Airlines and US Airways. 
The rise in productivity in the last decade has also helped bring down inflation. With new technology, new management techniques and an increasingly educated work force, American companies can make more goods than they did in the past while using the same amount of labor. G.M. made a profit in its most recent quarter, despite its discounts, partly by becoming more efficient.
In some previous eras of high productivity, like the late 1800's, deflation and economic growth coexisted as companies and workers split the spoils of their efficiency. The technology sector benefited from a similar virtuous cycle in the 1990's.
Today's wave of price cutting -- stemming mainly from economic weakness -- continues to bring benefits for consumers, but there is little that is virtuous about it for companies caught in its vise.

HEADLINE: INVESTING WITH/Richard C. Pell And Donald Quigley; 
Julius Baer Global Income Fund

BYLINE:  By CAROLE GOULD 

 BODY:
UNTIL late 2000, the $45 million Julius Baer Global Income fund made money betting on the strength of the dollar against foreign currencies.
 But since the spring of 2001, the fund's co-managers, Richard C. Pell and Donald Quigley, have positioned their portfolio to profit from the dollar's decline. Dollar-denominated bonds, which accounted for 80 percent of the fund's assets in June 1999, are now 65 percent of the fund -- the lowest level since Mr. Pell began managing the fund in 1998. 
 "There's been a massive capital outflow into the U.S. over the last 10 years from Japan, Europe and the emerging markets, which had weaker economic growth than the U.S.," Mr. Quigley said from his office in Manhattan. "Now we're seeing signs that foreign investors are more reluctant to send their money here."
The fund can help investors buffer portfolios against declines in the dollar, Mr. Pell said. Most bond investors keep all their wealth in their home currency, he explained, but the dollar makes surprisingly large moves against overseas currencies in cycles of up to 5 or 10 years.
The euro has risen about 25 percent against the dollar in the last two years and is now worth $1.066. "We think that trend can continue much further," Mr. Quigley said.
The fund returned 8.9 percent a year, on average, for the three years through Thursday, ranking in the top 2 percent of all multisector bond funds, which own a mix of domestic and overseas government and corporate bonds. That group rose 4.6 percent, according to Morningstar Inc. 
The fund returned 13.1 percent in the last 12 months, compared with 6.2 percent for its group.
Mr. Pell, 48, is chief investment officer and senior vice president of Julius Baer Investment Management in New York, the fund's adviser and a unit of Julius Baer Holding of Zurich. Mr. Quigley, 37, is a vice president and head of global fixed income for the adviser.
The portfolio generally has 40 or so issues. The managers say a neutral mix, based on the fund's composite benchmark, would be 80 percent of assets in dollar-denominated bonds and 20 percent in those denominated in foreign currencies.
The fund buys investment-grade-rated corporate issues or government or agency debt. Outside the United States, the managers buy only government bonds, minimizing credit risk. Domestically, the fund owns corporate bonds, at 29 percent of the fund's total assets; mortgage-backed securities, at 12 percent; and Treasury securities, at 18 percent. In the Treasury stake, a big chunk -- 7 percent of the fund's assets -- is invested in Treasury inflation-protected securities.
"President Bush is in the same place that his father was 12 years ago, with an election in less than two years and conflict with Iraq," Mr. Pell said. "His father lost the election because of economic weakness, and he'll try to avoid the same mistake. So we expect a tax cut and massive increases in government spending that may have inflationary consequences."
In January 2002, the managers began buying German government bonds with a 5.25 percent coupon due in July 2010. They paid 102.53 euros, on average, or $91.45 at the time, for every 100 euros of face value for the bonds, which are rated AAA by Standard & Poor's; the bond closed on Friday at 108.67 euros, now worth $115.82. While the Federal Reserve has been reducing American interest rates since 2001, Mr. Quigley said, the European Central Bank has been slower to do so and has some catching up to do. He also expects the euro to strengthen further against the dollar, creating a total return of about 12 percent, annualized, in dollar terms during the next five years.
The managers bought 7.625 percent coupon bonds due in February 2005 and issued by the Vodafone Group, the British wireless telecommunications company. They paid $109.963 for each $100 in face value for the bonds, which were issued simultaneously in several global markets, including New York. The bond now trades at $110.24, and because it is denominated in dollars, there is no currency risk. It is rated A by S.& P.
Vodafone "avoided paying for foolish acquisitions during the bubble period," Mr. Quigley said, "and it's going to be able to rise above the telecom fray." The company has strong products, he added, and a strong balance sheet that let the company gain market share during rough times in the industry.
The fund also owns housing bonds from the government of Iceland. Rated AAA, the bonds have a coupon of 4.75 percent and are due in December 2022. The bonds yield about 5 percent, Mr. Quigley said, but an inflation-adjustment feature increases that to 7.65 percent. He said the yield would become even more attractive if inflation rose in Iceland in the next six months, as he expects. 
In April, they paid 134.41 Icelandic krone, or $1.43, for each 100 krone of face value. They now trade at 152.73 krone, or $1.93.
